TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Jarosite Dumping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to (a) reverse the decision to extend the time allowed Pasminco EZ to dump jarosite at sea, and (b) endorse and comply with the December 1995 deadline established by the London Dumping Convention.

PETITION.TITLE: Genital Mutilation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: 1. Concern at the fact that genital mutilation of girls is occurring in Australia;

2. Concern that the likelihood of a woman facing discrimination on the grounds of sex if she returns to her country of origin is not considered to be sufficient reason for granting a woman refugee status.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners pray that the Senate in the Parliament assembled should, together with the House of Representatives:

PARA.TAB: 1. Classify genital mutilation as an illegal activity;

2. Follow the Canadian government's decision to allow potential `discrimination on the grounds of sex' to be sufficient reason for granting refugee status to women who would otherwise be returned to their country of origin;

3. Ensure that any such legislation is only one part of a broader strategy which includes community education about negative consequences of the mutilation practice, particularly peer education within the affected communities and education of the media in a non-sensationalist way.

PETITION.TITLE: Women: Pension Age
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned strongly opposes the increase in the pension age for women from 60 to 65 years.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate take action to reverse this decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Oyster Point
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned humbly request that the Senate honours the obligations of the Commonwealth of Australia to protect its territory that has received World Heritage status according to the World Heritage Convention of which Australia is a signatory.

Significant areas of marine and mangrove ecosystems of Australia's World Heritage Great Barrier Reef Marine Park are directly threatened with destruction by the adjacent construction of Australia's largest tourist resort and marina complex at Oyster Point near Cardwell North Queensland (opposite Hinchinbrook Island).

We implore the Senate to use its powers immediately to permanently halt the construction of the marina and access channel in the World Heritage "Buffer Zone" as recommended by the Valentine Report made to his Department in October 1994.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill 1994
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of Western Australia, draws attention of the Senate to the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill 1994 (Bill code: 94132.20) which is approaching its first reading.
We the undersigned have considered this issue in depth and consider that:

1. The current laws in Western Australia adequately protect the individual rights of its citizens in relation to sexual conduct between consenting adults in private, and keeping in mind, the obligation Government has to make laws which are for the good and safety of Society, to protect people from themselves, we do not believe the proposed bill to be in the best interests of the general public, and in particular the young and impressionable.

2. The current State's rights in relation to making and enacting laws should be maintained at all costs, as they have been decided for the people, by the people, in proper democratic fashion, therefore neither the United Nations, the Commonwealth Government, or any other outside influence should be permitted to over-ride the voice of the people. To transfer this right to a body outside of the boundaries for whom the laws were made has serious ramifications.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners request the Senate to allow the laws of the individual States to stand as they are.

Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, the government has announced that the sale of the Commonwealth's remaining 75 per cent equity in Qantas Airways Ltd will take place in the first half of 1995.

The Qantas Sale Act 1992, which established the legislative and administrative framework for the sale, received royal assent on 21 December 1992 and was subsequently amended in 1993 to extend the date of automatic repeal of any unproclaimed portions of the act until 30 June 1995.
Since then, there has been a number of developments which require the government's attention.

The Australian Stock Exchange's new electronic share transfer system, the Clearing House Electronic Subregister System (CHESS), became operational in September 1994. As a condition of listing on the Stock Exchange, Qantas will be required to be eligible to participate in CHESS.

The Sale Act imposes a limit of 35 per cent on the level of foreign ownership and currently provides that Qantas' articles of association must contain certain provisions enforcing that requirement. In particular, the act confers on directors the power to refuse to register a transfer of shares which could result in the foreign ownership limit being breached.

Because these powers are inconsistent with the CHESS rules which facilitate unrestricted electronic transfer and settlement in shares, it is proposed that the act no longer require the articles to impose restrictions on the transfer of shares to give effect to the foreign ownership limit. There are currently share disenfranchisement and divestment provisions in Qantas' articles which will continue to fulfil the legislative requirement that Qantas monitor and enforce the foreign ownership restrictions.

The Sale Act contains a number of provisions dealing with employee entitlements. Minor amendments will be made to the long service leave provisions to bring them into line with those in other asset sale legislation.

The Sale Act effectively imposes a deadline of 30 June 1995 for completion of the public share offer, as any provisions of the act which have not commenced by this date would lapse. The government has not yet settled on a date for the public share offer but wishes to leave open the option of conducting it after the conclusion of the May budget. In that event, the sale timetable will be very tight and it may prove difficult to complete all necessary administrative arrangements by 30 June. To ensure that the government has sufficient flexibility with regard to all its options, the bill provides that the legislative sunset clause be extended by two months to 31 August 1995.

The Air Navigation Act 1920 imposes controls over foreign shareholdings in Australian international airlines. Because Qantas is subject to its own controls under the Sale Act, it was not intended that the Air Navigation Act measures should also apply to Qantas. However, as the wording of the Air Navigation Act is ambiguous, it will be amended to confirm that this measure does not apply to Qantas.
Mr President, I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill and commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the final report of the Senate Community Affairs References Committee on the validation of care aggregated module (CAM) and standard aggregated module (SAM) funding of nursing homes, together with the Hansard record of proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: On 30 September 1993 the Senate referred the matter of the validation of care aggregated module and standard aggregated module funding of nursing homes to the committee. The committee tabled a preliminary report on 25 November 1993. In this report the committee decided to maintain a watching brief in relation to the reference and report to the Senate accordingly. The committee presented two further reports to the Senate—a short report on 24 March 1994 and a progress report on 30 June 1994.

PARA.TAB: The committee's final report tabled today concentrates on two main issues, namely, the process of validation and issues relating to the boundaries of CAM-SAM services. The committee notes that the Commonwealth Ombudsman and the Australian National Audit Office are also undertaking inquiries on validation and several studies have considered options for reform in the nursing home area in recent years. The committee understands that the audit office's report on aspects of validation will be released in December 1994.

During the committee's inquiry, concerns were expressed by nursing home industry organisations and a number of individual nursing homes at a number of features of the validation process, including the timeliness of validations, the consistency of decision making by validators and the impact of validations on the continued financial viability of nursing homes.

Of particular concern to many in the industry were the delays in the validation process, that is, the period of time between a cost being incurred and validation of that cost. The committee received considerable comment about the often long delays in validating 1986-87 data. The committee notes that the department did not finalise validation of this data until June 1994. Concerns were also raised over the effect that this delay had on the finances of many nursing homes. In respect of the validation of 1986-87 data, the committee concluded that the department performed very poorly.

The committee believes that these validations should have been completed by the department over a much shorter time frame than in fact occurred. The committee considers that the department should have recognised the need for additional resources to be devoted to the validation exercise and should have responded in a more timely manner. The department is now faced with the task of validating a large number of outstanding payments to nursing homes that must be completed within three years. The committee is concerned at the level of outstanding validations and the capacity of the department to fulfil the legislative requirement to complete validations of post-1 July 1993 benefits within three years. The committee has recommended that the Department of Human Services and Health provide a detailed schedule to the committee outlining its proposed program for completing these outstanding validations.

The committee also looked at the impact of negative loadings or recoveries by the department of any overpayments on the financial viability of nursing homes and concluded that, at least in the short term, these loadings may have some adverse impact on the financial viability of some homes. The evidence suggested that validation loadings are not solely responsible for nursing home bankruptcies, with other factors, including the financial management practices of some nursing home proprietors, playing a role in these bankruptcies.

The committee also addressed the need for reform in the overall funding arrangements for nursing homes. The committee concluded that the funding system could be substantially improved by moving the border between acquittable and non-acquittable funding from the current CAM-SAM boundary. The committee considers that the introduction of this system of funding would facilitate greater staff flexibility in nursing homes while still retaining proper standards of care for nursing home residents. The committee is of the view that more fundamental change to the current funding system is required than a mere `clarification' by the department of CAM-SAM boundary issues, and therefore considers that the government should introduce a system broadly based on option 2 of the Gregory report entitled Review of the Structure of Nursing Home Funding Arrangements: Stage 1. This proposal would involve a system of acquitting labour costs and providing a non-acquittable grant for non-labour costs.

The committee has also made a number of other important recommendations to improve the overall effectiveness of the validation program. The committee found that there had been cases of inconsistencies in decisions made by validation teams in different states. Where inconsistencies in decisions have been made, the committee believes that the department should take appropriate steps to address the problem, especially through its training program for validators. The committee also considers that validators should be required to have accountancy qualifications or other appropriate training.

In addition, the committee also concluded that consistency could be facilitated through better communication with the industry in relation to departmental policy. The committee recommended that the department should make available to the industry a document that would provide guidance to the industry on the validation process and that this document should form the basis for validations for the year in which it is issued. The committee also believes that the document should be widely disseminated throughout the industry.

The committee concluded that there should be better dissemination of information generally about the program by the department, to both proprietors and directors of nursing. The committee also believes that there needs to be improved consultation with the industry, especially in the formulation of departmental circulars, which are an important means of advising the industry of administrative or policy changes concerning the program. The committee, in particular, recommended that the department issue the NH20 form, which is required to be completed annually by nursing home proprietors and is the form by which proprietors account for their use of nursing and personal care funding, prior to the start of each financial year.

The committee believes that the recommendations that it has made will substantially improve the validation process and make the process more transparent and accountable. In particular, it considers that the reforms that it has proposed in the area of nursing home funding arrangements will address many of the concerns of the industry expressed during the inquiry while maintaining the high standards of care for nursing home residents. Finally, the committee wishes to thank those individuals and organisations who made submissions and gave evidence at public hearings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one of the committee members responsible for this report, I would like to draw to the attention of the house the fact that there is a dissenting report and that four of us disagreed specifically with the recommendation in relation to favouring Gregory option No. 2. Those of us who did so were concerned about the impact that option No. 2 potentially has on the standards of care in nursing homes. Before I get to that, on the issue of consistency and inconsistency it is important to note that in paragraph 3.5 of the report we say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Ombudsman advised the Committee that its investigations have not indicated `serious inconsistency' in the decisions made in different States. The Ombudsman noted that some inconsistencies may occur because there are differences in the nursing home industry in the various States.

I think, given the changes that have taken place in the legislation in the Victorian area in the last week or so, we are likely to see even greater differences within the industry between states. We looked at Gregory options Nos. 2 and 3 very seriously. It is worth noting what was said in the report. It states:

The Gregory report noted that under Option 2B there was a potential for some reduction in the standards of resident care. It was noted that, as in Option 2A, a proprietor would have the opportunity to divert funds provided for nursing and personal care staff to employ more administrative staff. Under this option, there is no financial incentive for efficiency in most areas where the proprietor has any control. The effect would be that the funding provided for care could be `effectively eroded', leading to reduced care, unless the Government provided additional funding.(152) The report also noted that because of this, more reliance would need to be placed on the standards monitoring system to ensure quality of care, that is, more intensive standards monitoring overall would be required.
That, of course, would require extra government expenditure. The report continues:

PARA.TAB: However, there are limitations to the extent to which standards monitoring can perform this function. The Gregory report noted that the standards monitoring program was designed in the expectation that nursing and personal care funding would be acquitted—`it was not designed to give emphasis to quality of nursing practice or adequacy of nursing coverage. It was designed to give most emphasis to the areas in which nursing homes were most deficient . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that if we blur the boundaries under CAM, the care aggregated module, which includes nursing care and personal care, and the boundaries under SAM, the standard aggregated module, which talks about the uniform amount that is required each day for a resident to meet the costs of food, electricity and building maintenance, we will make it more difficult for the monitoring of standards. We will require more in-depth standards monitoring. We will require more people to be involved in the process to see that this actually happens.

PARA.TAB: In the provision of aged care—care to the frail aged, disabled and the elderly—the most important thing, the paramount thing, is the standard of care. I for one could not be party to any recommendation that runs the risk of having an impact upon the standard of care in nursing homes. Those of us who have been around the industry for many years would remember what the standard of care in nursing homes was like 20 years ago. It was appalling. It left more than a lot to be desired. The treatment was not good. I would have to say that some in my profession of nursing did not fulfil their duties correctly. We have seen a magnificent change in that, and the standard is now very high. It is one about which we can be proud. But I am not prepared to be part of anything that runs the risk of reducing that standard of care.

I would also like to touch on the likely impacts on the nursing home industry of the Health Act (Amendment) Bill 1994, which was enacted last week in Victoria. This bill has effectively removed all safeguards which protect the quality of care of elderly residents in nursing homes. What the legislation is reported to be doing is removing the regulation that requires qualified nurses to be employed in nursing homes. It also, I understand, removes current statutory requirements including residents' rights to high quality health care, residents' rights to choose their own doctor, residents' rights to be treated with dignity and respect, and residents' rights to sufficient levels of nutrition, clothing and shelter. These are all issues relating to the standard of care that is given in nursing homes.

As I understand it, the legislation will allow any facility to advertise as a nursing home, remove the requirement for nursing homes to be registered in Victoria and remove the provision of confidentiality of residents' records. When we tie those changes to the relaxation of the CAM-SAM boundaries, the potential for the reduction in care that is provided to the residents I think is quite significant. To me, it is a reduction that is not tenable and not one that we should be accepting.

I recommend that people read very carefully the dissenting report that was signed by four members of the committee. We should be very careful to ensure that anything that is done in the area of nursing home care—the provision of care and assistance to the frail, elderly and disabled—does not at any stage reduce the standards of care to the people who are living in those institutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The background to this report from the Community Affairs References Committee is the difficulties faced by the nursing home industry in regard to the CAM-SAM boundary. The CAM—the care aggregated module—basically refers to nursing and therapy staff wages relating to nursing care and personal care; whilst SAM provides a non-acquittable uniform amount to meet things such as salaries of staff who are not involved directly in personal care, and other things such as electricity. There is also OCRE, which is not particularly relevant to the current report. That deals with cost reimbursement for superannuation and such like.

PARA.TAB: The problem has been that with the current system the non-acquittable SAM and the acquittable CAM systems mean that if SAM costs can be passed onto CAM there are more profits to the proprietor. Therefore, of course, there are boundaries between CAM and SAM at present which clearly need to be defined to make it possible for a nursing home operator to organise the staff appropriately. If the boundaries are going to be defined, they have to be defined in such a way that the people operating nursing homes can understand them; indeed, in such a way that they are actually communicating to the nursing home proprietors. It is clear that that was not done in a way which was satisfactory and appropriate to the industry.

If the boundaries were not clearly defined, how could people running nursing homes comply with boundaries that they could not see? There are a number of problems here, but I will come back to that point because it is of relevance to the issue that Senator West has just raised.

I will touch upon the question of timeliness because the validation for 1986-87 was not even started until 1990-91 and was not complete at the time this reference was made to the committee. The committee's conclusion that in this regard the department performed very poorly is entirely justified. There were no manuals to aid the nursing homes in terms of the validation procedure. Essentially, they had very little idea of how the validation procedures were going to work when they first started. They mainly gained their knowledge by word of mouth from other nursing home operators.

It is clear that a manual should be available to encourage and to allow people to meet the requirements of the validation process. This will simplify the validation process, and therefore make it less costly to the taxpayer. One of the committee's recommendations is that we should make sure that a manual is available—with confidential information removed, of course. On that basis, when the validation has been carried out the government can then apply negative loadings to nursing homes.

It is of interest that some 75 per cent of nursing homes validated had negative loadings applied to them. It is pretty difficult to accept that 75 per cent of nursing homes are crooked in some way. The only sensible conclusion to draw is that the bureaucracy involved, the lack of definition, the lack of clarification, and the lack of information and communication passed on to the nursing home proprietors were in large part responsible for the fact that 75 per cent of nursing homes did not meet the validation standards. The fact that they were not aware of the validation standards underpins the whole problem.

There were inconsistencies between states and between teams. It is not clear to the committee exactly how significant those inconsistencies were. Part of those inconsistencies could have been due to the different ways of operating nursing homes in different states and the different regulations involved. But it seemed that there were inconsistencies which could have been diminished, if not removed, by more appropriate training and by enrolling validators with better and higher qualifications. That is a recommendation of the committee.

The basis on which information is required by the department is a form called NH20. One would think that if one was going to ask the nursing home for information one would tell the nursing home in advance what information it should have. The department's manner in this regard was to say, `No, we will actually tell you what information we want to collect six months after the end of the year in which you are collecting it.' Clearly, by anybody's standards, that was unacceptable. A very strong recommendation of the committee was that the NH20 form should be available to nursing homes in advance of the year for which it was to be applied.

Because of the problem with validation, some nursing homes with negative loadings were sold to owners who were unable to ascertain whether in fact there was a negative loading involved. That problem has been dealt with in respect of nursing homes being sold now, but there was a period when there was no way in which the new purchaser of the nursing home could be aware of the problems facing that nursing home. That was clearly unacceptable. The ombudsman has suggested, and the committee agrees with the suggestion, that appropriate compensation should be considered, according to the merits of the individual cases in that situation.

Let me come to one of the main issues, which is this CAM-SAM boundary. The first thing we have to say is that the boundaries are artificial; they are not related to care, as such. For example, bed making is part of personal care, but food serving may or may not be part of personal care. There is a very rigid boundary between what may be CAM or what may be SAM, for example, in regard to food serving. In a particular nursing home, an individual might take the food from the kitchenette into the dining room. At this stage, that is a SAM duty. As soon as that person gets into the dining room, it becomes a CAM duty.

So the person doing that particular procedure has at some stage to turn around and say, `I am no longer SAM; I am now CAM.' That sort of nonsense is bad enough in a large nursing home, but for a small nursing home, where the staff are essentially multiskilled, it makes a nonsense and a mockery of the whole situation. It is not possible to define those sorts of procedures adequately and in a way which is sensible and which does not involve the proprietors in undue and inappropriate bureaucracy.

The recommendation of the committee, therefore, is that we adopt in broad terms the recommendation from the government's own report—the Gregory report—option two. Option two essentially abolishes the CAM-SAM boundary, saying that, directly or indirectly, most of the work done in the nursing home, except for some essential administration tasks, is related to the care of the patient. Gregory option two recommends that the labour costs be acquitted in general and some minor exceptions made to that, and other expenses are left in a separate category.

The question is: does this affect care? That is something which Senator West and I share a view on. We would not support any changes which in any way threaten to reduce the quality of care offered to residents in nursing homes. We believe there is no reason whatsoever why there should be any reduction in care. The most important maintainer of care in nursing homes is the standard monitoring teams assessments. The standard monitoring teams assess a number of criteria and make a report on those issues. It is a very effective way of maintaining standards in nursing homes, which, Senator West quite rightly points out, have improved enormously over the 20 years. To suggest that we would be going back 20 years, as Senator West implied, by making a change to CAM-SAM is a nonsense. It is not relevant. Nobody is suggesting going back to the old-fashioned system that we had 20 years ago.

What we are saying, however, is that simply by removing an artificial boundary as to what may or may not be personal care—a boundary determined by bureaucrats and not really relevant to the actual care given to the patients—we will make sure that the bureaucracy is removed and there are enormous savings in validations. It was mentioned by Senator West that there would be extra costs in expanding standard monitoring teams, but she forgot to mention that there will be significant savings by reducing the size and the work of the validation teams.

In this way, we can introduce flexibility into nursing homes. This is vital for proprietors to be able to organise their staff appropriately, according to the individual work place and according to whether the nursing home is large or small, or has particular issues in regard to the types of residents it has. It is absolutely crucial that we allow this to proceed. We believe this will enhance the level of care offered; it will enhance the efficiency of the nursing homes; it will reduce the bureaucracy which they have to face; and in the end it will improve the standard of care given to residents in those nursing homes, which is of vital importance to us.

We believe that the Gregory report got it right in this regard. I might mention in passing that there is a strong body of view that the Gregory report also got some other things right—such as ensuring that there is an appropriate remuneration on a per capita basis. I certainly hope that the government will follow the recommendations of the Gregory report and introduce the increase in funding which that report recommended as a way of ensuring that the quality of care, which is already excellent, is maintained over the next few years.

TALK.START.PARA: I do not want to add much more to what my colleagues Senator Herron and Senator Woods have said, but I do want to say that it was, I think, on 28 September last year that I moved a motion, with the support of the Democrats, to instigate this inquiry. I believe it has opened up some of the issues that were facing nursing homes—and, in many cases, are still facing nursing homes—in the validation of their funding for CAM and SAM aspects of funding to nursing homes.

PARA.TAB: I regret that it was not a majority report, that we did have a dissenting report on one issue. In the main, as I closely watched that committee because I was not on it—although I moved the motion, I was not on the committee until the very end—I believe that it was a very cooperative committee which came up with a lot of reasonable and appropriate recommendations in its report. I would ask the government and the department to look very closely at it to ensure that, as far as possible, those recommendations are followed because, really, the main game and the main aim is to ensure that frail, older people in Australia are cared for to the best of our corporate ability—that is, the ability of the government, the coalition, this parliament, the department and those people working in the field.

It is very complex to ensure that the funding is used appropriately and not misappropriated. We all understand that, and none of us would condone any nursing home or nursing home proprietor who misappropriates taxpayers' money which is legitimately directed towards the care of the frail and elderly in our community. However, we have to ensure that bureaucratic regulations, the shifting of goal posts and the untimeliness of carrying out validations does not interfere with the care of those older people. That is the balance we have to achieve to ensure that that money is spent appropriately and that accountability for that money does not mean that we impinge on or take away from the care of older people.

Constantly, as one moves around nursing homes, one hears—and I visit nursing homes with great frequency, two and three in a non-sitting week—the concern of proprietors about the time that is taken away from caring for their residents and the time that they have to give to filling out papers to comply with rules, regulations, inspections and whatever else might go on.

We know that many things are necessary to ensure accountability but we have to make sure that the balance is right. Some of the demands that are made on nursing homes are much more stringent than those made by the Australian Taxation Office in assessing whether we, as a community, have claims that are tax deductible. This is actually the same thing—the tax office is trying to appropriately assess tax deductible items. In the same way, the department is trying to ensure that nursing homes spend money on the things on which they say they have spent it, whether it be nursing care, kitchen staff or cleaning staff—and that balance has to be achieved.But, as I said, it must be achieved in a way that ensures that we focus on allowing most of the time of the staff to be given to residents rather than to meeting bureaucratic procedures.

I commend the report to the Senate, to the department and to the government. I also wish to place on record our appreciation as a committee, as I have just recently joined that committee, of the staff of the Senate Community Affairs References Committee. The staff have had a large amount of work to do and a number of in-depth reports to prepare. It never ceases to amaze me how the staff can get on top of an issue, know it in great detail and understand it. I commend them for their work and congratulate them on the assistance they have given the committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the 11th report of 1994 relating to the development of 2nd Field Hospital at Enoggera, Queensland, and the 12th report of 1994 relating to the housing development, Bligh Park, New South Wales. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: The first report which I have tabled involves recommendation for the development of the 2nd Field Hospital at Enoggera, Queensland at an estimated cost of $29.2 million. This hospital will replace present inadequate facilities at 1st Military Hospital at Yeronga, 2nd Field Hospital at Kelvin Grove and the Enoggera Medical Centre. When inspecting the current facilities the committee was impressed by the dedication of the staff at Yeronga and Kelvin Grove. These personnel are presently working in old timber, metal and asbestos-clad buildings which provide inadequate working conditions and lead to operational inefficiencies.

PARA.TAB: A need therefore exists to replace these substandard facilities with a modern hospital capable of providing medical and dental services for personnel of the Australian Defence Force. This will be achieved by building a modern purpose-built hospital at Enoggera. The new facilities will include accommodation for an operational army hospital with a 50-bed capacity. The proposal will also include the provision of logistic, administrative, training and living-in accommodation. The proposed hospital will be in close proximity to the units which it will support, as well as being in a location convenient for visiting civilian medical specialists.

The second report which I have tabled recommends construction of a housing development at Bligh Park, New South Wales, for defence personnel at an estimated cost of $8.5m. Some 450 service families are presently living in substandard accommodation in the Richmond-Windsor area—the majority being at Hobartville. The Defence Housing Authority proposes to provide suitable accommodation for some of these families by acquiring between 50 and 65 housing lots in a new stage of a residential subdivision—Precinct 29 at Bligh Park, New South Wales.

The Bligh Park Estate will eventually comprise about 2,225 dwellings. The Defence Housing Authority currently has 92 properties on the estate for service families. DHA intends to acquire these additional residential allotments and construct houses on them in a planned extension to the estate. The site is well located for housing for service families because of its proximity to RAAF Base Richmond and existing and proposed schools, shopping and recreational facilities which have been established over the past 10 years. The proposal will provide defence personnel and their families with good quality housing and services consistent with community standards. I commend the reports to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I present the final report of an inquiry into the conduct of the 1993 federal election and matters related thereto, together with extracts of minutes and the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the third report which the committee has presented during this parliament. Honourable senators will recall that in June 1994 I presented a report on women's representation in parliament, and an interim report entitled Financial reporting by political parties concerning election funding and disclosure. The government has acted on our recommendations and has introduced legislation which is currently before the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: The committee has now reported on each election conducted by the Australian Electoral Commission since the AEC's establishment in 1984. This process has proved to be an effective means of informing the government and the AEC of the perceived need for legislative or administrative change to the electoral system based on the evidence of electors, parliamentarians, political parties and informed observers of the political scene.

Accordingly, this report records the findings of the committee on the criticisms and proposals for change that have been submitted to the inquiry based on the experience of the 1993 federal election. The report recommends refinements to many areas of the electoral system. Most of these proposals have the support of the whole committee. However, there are differences of opinion on some matters of policy. In these cases members have elected to exercise their right to add dissent to the report.

The committee is able to make a positive report on the operation of the electoral system and its administration by the AEC. The AEC provided an improved level of service at the 1993 election at a lower cost in real terms to that in 1990. The use of revised polling place strategies and the adoption for the House of Representatives scrutiny of the two candidate preferred count virtually eliminated problems experienced at the 1990 election with queuing at polling places and slow results.

The result of the House of Representatives election was predicted at a very early stage on election night. In our report, we have recommended further improvements to the conduct of the two candidate preferred count. For the Senate scrutiny, we have recommended that the Commonwealth Electoral Act be amended to allow known preferences on the group voting tickets to be taken into consideration. This should speed up the final determination of Senate results considerably.

A contentious issue examined during the inquiry was the potential for electoral fraud. Having examined the evidence, a majority of the committee agrees with the AEC that fraud was not a significant occurrence during the last election and did not influence any result. Therefore, we do not consider that changes to procedures intended to reduce the opportunity for fraud—such as requiring proof of identity and closing electoral rolls as soon as an election is called—are required. We believe that electoral integrity requires that electors be given every opportunity to exercise their franchise, and we support absolutely the AEC's policy of encouraging maximum possible participation.

The committee, however, agreed that the integrity of the electoral rolls is of central importance to the functioning and acceptability of the electoral outcome. We would like to see a move away from the present arrangements which rely on a blitz on enrolments through habitation review just prior to an election. A better system would be one based on continuous roll review.

Many of the committee's recommendations are designed to increase participation by electors in rural and remote communities, including Aboriginal communities. For example, we recommend improvements to the process for removing names from the electoral rolls following objection action, and we recommend that interstate absent voting be allowed in electoral divisions bordering state boundaries. Also, some postal voters in remote areas are regularly disenfranchised because infrequent mail delivery means they cannot return their ballot papers in the time allowed by postal voting. We, therefore, recommend that general postal voters living more than 100 kilometres from a polling booth be allowed to receive ballot papers as soon as the election is called without having to first fill in and return a postal vote application form.

The committee acknowledges the importance of electoral education. We recommend a public education campaign to improve electors' understanding of how preferential voting works. Submissions were made to the committee recommending the insertion of so-called `truth in advertising' provisions in the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Government members of the committee continue to believe that such legislation would be unenforceable and ineffective.

Also, the committee rejects calls for the use of how-to-vote cards to be banned. However, we have recommended that the AEC investigate means of displaying how-to-vote information inside polling booths, as is done for some state elections. The committee has recommended that the minimum election period be reduced from 33 to 28 days, a reform that will undoubtedly be welcomed by the public and will potentially lead to a reduction in the overall cost of elections.

Lastly, the committee recommends that prisoners under sentence for an offence punishable by five years or more imprisonment no longer be deprived of the vote. A majority of the committee believes that this reform, if enacted, will serve the aim of rehabilitating prisoners by encouraging them to observe one of their most important civil obligations.

I thank my fellow committee members for their support during the inquiry. I believe our endeavours will result in a system for the next federal election even more efficient and inclusive than that used so successfully in 1993. I thank the committee secretary, Mr Donald Nairn; the research officer, Mr Russel Chafer; the administrative assistant, Mrs Helen Fyfe; and other staff who served the committee during the course of the inquiry.

Finally, I would like to thank all those people who made submissions to the inquiry and appeared as witnesses, in particular, the officers of the Australian Electoral Commission. We particularly thank Mr Brian Cox, who has recently announced his retirement, for his distinguished service as the Commonwealth's most senior electoral officer and for the support he has given to the committee during his period in office. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I want to make a few remarks on this report, and I begin by joining the Chair of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, Senator Foreman, in thanking the staff of the committee for their extraordinary work and also the Australian Electoral Commission for its cooperation with the committee on this very long review. After all, we are talking about a review of an election held 20 months ago.

PARA.TAB: The coalition members of this committee agreed with the government on many of the issues identified in the report. The report proposes many sensible changes which we hope the government will accept. However, the coalition members have prepared a minority report for presentation to the parliament because we believe that, on several critical issues, the Labor Party and the Labor members of the committee have turned a blind eye to many of the problems in the electoral system that are evident to us and which this government is choosing to ignore.

We are most concerned about the integrity of the electoral system. The fact that more submissions were received on this issue than any other and have aroused a lot of controversy and problems in the hearings makes it clear that there is a growing lack of confidence in the Australian electorate with the integrity of the electoral system. Our argument is that the electoral system is wide open to abuse and potential fraud. It is not a question of whether the system is being abused but whether it is open to abuse.

The government argues that there is no real evidence of abuse. One of the problems is that it is so open that it is extremely difficult to prove whether it is being abused. Our argument is that the Electoral Commission is incapable of satisfying us that it is not being abused.

We are extremely concerned over how easy it is to enrol. All that is required of people is that they roll up with a card signed by another elector and they are on the roll. It is also extremely easy to vote—so easy that, if people wish to do so by fraudulent means, there is virtually nothing in the system to prevent them from doing so.

There is clearly a problem with multiple voting. According to the commission's figures, there were 6,000 cases of multiple voting completely unaccounted for and unexplained. Since the government won the last federal election only by about 12,000 or 13,000 votes, 6,000 cases of multiple voting is an extremely serious matter.

There are also problems in relation to people voting in false names—there is no way of telling whether that is going on—and with people being able to enrol when they are not eligible to enrol. No-one can prove that that is not occurring either. The government members are simply not prepared to do anything about this system, presumably because they believe that having a system wide open to abuse suits their electoral purposes.

In their minority report, the coalition members have proposed a number of measures to counter problems in a system that, we believe, is losing respect within the Australian electorate and is open to abuse. We have called for a system requiring proof of identity for enrolment. To most Australians it is unbelievable that there is no system of requiring proof of identity for enrolment. People have to prove who they are for almost everything else in society, so for one of the most important things—the right to vote—people should have to prove who they are for everybody else to have confidence in the system.

We believe that the Electoral Commission should be asked to trial a system of voter cards—that is, when people go to vote they have to hand over a voter card. That has been trialled in the state of Victoria and, according to reports we have received, works extremely well. It is used in many other jurisdictions and should at least be trialled in Australia for potential implementation.

At least the government has made one concession—and we agree with it—that there should be continuous roll reviews. These one-off, haphazard, ad hoc roll reviews done in the run-up to elections are simply not good enough. They should be continuous. We are pleased to see that the government members have proposed that.

We also believe that to minimise the extent to which there may be multiple voting, subdivisional voting should be reintroduced. It is quite extraordinary that people can vote at any booth in an electorate on election day. We think that subdivisional voting should be reintroduced.

The most significant proposal, in my view, made by the coalition members is the proposal in this report, in the context of the integrity of the electoral system, to abolish compulsory voting. As the Senate knows, I am something of an advocate of non-compulsory voting for a whole range of reasons, both philosophical and practical. But it was readily apparent to the coalition members of this committee that our system of compulsory voting is one of the most significant contributors to the maintenance of an electoral system wide open to abuse.

The government members and the Electoral Commission both argue that, because we force citizens to enrol and vote, we must make it as easy as possible for them to enrol and to ultimately vote. The two are intrinsically linked. There is an umbilical cord between compulsory voting and the system which, in our view, is wide open to abuse and which has lost the confidence of the Australian people. For that reason alone, compulsory voting should be ended. It should also be ended for all the other reasons which I have long expounded on. It is undemocratic, it should end, and I am delighted that my coalition colleagues on this committee have joined me in calling for an end to compulsory voting.

The minority report of the coalition members also strongly opposes the government members' recommendation that all prisoners be allowed to vote. I think the government members might rue the day that they ever proposed something like this. I think the government, in its wisdom, will reject this proposition that all prisoners should now be able to retain the right to vote. That will be offensive to the great majority of Australians, who believe that, if people commit an offence, they should be denied certain basic freedoms. One of those is the right to vote.

The current law provides that, if someone has been convicted of an offence punishable by a term of five years imprisonment, he or she is denied the right to vote. We understand there are difficulties with that, and perhaps the law should just provide that, if a person has been sentenced to a term of, let us say, three, four or five years, that person is denied the right to vote. But to solve the problem by tossing out the baby with the bath water, as the government members suggest, is absolutely ridiculous and, I think, offensive to most Australians, who believe that law and order is a major problem and to make this great concession to prisoners to give them back a right to vote is completely wrong. I urge the government to reject that recommendation.

We also oppose the quite blatantly cynical proposition by the government members that the length of an election campaign should be reduced from 33 days to 28 days. The Electoral Commission itself has great reservations about that proposition. It is clearly designed to suit an incumbent government. That is why the government has proposed it. It is simply not practical to have a federal election campaign run from start to finish in 28 days. Thirty-three days causes great difficulties for parties and the Electoral Commission. Twenty-eight days would be quite untenable, and again we urge the government to reject it.

The coalition members have also called for prohibition of misleading and untrue advertising. We believe that the provision on this that was in the act in 1984 should be reinstituted. We are brought to that conclusion by the campaign which the ALP conducted in 1993, when it broke all the conventions in relation to political advertising and used its trade union resources to run election advertisements which blatantly lied about coalition policy. We have a provision like this in the South Australian electoral act. It works; it works well. It does restrict the extent to which blatantly untrue political advertising occurs. It is unbelievable that a government which actually tried to ban political advertising now will have no part of regulating the extent to which untrue advertising is put to air. I am glad the Democrats have joined with us in calling for a prohibition of misleading and untrue advertising.

We have also, in the spirit of free speech, called for repeal of the provision in the act which makes it an offence to advocate informal voting. This government's record in relation to free speech is abominable, as we have seen in the racial vilification bill, and the existence of this particular provision, which means that people commit an offence if they say to someone that they should vote informally, is quite offensive and should go.

So there are a number of areas where the coalition members disagree with the government members on this committee. We believe that the electoral system is in question and the integrity of it must be ensured by a number of the measures that we have put forward. In conclusion, I commend the minority report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: SOCIAL SECURITY (PARENTING ALLOWANCE AND OTHER MEASURES)

This Bill continues the major reform of Australia's income support system for unemployed people arising from the Government's White Paper, Working Nation. The measures provide increased incentives under the income test for unemployed people to take up low paid work. They also include the introduction of parenting allowance. The Bill also continues the strategy of phasing out payments based on a dependent relationship between people in the social security system, with individuals needing to establish a personal entitlement to a social security payment.

From 1 July 1995 there will be an important new non-activity tested, independent payment for families. This new payment, to be known as parenting allowance, will be available to the partners of income support recipients who have dependent children under 16. It will also be available to the partners of low income earners, and to partners who have low personal income, who have dependent children under 16. It will incorporate, and go beyond, the home child care allowance currently being paid to Australian families. It will, however, preserve the major elements of the home child care allowance.

The maximum rate of parenting allowance will be the same as the rate paid to each member of a pensioner or allowance couple (currently $268.20 a fortnight). Generally, parenting allowance will be income and assets tested. Income of both members of a couple will be taken into account. However, as home child care allowance will be merged into parenting allowance, an amount of parenting allowance of up to $61 a fortnight (a basic parenting allowance component) will be available regardless of income received by the recipient's partner. The amount of up to $61 represents an estimated maximum rate of the home child care allowance that will apply from 1 January 1995. This amount may be reduced only by personal income of a parenting allowance recipient.

Both the maximum parenting allowance rate ($268.20 a fortnight) and the maximum rate of basic component ($61 a fortnight) will be indexed twice a year in March and September. Although parenting allowance will generally be taxable, any amount paid up to $61 a fortnight will be free of tax. Generally, only people receiving parenting allowance at a higher rate than the $61 basic parenting allowance component will automatically be entitled to additional family payment and health care card concessions.

Parenting allowance has been carefully designed to improve full-time work incentives for unemployed couples with children. It will also make sure that low income couples with children will continue to be financially better off with one partner in full-time work rather than both being on income support. A further feature of the new allowance is that low income families will have a greater degree of choice about whether one partner will stay at home and care for their children, a choice generally available up to now only to those on higher incomes. At the same time, the entitlement of most higher income families to the basic parenting allowance component that was formerly home child care allowance will be maintained.

Around 260,000 families will receive more than $61 a fortnight. Overall, some 117,000 families are expected to gain around $59 a week from parenting allowance. Announced and introduced into Parliament in the International Year of the Family, the parenting allowance initiative will give the partner caring for the children an independent source of income, recognising financially the valuable work of the carer.

This Bill makes strategic changes to the income test for unemployed people to make sure that they will always be financially better of by increasing their work earnings. Under the current arrangements, every dollar of income earned above a modest amount causes the loss of a dollar of income support. This seriously diminishes the incentives for people to increase their earnings since they will generally be no better off overall unless the increase in their income is so substantial that they have no further need for income support.

From 1 July 1995, all unemployed people will be able to earn $60 a fortnight before losing any income support. They will lose 50 cents for each dollar of extra income between $60 and $140 a fortnight and 70 cents for each dollar beyond that point. The new rule will apply to single unemployed persons and to couples unless one member of the couple is a pensioner. The new rule will generally replace the joint income test that has tended to discourage both partners from seeking work. The income of one member of a couple will start to affect the other partner's allowance only when the first partner loses entitlement to a social security benefit altogether. Based on current rates, the first partner will be able to earn $466 a fortnight before the other partner's payment will start to reduce. The reduction will then be 70 cents for each dollar of earnings. The existing joint income rules will continue to apply where one member of a couple is a pensioner.

This Bill continues the elimination of social security payments based on dependence on another person that started with the withdrawal of the partner add-on rate component earlier this year. Payments are being redirected to individuals based on need in their own right. It also recognises the desirability for equity between social security clients, some of whom have to undertake activity testing to qualify for income support and some of whom do not.

Wife pension is currently available to a woman whose partner is receiving either age or disability support pension, disability wage supplement or rehabilitation allowance in certain circumstances. Mature age partner allowance is available to the partner of a mature age allowance recipient. Special needs wife pension is paid to a woman whose partner is receiving either special needs age or special needs disability support pension. All three payments are available without activity testing. There will be no new grants of any of these payments on or after 1 July 1995. However, people who claim and qualify for one of the payments on or before 30 June 1995 will have their entitlement "saved".

Most people affected by this proposal will qualify for another form of income support. Those with dependent children under 16 may claim the new parenting allowance. The full range of principal income support payments such as job search allowance or the various pensions will be available. Carer pension may be paid to those caring for an aged or disabled person. Partners aged 40 or more without recent labour force experience may claim the non-activity tested partner allowance.

Partner allowance itself is being refined in line with other changes made by this Bill. People currently on partner allowance who have dependent children under 16 are expected to move to the new parenting allowance. Partner allowance will continue to be available to the partners of recipients of job search, newstart or sickness allowance or special benefit; it will also become available to the partners of recipients of age or disability support pension, rehabilitation or mature age allowance or disability wage supplement. However, it will be restricted to partners who are aged 40 or more with no recent workforce experience and no dependent children under 16. Current clients who do not fall into this category will need to claim income support in their own right, with most expected to move to job search allowance. If the client has been registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) for the 12 months prior to 1 July 1995, newstart allowance will be available. Clients at risk of long term unemployment will be taken to have the same history of CES registration as their job search or newstart allowance partners so that they will have access to the same programs and job compacts as their partners.

The Bill also provides that a parenting allowance and a partner allowance will generally remain payable to a qualified person even if the person's partner is subject to a non-payment period and even if the partner's payment ceases, subject to meeting the income and assets tests. In a further amendment, parenting and partner allowance recipients will be entitled to health care cards in their own right.

A new widow allowance is being introduced by this Bill. Since July 1987, there have been no new grants of widow B pension to women under age 50 at that date or to those under age 45 if they had previously been sole parent pensioners. This has been part of a strategy to remove from the social security program gender specific and non-activity tested payments for people of workforce age. Many women who would have qualified for widow B pension previously have moved onto other payments such as job search allowance and have had to undertake the usual job search activities to be able to get income support.

However, many of these women grew up in an era when it was not expected that they would ever work outside the home after marriage and have no recent workforce experience with which to confront the harsh realities of the job market. The new widow allowance is being introduced to ease the transition between the current provisions and the eventual phase out of the types of payment mentioned.

From 1 January 1995, widow allowance will be available to women who are widowed, divorced or separated, who become so after turning 50 and who have no recent workforce experience. The new allowance will be paid at the same rate and under the same income and assets tests as job search and newstart allowances but it will not be activity tested. Widow allowance will carry an entitlement to a health care card. Women receiving another payment immediately before 1 January 1995 may transfer to widow allowance without having to satisfy the recent workforce experience requirement. Women who have turned 60 and who have been beneficiaries for 12 months or more will be entitled to a pensioner concession card. There will be no new grants of widow allowance on or after 1 July 2005, except to women born before 1 July 1955. To avoid confusion, the current widowed person allowance will now be called bereavement allowance but will not otherwise be changed. The other measures in this Bill relate to advance pharmaceutical allowance and education entry payment. Advance pharmaceutical allowance was introduced in 1990, originally to operate until the end of 1991. The success of the scheme has resulted in its extension year by year. It is now to be extended indefinitely by the removal by this Bill of the "sunset" clause.

Education entry payment is currently available to recipients of certain social security payments to ease the costs associated with taking up study which may in turn improve the person's chances of finding work. The $200 payment is now being extended to recipients of partner allowance, wife pension and mature age partner allowance and to recipients of the new parenting and widow allowances.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
SUPPORTED ACCOMMODATION ASSISTANCE BILL 1994
and
SUPPORTED ACCOMMODATION ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1994
Mr President, Senators, in the first of these bills, we have before us today a very important piece of legislation—the Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill.
The bill is important because it addresses a key objective of this Government's Social Justice Strategy and one of the most challenging issues in Australian social policy today—homelessness.

The bill signals a major step forward in the way we respond to homelessness in Australia and will set a new benchmark in the provision of services to help homeless men, women and young people overcome the cycle of disadvantage.
This is not the first time a Labor Government has acted to revolutionise assistance to homeless people.

The bill before us today is very much a legacy of the reforms that were begun by the Labor Government in 1974 with the passage of the Homeless Persons Assistance Act. This was the first piece of Commonwealth legislation which provided government assistance through community-based organisations to homeless people.

Homelessness did not suddenly emerge in the 1970s—the first female immigrant's home was established in Sydney by Caroline Chisholm in 1841 and the Sydney City Mission began operating refuges for the homeless in 1861.

What was important about the Homeless Persons Assistance Act was that it was the first time that the Federal Government had recognised that it was the responsibility of national Government to provide assistance to homeless people.
The other important aspect of the legislation was that it dealt with homelessness as an issue of social policy.

In the two decades following that ground breaking piece of legislation, Federal Labor Governments have shown leadership by playing a central and active role in responding to homelessness in Australia as a key objective of the national social policy agenda.

In 1985, the Federal Labor Government created the first Supported Accommodation Assistance Program (SAAP) by amalgamating the Homeless Persons Assistance Program, the Women's Emergency Services Program and the Youth Services Program.

SAAP agreements were signed with all States and Territories. In 1989, a second round of agreements were signed with the States and Territories. Under these agreements SAAP grew to some 1600 services, consolidating a network of social infrastructure in regions across Australia which provided accommodation and support for homeless men, women and young people.
It is due to the contribution made by these services in this decade that Australian cities and towns do not present the same scenes of street living and begging as New York and London.
In 1994, we have the opportunity to take the reform process in Australia one step further.

The legislation before Parliament today lays a new foundation for the third round of supported accommodation agreements to be signed between the Federal Government and State and Territory Governments by 1 January 1995.
The Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill sets a new framework for the provision of SAAP services. The focus is on assisting homeless people to achieve the maximum possible degree of independence.

The bill seeks to move SAAP from a program of last resort—a `safety net' for people who are homeless—to one which is active in helping them to change their lives. It seeks to change SAAP from a program which provides care to a program which provides care and opportunities.
In the past, we have not been active enough in taking this approach. We have allowed homeless people to remain marginalised.

Services have been built in the industrial parts of town—beside factories rather than in communities. We have paid great attention to providing beds for the night often at the expense of other services including labour market assistance, health and rehabilitation, childcare and long-term housing solutions.

The community has often accepted a lower standard of service for homeless people. This has perpetuated the myth that homelessness is threatening to the community—the images of sub-standard accommodation and associated violence and crime creating a stigma.
The result has been that people who become homeless are vulnerable to entering a cycle of dependence that becomes a lifestyle—and very difficult to break out of.
SAAP clients are among the most marginalised and powerless members of our community.

PARA.TAB: On any given night up to 11,500 people are assisted by SAAP.
7500 of them are adults and 4000 are accompanying children.
Of these 7500, 56 per cent are male and 44 per cent female.
The majority of women (52 per cent) are aged between 20 and 40 years of age.
Men tend to be older—10 per cent of men in SAAP are aged over 60, compared to 3 per cent of women.

SPEECH.PARA: Another important statistic is that indigenous Australians account for 15 per cent of SAAP clients. They account for 1.6 per cent of the Australian population.

SAAP is generally divided into four sectors. Youth accommodation accounts for 29 per cent of services; services for single men 26 per cent; services for women escaping domestic violence 12 per cent and services for families 12 per cent. People with children using SAAP account for 25 per cent of all clients.
People using SAAP are poor—87 per cent are reliant on Commonwealth Government benefits and a further 5 per cent have no income at all.
As this data illustrates, people who are homeless are extremely disadvantaged in Australian society and this bill establishes SAAP's place as central to achieving positive outcomes for them.

It is based upon the principle that all Australians, regardless of their economic, social or housing status, have basic rights and responsibilities and that people who are homeless have the same entitlement to these rights and responsibilities as any other group in our society.

This Labor Government is concerned with building an Australia which is fair, which offers all its citizens opportunities to prosper, to enjoy fulfilling lives, to participate in their communities—in short, to exercise the rights of citizens and to fulfil the responsibilities which go with those rights.

We have acted to protect the rights of all Australians by recognising international standards for the protection of universal human rights and fundamental freedoms. The Government has ratified human rights treaties in relation to civil, political, economic, social and cultural rights.

PARA.TAB: In relation to eliminating racial discrimination and discrimination against women.
In relation to the rights of the child.
And we have enacted legislation which outlaws discrimination of the basis of gender and disability.

SPEECH.PARA: All of these initiatives are designed to build social cohesion in Australia and a society which offers equal opportunities to all citizens.
The Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill recognises that we will not make advances in the area of homelessness without a recognition of the rights of homeless people.

Access to a home is one of the most fundamental requisites for securing a decent quality of life. The bill seeks to make the rights of people who are homeless to housing and to the other essential elements of a decent quality of life central to the services provided for them and to the opportunities they are offered.

It outlines the principles that underpin the provision of services to homeless people—respect for human dignity, respect for cultural background and beliefs and protection of universal human rights. These rights are to be advanced in conjunction with the responsibilities expected of clients while using SAAP services.

The bill also recognises the importance of housing to quality of life in the definition of `homeless' which is provided. This is the first time such a comprehensive definition has been included in Commonwealth legislation.

Previous definitions have constrained `homeless' to traditional interpretations of total absence of shelter—literally living on the streets, sleeping in parks, derelict buildings or railway stations for want of anywhere else to go.
The definition of `homeless' in this bill recognises homelessness as being more complex than the absolute absence of shelter.
The definition provides that a person is homeless if he or she has inadequate access to safe and secure shelter.
The definition of inadequate access to safe and secure shelter encompasses health and safety issues, the physical environment and the economic and social supports a home would normally offer.

An example of a situation which this definition intends to cover is the case of a woman and her children being subjected to continued violence in the family home. Because the woman's health is at risk, the home is rendered unsafe and the woman would be considered to have `inadequate access to safe and secure shelter' and to be at imminent risk of homelessness.

This bill recognises that SAAP does not operate in isolation. It takes account of the factors which lead to crisis, both economic and social, and which influence the outcomes of our attempts to redress crisis and assist people who are homeless to regain independence.

These influences are complex and varied and extend beyond access to housing, that is to thinking a person's crisis is solved through merely providing a roof over their head. The issues relate to health, to employment, to security of income, to the person's capacity to build and maintain personal relationships, to violence and to the legal system.

The bill sets objectives for SAAP which link the provision of shelter with all of these other services. It provides for a system in which case managers work with individuals to put together a package of assistance to suit their needs.

It may be that an older single man who has been homeless for some time and who is eligible for the Job Compact is provided with labour market assistance at the same time as SAAP provides his accommodation.

A woman escaping domestic violence will be provided with accommodation for herself and for her children and at the same time provided with childcare and related support so that she can start to look for employment.
A homeless family will be provided with counselling at the same time as the SAAP case manager organises rent assistance and social security to find the family a suitable house for private rental.

The bill asserts the right of homeless people to the full range of government services and community resources and to participate fully in their communities—the same universal human rights other members of the community take for granted.
It provides the framework and impetus for more innovative and integrated responses to the issues which face homeless people.
It is about maximising people's chances to participate.
The Government provided an additional $19 million in the last Federal Budget to deliver this new approach.
The community will be closely involved with the implementation of this new approach.

As part of the reform process, a Commonwealth Advisory Committee on Homelessness will be established. It will provide people who are homeless and the wider community with the opportunity to be directly involved in the new SAAP program.
This Committee overcomes the current fragmented approach to community participation in SAAP. It will provide national leadership in both advocacy and policy development for people who are homeless.

But if people who are homeless are to take their rightful place in the community we must increase understanding in the community of homelessness. The Department of Housing and Regional Development will be undertaking a targeted public awareness campaign during the 1995 United Nations International Year of Tolerance.

The major messages of this initiative will be that homelessness is not the result of individual failing, but the effect of a complex range of social and economic influences and that homelessness is not a permanent condition. With the right support and assistance, most people who are homeless can regain independence.
This campaign will also bring to the public's notice the detrimental effects of attitudes which exclude homeless people from communities.
SAAP is to continue at least until 30 June 1999, with the Commonwealth and the States and Territories maintaining their relative contributions over this time.
In 1994-95, we are contributing $104.9 million towards SAAP, while the States' combined contribution is $80 million.

This Government has approved additional funds to foster the reforms to SAAP I have outlined above. In 1994-95, $3.9 million in additional Commonwealth funding is committed for this purpose, rising to $4.5 million in 1995-96 through to 1997-98.

The bill also includes provisions to ensure that members of the Commonwealth Advisory Committee on Homelessness receive adequate remuneration for their expertise and for their time and efforts in participating on such a committee.
Remuneration costs for committee members together with running costs for the operation of the committee are not anticipated to exceed $60,000 per annum.

The second bill, the Supported Accommodation Assistance Amendment Bill, amends the Supported Accommodation Assistance Act 1989 to prevent the Commonwealth entering into an agreement, or authorising payments, under that Act after the date on which the first State or Territory enters into an agreement under the new Supported Accommodation Assistance Act 1994.
The quality of services that the community provides to people who are homeless is a test of our collective commitment to social justice.
Combating homelessness is a national policy goal.
It requires a strong national effort to achieve results, leadership by the Federal Government and the collective commitment of the States and Territories and the community.
The Federal Government will provide the leadership required to make this a truly national step forward—with each State and Territory with us.

With this bill, this Government has taken the opportunity to move SAAP forward to become not only a responsive and suitable service to meet the immediate needs of people who are homeless, but for many of them, the point in their lives when they were offered the opportunity to move forward towards greater independence and control over their own lives.
I commend these bills to honourable senators.
