TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment 20 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister must cause a copy of the national indigenous land strategy or any changes made to the national indigenous land strategy to be presented to each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days . . .
Part (8) of this amendment states:
The national indigenous land strategy, and changes made to the national indigenous land strategy, are disallowable instruments . . .

Part (9) states that no land is to be purchased and no moneys distributed until after the national indigenous land strategy has been tabled. First of all, I wish to comment on the last point, part (9). I think it has been generally admitted that that would cause undue problems for the corporation and for its tasks—

TALK.START.PARA: —We have conceded that.

—Senator Campbell has indicated that that has been conceded, so we are really not talking about part (9). I do not think we are talking about part (7) either. I think everybody is in agreement that part (7) should operate—that is, there should be a tabling of the documents.

PARA.TAB: The question is whether the strategy is to be a disallowable instrument. Arguments have been advanced that this would go against the thrust of what the opposition, the Greens and I have intended, and that is to ensure that as much autonomy as is possible within our democratic system is to be given to the corporation in the exercise of its land acquisition and land management functions. That has been one of the basic premises upon which the amendments have been advanced and supported by the committee.

On the face of it, this appears to take a step back from that, but I do not see that situation at all, because this parliament is a parliament not only for white Australians but for indigenous Australians as well. That is the important point. I believe we would be failing in our duty to Aboriginal peoples if we were not to ensure that part (8) is incorporated. The reason I say that is that in any executive government appointed body there will inevitably be an influence exercised by the person who appoints that particular body. When I say `inevitably', that is probably taking it too far. There is a very real likelihood that that could occur, either directly or indirectly.

The results of that could be that a number of Aboriginal persons would be seriously disaffected by the national strategy that is being developed, notwithstanding the fact that we have moved amendments, which have been adopted, that the national strategy has to emerge out of regional strategies. Nonetheless, I believe that Aboriginal Australians are as entitled to have the national parliament consider seriously the question of the national strategy as any other Australian is entitled to in the normal course of events so as to question the power and the possible influence of the executive government and perhaps an undue influence on strategies.

In the Native Title Act there are disallowable instruments—there is a heap of disallowable regulations, at least. I will not go into them, but most of them deal directly with determinations made by the minister. The same is the case in three other Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander related pieces of legislation. There are disallowable instruments in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Reserves and Communities Self-management) Act 1978, as well as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989.

As I said, most of those relate to ministerial decisions. However, I will give an example of some that do not. Under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act both houses may restore to office a regional councillor suspended from office by ATSIC. I did not hear the argument advanced during debate on that legislation that that should not be a disallowable instrument on the basis that it is interfering with the autonomy of ATSIC which, after all, is an elected body, not an appointed body—or it will be. Under that act, both houses may restore to office a chairperson or deputy chairperson of a regional council suspended from office by the minister. That is a direct matter. People might say, `Unanimously we agree that a direct executive government decision such as that ought not to escape the overview of the parliament.'

The government cannot say that what the opposition is proposing in this amendment offends in the way that it has suggested. In fact, that particular provision would seem to be even more of an interference than the one that is currently being proposed. I remind the committee that we are only suggesting that it be a disallowable instrument; we are not suggesting that we are going to be altering or amending the national strategy. The strategy would have to have rather extraordinary failings if a matter were such that it would be disallowed by either house of parliament. We would have to have an enormous upsurge of discontent amongst those affected, or likely to be affected, by the national strategy before we could get the numbers in either house.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you sure?

—Yes. We are not talking about the national strategy; we are talking about one that could be influenced very substantially by the minister who has appointed the members of the corporation. That is the basis for this particular amendment.

PARA.TAB: The basis is the possible exercise of undue pressure by the minister of the executive government which appoints members of the corporation to the detriment, as they might feel, of Aboriginal Australians. I believe that they have the right of protection as is normally the case for every other Australian. I simply do not accept the suggestion made by the government that, somehow, we are taking a step back from what we have been doing thus far—that is, to provide the corporation with the independence it deserves and the structures of consultation which are required to develop a particular national strategy.

I am a parliamentarian who believes that this chamber particularly—certainly this the case as well in respect of the other chamber; however, members of the other house are elected on the basis of individual electorates, and some of those electorates may not have Aboriginal persons—should be a chamber for all Australians; it should be a chamber for Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders as well as all other Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to put one view which I think is very important in our quest to achieve what Senator Harradine has been arguing for—that is, that the strategy not only be tabled but also be disallowable. A thought which has just occurred to me should, I hope, appeal to the Greens because of the importance they particularly have placed on the national strategies reflecting the regional strategies—that is, a grassroots-up approach to creating the national strategy.

PARA.TAB: We have already been through the arguments about ensuring that, if the national strategy takes place, after all the consultation the Senate has now mandated is required under the law, the ILC board could still do the consultation but could still have a strategy that does not reflect that consultation. There is a requirement because of the J series of amendments that the national strategy reflect the regional strategy. But the reality of it is that if the national strategy does not reflect the regional strategies—as Senator Harradine has articulately put it—Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people would have no ultimate redress or leverage.

The strategy will be tabled here. Senator Chamarette and Senator Campbell may not like the national strategy, nor might every Aboriginal person in Australia. But it would not matter how much they jumped up and down about it or how often they wrote letters to us saying, `This national strategy has betrayed everything the board said that it would be,' because, unless it is disallowable, they would have no leverage. That is an ultimately sensible argument as to why that leverage should be put in place by supporting amendment 20 to subsection (8). Ultimately, the national strategy may not honestly represent the regional strategies. It may not reflect those and it may not derive from those, even though we require that it should. Ultimately, no-one has any say as to whether it does.

As Senator Harradine says, it would be a most unlikely thing for the parliament to disallow. But the reality is that Aboriginal people would have this power in their hands if the strategy put forward by their leaders did not reflect those regional strategies. I urge the committee to strongly consider that argument, which, in a very real way, makes the case for putting the power in the hands of those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens have given their reasons twice, so I will not repeat them. But I will respond to Senator Harradine and to Senator Campbell. I was particularly moved by Senator Harradine's comments, and there is a validity to the argument presented. Nevertheless, there are two reasons why the Greens will not be supporting this. One reason is that the parliamentary system is essentially an imperfect system. It is even more so in terms of representing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

PARA.TAB: My concern is that, because it is up to the whim of representation in the parliament and the numbers and unrelated to content, the way in which a disallowance motion will be eventually decided will have more to do with the numbers in the parliament and the capacity to disrupt than the actual wishes of the Aboriginal people regarding the content to which they object. I have great sympathy with the need of Aboriginal people to have a capacity to challenge the national strategy. There is extreme importance in the argument that Senator Campbell raised: what if the national strategy does not reflect the regional strategies as required by our amendments? What redress or leverage do Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have?

My response is that I do not feel that making it a disallowable instrument is the ideal way to give them leverage because I think it gives too much leverage to make them a political football—and we know, we have had those concerns raised. I do think they have one mechanism—and that is what reassures me—and that is, it can go to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; it does run to the way in which the minister undertakes office. If there are problems with that then I believe that the content can be challenged. As I am much more concerned about the content being challenged by the Aboriginal people who have the concerns, I would prefer that method of redress and leverage rather than support what I think is a perfectly reasonable suggestion of the tabled document becoming a disallowable instrument.
I regret that I cannot be swayed by those arguments. Our stand is that we what to give maximum leverage to Aboriginal people and not necessarily to the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not regret at all not being swayed by any of the arguments. I think there are some quite clear points here. Senator Harradine talked about the theory of disallowance. We all in here know a great deal about the politics of disallowance. Having added cumulative layers of process here, it is neither right nor appropriate for us to give parliament the opportunity to disallow in this case because to do so will cause huge and unacceptable delays that would undermine the whole purpose that we have spent a lot of time putting in place. So I am not swayed by any of the arguments at all.

That was the subject of previous debate. I will not go into it any further in order to save time. Suffice to say that this amendment includes a further subsection (1A) which refers back to (1)(c) and says that that does not authorise the Indigenous Land Corporation to carry on a land management activity in relation to a particular piece of land held by indigenous land-holders otherwise than under agreement with that land-holder. So it gives it the same safety or assurance as is contained in (1)(a). The draftsman has seen fit to include a new section (1A). I do not quarrel with the drafting of that. I understand that it was done for a particular reason. I commend the amendment to the committee. I believe it addresses the query that I raised previously.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, there are two other amendments that have been passed over. I have made a request that the AA series of the Greens' amendments be deferred until consideration of the Greens' A series. My understanding is that we are ready to move on to the Democrats' amendments in relation to section 192W.
—I call Senator Kernot to move amendments 1 and 2 on behalf of the Democrats.

—I am considering withdrawing these amendments, but I want to put on the record why they were drafted in the first place and then get a response from the government on this matter. We had a lot of discussion on Monday about whether or not the fund should be in the public account and what effect that would have on the deficit. The Democrats had considered that, but I guess our paramount concern was that the land fund should be self-sustaining, as the government promised that it would be. That required the fund eventually being able to achieve investment returns in each year higher than dispersals.

PARA.TAB: At the Senate finance and public administration hearing, we heard evidence from investment advisers J. P. Morgan which I think casts some doubt on whether this self-sustainability could be achieved under the government's plan of investing in a fairly narrow range of cash instruments. J. P. Morgan—and I concede this is just one form of external advice—argued that diversifying the portfolio would allow a higher level of return for any given level of risk. They argued that on diversified investment of a securitised fund it could be as much as $300 million or 20 per cent larger in 10 years.

I thought it was important for us to consider that option. On that basis we drafted amendments to achieve that. Our amendments had three key parts. Firstly, the investment of the land fund was to be done by professional investment managers with more input from the business and Aboriginal communities through a committee of advisers. Secondly, the land fund was to have wider investment powers similar to those of trustees in general law. Thirdly, the guaranteed appropriations to the land fund were to be securitised, allowing for an immediate issue of land fund bonds and investment of the full amount of the land fund. Apart from J. P. Morgan, various other private sector advisers told us that this model was workable.

The government, through the Minister for Finance, Mr Beazley, raised with us its serious concerns about this proposal. Its central concern was with the proposal to securitise the funds appropriations into an issue of index bonds. Representatives of Treasury argued that recent issues of index bonds had not marketed very well and that there were very grave doubts about whether a market float of specific land fund bonds would raise an appropriate return. They talked about a very recent experience with index bonds and the way in which that placed grave doubt on the realisable value of the fund, which would in turn reduce the base from which returns on a diversified portfolio would run. So that is their first concern.

The second thing they said to us was that they were concerned about allowing for diversified investments. They argued that while cash instruments have performed poorly in the last year over time, a four per cent real return needed to sustain the fund was quite feasible. They also pointed out that existing audit legislation, despite what we said on Tuesday about other models, in fact allows the finance minister to invest in a diversified portfolio, although this is a power which is seldom used.

So the Minister for Finance and Treasury officials argued that they were sufficiently confident of achieving a four per cent return. We said, `Well, we don't want to just rely on your confidence. We'd like to actually make sure it happens.' When I move to 193AA and my amendment (8)(a), I will tell honourable senators why we will accept the so-called top up proposal in preference to pursuing this fairly complicated structure to achieve a more diversified portfolio. So I will not be proceeding with amendments 1 and 2.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—So the amendments have not been moved and they are withdrawn.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply want to confirm what the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Kernot, said about the discussions that were held. The government, indeed, put very strongly the views that Senator Kernot just referred to. I want to confirm that the Audit Act allows the trust fund balances to be invested in certain ways. In essence, these are where the investment is guaranteed by a Commonwealth or state government instrumentality, but the Minister for Finance can authorise other forms of investment under that act.

PARA.TAB: The government accepts the concerns that the Democrats raised about guaranteeing the returns. For that reason we indicated to Senator Kernot that we will support the Democrats' amendments, when they are moved, that will provide for that top up, if it is required to guarantee the return on the trust.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 25, proposed section 192X, line 20, omit "and the Commission under this Division".
Clause 3, page 27, proposed subsection 193A(4), formula, omit "$24 million", substitute "$45 million".
Clause 3, page 27, proposed subsections 193A(5) and (6), lines 16 to 33, omit the subsections.
Clause 3, page 28, proposed subsection 193A(8), lines 10 and 11, omit "(4), (5), (6) or (7)", substitute "(4) or (7)".
Clause 3, pages 28 and 29, proposed section 193B, line 12 (page 28) to line 12 (page 29), omit the section.

In the minority report on the hearing conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on this bill in October, Senator Ellison and I at page 41 asked the question: why two land funds? If the ILC is being set up under the fine principles espoused in the preamble to the Native Title Act—that is, to assist those who have been dispossessed and who are unable to assert native title rights—it needs to be done as effectively as possible.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette—and I am sure we will talk more about this as this day goes by—has said that the level of funding is not enough and that more money is needed. While all of us in this chamber recognise the considerable disadvantage suffered by Aboriginals, the coalition is making the point with these amendments that, if we are setting up a land fund to assist Aboriginals, we should be ensuring that the resources get to the people who need them most.

There is a very clear recognition—by experts in Aboriginal affairs as well as by the man in the street—that we spend a lot of money, not only on Aboriginal affairs but on all sorts of other programs to assist disadvantaged Australians. In fact, billions of dollars are spent to assist disadvantaged people. But there is also a clear recognition—this can be heard standing at the bar, at a barbecue or just about anywhere—that there is a lot of inefficiency in the bureaucracy and in the delivery of that well-intentioned assistance.

Probably unfairly, a lot of people perceive that in the area of Aboriginal affairs there is a lack of efficiency in the delivery of assistance. As I said earlier, people see the billions of dollars that Senator Collins talked about going to Aboriginal people but, after years and years of programs implemented by well-intentioned governments of both political persuasions, the plight of Aboriginal people does not seem to have improved very much.

We have here a genuine attempt to assist disadvantaged Aboriginals, particularly those who have been disadvantaged as a result of their dispossession. But we also have—and the federal government has made no attempt to hide this fact—the effective establishment of two land funds. One is already provided for with ATSIC. On page 12 of the current additional estimates statement of the Department of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs there is stated the specific objective `to promote economic independence and support the social and cultural development of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples through the land acquisition and management and the business funding scheme programs'. So that is already in place; there is already an administration within ATSIC that is doing that.

As it now stands, the government's bill creates a new administration with new administrative expenses and new overheads such that there will be two parallel administrations over what the government calls a transitional period. But in seeking to establish a function like that, we really should be trying to avoid duplication. We have already heard in this debate that there is significant duplication between state and federal initiatives in the area of Aboriginal affairs, including land functions. Here the government is clearly saying that it will be setting up two operations which will run parallel for a period of three years—that is, up until 1997. That means we will have two administrations.

The effect of the coalition's amendments is to ensure that the money that is already going into the land acquisition functions of ATSIC is not directed back to the ILC, syphoned through and then back to ATSIC again, but that all of it goes into the ILC, and that the administration of the ILC is efficient and therefore maximise the money that can be applied to land acquisition and management for the benefit of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The amendments ensure that that money is not chewed up in a dual administration of what is quintessentially an identical administrative function. That is the nub of the argument.

We believe it is quite outrageous to suggest that we seek to assist Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in acquiring land when what we are effectively doing is ensuring that the people who get the real assistance and the real benefit are the administrators here in Canberra. That is something that riles all sorts of people. As I said earlier in the week, it riles the redneck people who like to kick the anti-Aboriginal can because they just talk about the Aboriginal industry and the Aboriginal bureaucracy and use this sort of foolishness as an excuse to kick that often racist can. But it could also be very upsetting to those of us who do have a genuine concern at trying to see Aboriginal disadvantage overcome. I do not think any of us would like to see more bureaucracy and more administrative expense in these sorts of programs than is absolutely necessary.

There will be further amendments dealing with this problem. Senator Chamarette is proposing—I do not know whether the amendment has been circulated yet; it may be in the stack of paper on my desk—to deal the administration expense side of things further down the track today. The effect of the coalition amendments is to ensure that all of the money flows into the ILC, that the administration is efficient and that we do not have this duplication for what the government calls a transitional period.

The reality is that a transition period is simply not necessary on any basis. The government has not put in any of the hearings on the bill or any arguments publicly or privately that there is some sensible, practical, administrative reason why we should have these two funds. I have used in the arguments in the minority report the establishment of the Australian Securities Commission as an example of a massively more complicated Commonwealth body that effectively was up and running within a few months with virtually no transitional period. It had to amalgamate the companies officers in six different states and the territories. It had to move from the state administration of companies law to the federal administration of companies law, where it was dealing with something like 900,000 clients, 900,000 corporations, and that transition was effectively achieved under the chairmanship of Mr Hartnell within a period of a few weeks.

So there is no administrative practical reason why we need to have this three-year handover. What it is really inviting to happen is that there will a dual administration, much more expense allocated to administration than is required and, therefore, ipso facto, a diminishing of the amount of Commonwealth resource that is go to the clear objective of the land fund, and that is to assist Aboriginal people. That is the intent of our series of amendments and I commend them to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of supplementary comment, I draw fellow senators' attention to the amendment which was passed in relation to the principles and object of this bill and, in particular, principle 3(e), which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . In the performance of functions and the exercise of powers under this Part, the following principles are to be adhered to:
(e)administrative costs should be kept to a minimum and duplication of administrative capability should be avoided.".
I remind the chamber that we have amended the bill thus far in that manner and this just extends that principle and, I believe, sits comfortably with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Greens comment on our view of these amendments, I would like to ask the minister to justify why this split is necessary, because I think it needs to be on the public record. What I have heard is that it was initially a deal with the Northern Territory government essentially against the interests of the Aboriginal people by preventing them from using any of the ILC funds under the land rights legislation in the Northern Territory. There was then a double deal—or a counter deal—with the Aboriginal people that said, `It's all right; half will still be going to ATSIC', and then presumably to the Northern Territory people who would be disadvantaged by the first deal in order to gain access under the Land Rights Northern Territory Act.'

PARA.TAB: If our amendment which said that the Northern Territory Land Rights Act should be able to be used for people under the ILC funding had been accepted, then we would have been happy to support the removal of the split. Because our understanding is that these amendments would very badly disadvantage Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory, the Greens are not supporting them. I would like to hear the minister's justification for this duplication of land funds of virtually identical amounts of money that would be administered for the next three years.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that when we get an agreement with the Greens it is referred to as an agreement; when we get an agreement with anyone else it is called a deal. I suppose it is just a question of where we sit in the arrangement. It is an absolute fact that these are transitional arrangements, unabashedly so, and they are part of an agreement that was reached after a lot of negotiation with representatives of Aboriginal organisations.

PARA.TAB: I am aware that the Greens have a view that the existing provisions of the Northern Territory Land Rights Act that conversions of pastoral land in the Northern Territory should be able to continue past 1997—which is a provision of the act which has existed for some 18 years—should not be there. I respectfully disagree with that view. As the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly Parliamentary Record will indicate, I have respectfully disagreed with that view for over a decade.

Those were transitional arrangements also that were brought in originally in the Northern Territory Land Rights Act. Frankly, I think the period that was allowed to 1997 for those conversions to take place—which can mean, effectively, that pastoral property can be taken out of production if that is the end result after conversion—was a fair go. I certainly do not support any suggestion that that should be removed. I might add that the land councils that operate very professionally in the Northern Territory do not exactly faint at the prospect either. In fact, it is something that they have been working with now for almost 20 years and are well and truly capable of handling when the time comes.

ATSIC has built up a substantial degree of expertise in land acquisition for Aboriginal people in Australia. Applications have already been received and processed for the 1994-95 year and all the funds have been allocated. The continuation of ATSIC's land acquisition until 1996-97 will ensure a smooth transition. During this period ATSIC will have time to finalise and put to rest all of its final purchases and land management arrangements that are already in place. We have had extensive discussions with Aboriginal groups, and I can assure Senator Chamarette that we have no doubt at all that ATSIC and the ILC will work with total cooperation during this period.

I just mention in passing that ATSIC operates and has operated—and inherited from previous administrations—a concessional home loan scheme for Aboriginal people. That scheme in various forms has been operating certainly most of my life, to the best of my knowledge. The reason I mention in passing ATSIC's long experience and expertise in doing these things—I just make that point—is that that is very similar in nature to the proposal which by way of amendment has been brought into the ILC arrangements in respect of purchasing individual property. Let us put it right on the line: this means houses for Aboriginal people to have individual title to and do what they will with.

The fundamental difference is that the ATSIC scheme, which has operated for a very long time and which is a concessional scheme, provides a loan which does have to be repaid, not unreasonably, by the Aboriginal purchaser, who does get the advantage of getting concessional rates as a recognition of the economic difficulties that most Aboriginal people in Australia have. It may well be that Senator Ellison and Senator Campbell are not even aware of the details of that scheme, which has a quite complex stepped arrangement for concessional loans.

I have to say to Senator Chamarette that I have a strong view that that has been a very appropriate and welcome form of assistance for helping Aboriginal people acquire housing in their own right, to do what they will with. It has worked very well indeed. It is an appropriate way of doing it, as against the totally inappropriately way of doing it—again, to my total astonishment, with the support of the coalition—that has been put in this bill. It is precisely a transitional arrangement. That explanation has been given by the government. It came out of intense negotiations with all parties concerned.

As with many agreements, not everybody is entirely happy with the arrangement. One group that has expressed some dissatisfaction is the Northern Territory government. I have to say that there is some validity—and I have said this publicly for more than 10 years now—in the Northern Territory government's quite legitimate concern as managers of pastoral land in the Northern Territory that for an indefinite period of time there is a possibility of not just land acquisition but that with conversion the land can be put to another use. It would not worry me if every pastoral property in the territory and in the Kimberleys was being run and operated by Aboriginal pastoralists, as many are. The problem is that there would be no requirement that it continue as an operating pastoral concern. Those concerns by the Northern Territory government are legitimate. However, I do not believe its criticism of these arrangements is legitimate at all.

Senator Chamarette referred to this matter; that is the reason I mentioned it. She refers to double deals being done. That is utter nonsense. What the Northern Territory government was legitimately concerned about was that under the existing arrangements, if an additional and substantial sum of money was provided, effectively doubling the land acquisition capacity of Aboriginal people, this would lead—particularly in depressed times when land prices on pastoral properties are down and when there is no question that there are pastoralists who would be attracted by offers to exit their properties—to some sort of huge land acquisition in the Northern Territory, with the consequent conversion meaning that significant parts of the Northern Territory pastoral industry would disappear. That is an entirely unwarranted concern, in my view; and I have said so many times. It is an exaggerated view of what would be likely to happen.

The concerns Senator Chamarette raised on behalf of the Northern Territory government that some double deal was done related to the agreement the government then sensibly reached that new money would not be used for that purpose but that ATSIC could continue until the cut-off date of 1997 to use its acquisition powers to continue, as it has been for years, to acquire—when it takes the decision in terms of its priorities—pastoral properties in the Northern Territory.

The only fear that would then be raised, and I am prepared to bet large sums of money that this is not going to happen, is that the $21 million of ATSIC funds would be used—this is what Marshall Perron was referring to in terms of his reference to double dealing; and it is a nonsense scenario—exclusively or largely over the next three years to purchase land in the Northern Territory to the exclusion of everywhere else in Australia.

I know that Senator Chamarette is extremely familiar with Aboriginal organisations, with Aboriginal politics and with the fact that they play it as hard as or harder than everyone else. She would also be familiar with the fact that there are three Northern Territory commissioners out of the 20 on ATSIC. As I say, I am prepared to bet Senator Chamarette a huge sum of money—any sum she would like to name—that the prospect of ATSIC's land acquisition funds exclusively being devoted to land purchases in the Northern Territory is a highly unlikely scenario indeed.

What I confidently predict will happen is that the pattern of purchases by ATSIC over the next three years in the Northern Territory will continue very largely as it has since ATSIC was set up, because the same balance of power exists on the commission. There are the same broad range of interests across Australia and the same priorities will continue to apply to that $21 million fund for the transitional period that it continues to operate. That is the explanation. I do not believe that Senator Chamarette's reference to or her concerns about this double deal are valid for the reasons that I have just given.

So far as the transitional arrangements are concerned, I believe they have considerable merit in allowing ATSIC, after a long period of being in the land acquisition business, to gradually wind down its operations over that period while at the same time allowing the ILC to establish its expertise. The government is absolutely assured by ATSIC that there will be no difficulty at all with these transitional arrangements being handled professionally, competently and cooperatively by the Aboriginal organisations concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what we are forgetting here is the history. The history is that ATSIC was set up before the native title judgment was made. So it is a bit unrealistic to say that, as from this point here and now, ATSIC should cease to have any responsibility for land acquisition and land management when it has been a very important part of its functions. Notwithstanding that structural problem, the problem of duplication existing for a couple of years—
—Three years.

—Okay—till 1997. Given that we lost the amendment to rectify the situation in the Northern Territory—the Greens' amendment which the Australian Democrats supported—and irrespective of the politics of the deal, I think the most sensible thing to do is to maintain an orderly transition. So the Democrats will not be supporting this opposition amendment.

—I thank the minister for his clarification about what he understands to be the interaction between section 191U of the legislation and the split of moneys. I indicate that the Greens, because of our commitment to Aboriginal people and the desire not to see them disadvantaged by what we consider to be an utterly inappropriate section, section 191U, we will not be supporting the amendment put forward by the opposition.

PARA.TAB: We express our concern about the fact that the ATSIC money will have two pressures placed on it and that one or other group of people will be disadvantaged. The amount of money which has been available over the last few years and which will remain available for three more years under ATSIC will be the only window of opportunity for Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory to access land under the land rights act.

Obviously, they will fight hard, as the minister has indicated, for their rights. If they win, fair enough, but it will be to the disadvantage of Aboriginal people right around the rest of Australia who are trying to gain access to ATSIC funding. If, on the other hand, they do not win, they are disadvantaged. It is a very sad and regrettable commitment with the Northern Territory government. I will later be moving an amendment which indicates that the Greens do not support a sunset clause being put on land rights legislation. Regrettably, I am not expecting support for that amendment, but I flag it now.

The Greens series B amendments and our amendment C2 relate to a single payment to the ILC. I will withdraw that amendment at this point. I simply indicate that the Greens will not be supporting the opposition's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has failed to say why there should be two funds. It has said that it is a sensible transition. Senator Kernot quite properly says that ATSIC does have an institutional history of dysfunction.
—Because it was set up before native title.

—Yes, and that makes my point. We have an institutional history under the national companies and securities scheme of a cooperative companies administration which, between December 1990 and January 1991, transferred to an entirely different system. We had hundreds, possibly thousands, of state public servants who had been responsible for administering companies in various states—some would suggest in not the best way possible during the 1980s in particular—who moved across to the new administration over a period of four, five or six weeks.

PARA.TAB: There is absolutely no doubt that within ATSIC there are people who have enormous experience and, I am sure, expertise and wisdom when it comes to administering land funds. In the latest report of ATSIC the operations of the land acquisition function are detailed. It will be like deja vu for those of us who have been dealing with the land fund bill over the last few days and weeks.
On page 41 of the ATSIC annual report, under `Land Acquisition,' three of the most important issues for the management of this program in 1993-94 were listed. The first one was:

SPEECH.PARA: determining the mix of funds to be spent on new acquisitions versus management of existing properties;
That will ring a bell with Senator Chamarette. That is a dilemma which ATSIC has, and it is a dilemma that Senator Chamarette has correctly identified in the ILC. The annual report goes on to say:
further developing procedures for the efficient delivery of the program, especially having regard to the different land management regimes in each State and Territory;
Again, that is an issue that the coalition identified and which was the subject of a successful amendment in the Senate. The report continues:
developing protocols for ATSIC's interaction with the proposed ILC in the context of the proposed establishment of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund.

The coalition recognises the fact that this amendment is not going to get the support of the requisite number of senators to be successful. However, I respectfully suggest to all senators that the third issue—that is, `developing protocols for ATSIC's interaction with the proposed ILC'—supports our argument enormously. Instead of having people in the land acquisition section of ATSIC developing protocols for ATSIC's interaction with the ILC, those people should be integrating with the ILC right now—not wasting time developing protocols. They should be developing an integrated organisation called the ILC with the sole objective of delivering assistance to the Aboriginals whom we are seeking to assist with this legislation. They should be seeking to assist the Aboriginals to acquire land and work out appropriate ways of managing that land and assisting those people—not sitting inside some ivory tower in Canberra and developing protocols to see how the two organisations are going to get on together between now and 1997.

PARA.TAB: It is an absolutely classic example of duplication, government waste and inefficiency. Who are the people who miss out under this?—Torres Strait Islander and Aboriginal people who want redress and assistance because of their dispossession and their disadvantage. There is no practical reason that this minister or Senator Kernot has given as to why we should have this stupid three year transitional period where we will have administrative expenses doubled at the cost of the people that Senator Kernot seeks to represent here.

The minister is quite right; there is a balance between the states about where ATSIC spends its money. The minister may be aware that in the last year this report covers the expenditure was of the order of $2.2 million in the Northern Territory. What was the running cost of the whole program in this last financial year? The running cost of the ATSIC land acquisition program was just under $3 million. All of the money spent on purchasing pastoral properties in the Northern Territory in the last financial year was less than what was spent on administration here in Canberra. So more money went into paying bureaucrats in Canberra to administer the program than for all the pastoral leases purchased in the whole of the Northern Territory.

What are we going to do here? We are going to set up a new administration and spend another $3 million to administer land acquisitions. So we will have two lots of administrative expenses instead of one. Again, we could take all of the purchases in the Northern Territory for the last year and pump them into more bureaucracy in Canberra, because the government wants to have two funds instead of one. Senator Chamarette hit the nail absolutely right on the head. Whether it is called an agreement or a deal makes no difference, because it is the consideration involved. The consideration here was that Mr Keating tried to get Marshall Perron to support the concept of the land fund. Marshall Perron said, `I'll support it as long as you don't spend all the money buying pastoral leases in the Northern Territory.' That is where proposed section 191U came from. Mr Keating said, `Fine, that is okay, Mr Perron. We'll put a ban on using land fund money to purchase pastoral leases for conversion in the Northern Territory.'

TALK.START.PARA: —And we have.

—The government has done that; that is very good. When people go and shake hands with Mr Keating, they must remember Sir Charles Court's old saying, `Be careful, don't shake hands with a cobra,' because he will bite them where it hurts. That is what happens when people do deals with Mr Keating. Do not shake hands with a cobra. He put in proposed section 191U and said, `No, we won't use this land fund money to purchase land in the Northern Territory.'

PARA.TAB: But Mr Perron was a practical and sensible man. Anyone who has been in Northern Territory politics for a long time probably becomes more practical. He probably did not think the government would be so stupid—and waste so much taxpayers' money—as to have two land funds instead of one. So Mr Keating said, `Mr Perron, we'll give you a commitment that there won't be any money from the land fund used to purchase properties to be converted under the land rights Northern Territory act.'

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't say he was going to remove ATSIC's land acquisition right.

—No, of course he did not; Mr Keating kept his word! Everyone in Australia knows that Mr Keating is a man of his word and that when a deal is done with Mr Keating, it will stick! What Mr Perron did not realise was that Mr Keating had his fingers crossed behind his back. Mr Keating said, `I'll promise you that we won't use any land fund moneys to purchase land in the Northern Territory; we'll just have another land fund and use it for that.' The arguments made by the minister and by Senator Chamarette are actually quite—
—What other land fund? It's the one that has been there for years.

—Of course it has! It is gross hypocrisy and absolute stupidity to say that we will help Aboriginals to buy land but in doing so, instead of having one lean, mean, efficient organisation with its objective to actually assist Aboriginals, we will have two administrations. We all know the reason why we are going to have two administrations until this magical date in 1997. There is no practical, administrative, sensible reason why we should have a transitional period that happens to be exactly three years and which complies exactly with the date of the sunset provision.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette has gone right to the heart of it: the transition period is to get around the first deal Mr Keating did with Mr Perron. Mr Keating said, `No, it's okay. You support this land fund, Mr Perron, because we won't come up and buy up the Northern Territory.' The date of the sunset provision is to ensure that the government can get around that promise. It reminds me of the promise Mr Keating made to the premiers in June last year. He said, `You come along and create some complementary legislation in relation to native title and we will help pay the compensation for native title and we will compensate you for extinguishment.'

Of course, he made that promise in January. He even went back to the premiers again and said, `As long as you don't join Premier Court in the High Court action opposing the constitutionality of the Native Title Act, we will compensate you. Anyone who goes and joins Richard Court will not be compensated.' Mr Keating again made a promise to the premiers, `We'll pay you compensation.'

So what is the situation now? The New South Wales government has done the right thing by the Prime Minister and kept its end of the deal by passing its legislation. The Premier of Queensland, Wayne Goss, and the parliament of Queensland have passed their legislation complementing the Native Title Act here in Canberra. The Kennett government in Victoria has passed its legislation, and I think Mr Brown's legislation in South Australia is on the way through as well. But not one state has proclaimed its legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's pretty divisive.
—Do we know why, Senator O'Chee?
—Because they are having a High Court case.
—No, they are not.
—Of course they are.
—They are in dealings every single week because Mr Keating will not come good with the money. So hundreds of mining leases across Australia—
—Won't come good with their money.

—No—will not come good with the promise he made in June. So we have hundreds of titles, hundreds of mining licences and hundreds of exploration permits all around Australia at a time when there are hundreds of thousands of Australians wanting jobs and Mr Keating again failing to keep his promise on compensation. So hundreds of mining licences and exploration licences in Queensland and New South Wales are being held up because Mr Keating is not keeping his promise. He said, `We'll pay you compensation if you legislate.' They legislated; he did not pay the compensation.

PARA.TAB: What does Mr Keating care? He does not care that hundreds of thousands of people around Australia cannot get jobs. He does not care a damn about that. If he kept his promises and compensation was agreed between New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland and the federal government, these mines would be off the ground. People would be going out buying Landcruisers and running around the country trying to find mines. They would be buying portable accommodation. People out there would actually be doing things.

It is another case of Mr Keating deceiving the people of Australia and not keeping his end of the deal. So we have this massive dislocation in the productive sector of the Australian economy because he has failed again to keep his word. It does not matter—he can go there and make `historic' statements in the House of Representatives saying, `This is an historic day for Australia because we've passed this legislation and all the states have agreed.' But the reality is that, when it comes to the implementation of it, it is stuffed up again, and it has cost Australia in terms of employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you even comment when you didn't even vote for it in the first place?
—I will talk about the hypocrisy of this Prime Minister till the cows come home, and the hypocrisy of promising to pay the states compensation for extinguishment.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—Senator, it is not particularly parliamentary to talk about the Prime Minister's hypocrisy. I would appreciate it if you would actually direct your comments through me as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chairman, the hypocrisy of this Prime Minister is highlighted in his promise to the Northern Territory government that no money under the land fund would be used to purchase properties and then the creation of a device in this bill to ensure that that will happen. The object of the coalition's amendments is to ensure that all the money goes into one fund, that the administration is concentrated in one fund, and that the benefits are directed to Aboriginal people right across Australia.

PARA.TAB: This government does not care about that, because if it did care about it, it would make sure it did not have two land funds for three years. The government has offered absolutely no reason except for the fact that it gets around the promise that was made by Mr Keating to Mr Perron. That is the only reason for there being two funds.

If the government were fair dinkum, it would have kept its word and done something to assist Aboriginals in the Northern Territory in the terms that Senator Chamarette has mentioned. The government has not done that because it is not fair dinkum. Government members are deal makers. They are not driven by any sort of fundamental, humanitarian care for the citizens who are affected by this legislation. They are driven by crass politics, they are shooting off at tangents and they are taken down side paths because of their fundamental hypocrisy in these matters.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite all the micturition and cyclones we have just witnessed, there was no basis for any of the things that have just been said. I would like to give Senator Campbell a very brief history lesson. The commitment to allow purchases of Northern Territory pastoral land to be made for Aboriginal people—in the first instance that was in the 1976 land rights act, unamended—was made in perpetuity. Senator Chamarette may be interested to know that that commitment to which she would like to have the legislation return was, in the original act, open ended. That was a commitment given to Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory by Prime Minister Fraser.
—Senator Chamarette knows that.
—Senator Campbell does not.
—I do know that, you oaf.

—As I say, Senator Campbell is all micturition and cyclones. That act, from memory, was amended in 1986, a fair while ago, by this government, because the open-ended commitment that was given to perpetual conversions being allowed—which, in our view, was probably not anticipated by the Fraser government—we thought was unreasonable in terms of the uncertainty that it would cause to the pastoral industry in the Northern Territory. A long time ago this government put the cut-off date at 1997. In fact, Clyde Holding was the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs at the time and I can remember only too well being involved in negotiations in the Northern Territory when that came about. So it is nonsense to assert—
—How did the opposition vote on that?
—I would not have a clue. I might have a look afterwards. I know how they voted on Mabo.
—They voted for it.

—I am sure they voted for it. All I am saying is that there was a commitment given with regard to new purchases. The government recognised the concerns of the Northern Territory government. That is the agreement on which Senator Campbell is now pouring scorn. We could have just ignored those concerns totally and said, `Go to hell in a hand basket, Northern Territory government. Significantly enhanced amounts of the new money can be used any way you like in the Northern Territory to purchase double the properties and so on.' This government did not do that. The government gave a commitment to the Northern Territory government which we have discharged that that would not happen, and it is not going to.

PARA.TAB: There was no suggestion that overnight we were simply going to cut off the existing arrangements in the Northern Territory that have been going on for years in respect of normal ATSIC acquisitions. To do so would have abrogated legislated commitments in the land rights act—and that was never suggested by the Prime Minister—in the first instance by Senator Campbell's predecessors, in a totally open-ended commitment that had no end to it and, in the case of this government, by an amendment moved by this government almost 10 years ago that there would be a cut-off date in 1997. In other words, there would be the opportunity to both acquire and convert pastoral properties in the Northern Territory until 1997. We do not intend—

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet Clyde Holding was enthusiastic about it!

—Let me tell Senator Campbell that there has been an intense debate, that he has never been involved in, for at least a decade over that issue. We have not given any commitments that we are going to abrogate that legislated commitment. Aboriginal people will have the opportunity to continue to acquire and convert land, as the land rights act says they can, until 1997. There was no commitment given, despite the protestations of Chief Minister Perron. Chief Minister Perron wanted more than we were prepared to give. That is a fact. In fact, what he got was a positive response from this government and the arrangement that was then publicly announced. He is now complaining about that because he wanted that legislative commitment to be abrogated. There is no secret about that; he has wanted that knocked off ever since there has been a Northern Territory government. We never gave a commitment to do that.

PARA.TAB: As a result of all of those reasons, the Northern Territory government not only has nothing to fear from these arrangements but knows perfectly well that the arrangements that have been operating for years will simply continue until the cut-off date, which has been in the legislation for almost 10 years, is exercised in 1997. That did not come as a shocking surprise to the government, despite Senator Campbell's protestations. As a result also of the long-time involvement of ATSIC in land acquisition, it is pleased—and I might add that everyone else I have talked to is pleased—that a transitional arrangement will be set in place that will allow it to gradually get out of that business and the ILC to gradually come into it. There is no question at all, as I have said, that no deals have been done or abrogated.

I want to finish on one final point: the nonsense that Senator Campbell asserted about promises being made of particular kinds of financial assistance to be provided by the Commonwealth government to the states. The federal government made normal offers which, to this point in time, have not been accepted. Negotiations, as they always do, are continuing to go on at some pace between all of the administrations that are cooperating in this arrangement around Australia. After the last briefing I had on this, I have no doubt that, at the end the day, they will be successfully finalised.

TALK.START.PARA: —End of what day?

—But there are discussions. It is an interesting picture that Senator Campbell has painted of the coalition in government. The suggestion has already been made in respect of other things that I have an interest in that the government should simply put out a press statement, announce an amount of money and just fund it. If Senator Campbell was in government, his approach to federal relationships would apparently be that if the states asked for $100 million, the government should simply give it to them on day one. It is an interesting picture.

PARA.TAB: We have made offers. We are negotiating carefully with the states, as we always do on the financial arrangements. Senator Campbell is quite right: negotiations have not yet been finalised, but they will be finalised when a final package of compensation arrangements is agreed on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask the minister a very brief question. I am somewhat intrigued and curious to know why the cut-off date for the transition coincides with the sunset clause, or vice versa. Is the minister suggesting to the committee that the 1997 effective date is necessarily so because of the undertaking given by Clyde Holding at the time of the amendment in 1986? Does that necessarily determine the date of dual operation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —No. No magic is attached to that date. As I have just indicated—at further length than I have done so far in this entire debate—a whole range of issues, which I enumerated, were involved in those negotiations. The negotiations were conducted with a range of interested people. The Northern Territory government was involved, and a range of Aboriginal organisations were on the other side of the negotiations. The Aboriginal representatives agreed, in respect of what was an already legislative cut-off date in 1997, that that period of time suited them as well. It was an agreed transitional period which, at the end of the day, on balance, seemed to satisfy most of the concerns that the federal government was dealing with at the time.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Clause 3, pages 25 and 26, proposed subsections 193(1) to (3), line 34 (page 25) to line 16 (page 26), omit subsections, substitute the following subsections:

PARA.TAB: "`193(1)On the first business day in the first category A year, there is to be credited to the Land Fund such percentage of 1% of the total Commonwealth revenue collected from all sources in the previous financial year as equals:

SPEECH.PARA: N

PARA.TAB: where N is the number of days remaining in the first category A year after the commencement of this section.

(2)On the first business day in the second category A year or a later category A year, there is to be credited to the Land Fund 1% of the total Commonwealth revenue collected from all sources in the previous financial year.".
Clause 3, line 23 (page 26) to line 11 (page 28), omit the section, proposed section 193A, substitute the following section:
"193A.(1) Monies credited to the Land Fund may not be invested other than in the manner for the time being authorised by an Act or a State or Territory Act for the investment of trust funds.
(2) Subject to subsection (1), in each category A year, as far as practicable, not less than 75% of the monies credited to the Land Fund in that year pursuant to section 193 must be invested.".
Clause 3, pages 28 to 32, proposed sections 193B to 193H, line 12 (page 28) to line 40 (page 32), omit the sections.
Clause 5, page 43, paragraph (d) definition of "category B year" lines 26 and 27, omit the definition.

Under this proposed legislation the government will contribute around $1.28 billion over the next 10 years to a trust account within the Commonwealth public account, to be called the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander land fund. The Greens (WA) are concerned that the fund will not be sufficient to meet the land ownership needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and that it will not be self-sustaining.

Two other funds have already been mentioned and I would like to look at those. The first is the ATSIC fund. There is provision in the ATSIC Act for funding to be provided to Aboriginal corporations and communities to assist with land management as well as land acquisition. As we have already pointed out, demand for land management funds under the act outstrips the moneys available. ATSIC already spends some $9 million on funding land management, having decided that it could not meet the demand last year of $13 million. Clearly, the $21 million ATSIC land fund could never meet the acquisition and management requests made of it.

Moreover, this legislation would enable ATSIC to provide land management funding for any Aboriginal held land, not simply land acquired under the fund, so demands on the fund could be unlimited. The ILC's land management function is defined at section 191E and it also relates to any indigenous held land, not only land purchased under the powers granted by this bill. So we are duplicating the amount of money available in the ATSIC land fund at the moment while extending to an almost infinite degree the scope of purposes for which that money is meant to provide.

We also know from the Aboriginal Benefit Trust Account report on the trust created under the 1976 Northern Territory land rights act that demand for funds generally exceeds funds available by a ratio of at least five to one. It is inconceivable that the $45 million per year that would eventually flow to the ILC after the three-year transitional arrangement period could in any way meet the demands placed on it for land management.

If we review some of the benefits of the Aboriginal Benefit Trust Account to land acquisition and management, we learn that 1993-94 was a lean year for those seeking grants, with only $16 million being approved. In 1990-91, as a result of the review of the long-term strategy of the trust account, it was possible to set aside $22 million as an investment reserve while approving grants of $20 million, of which $16 million was earmarked for land acquisition.

We can see that in one year the Northern Territory Aboriginal Benefit Trust Account has allocated virtually the same amount that this government is allocating by way of additional funding through the ILC. I think that comparison is quite appropriate. It also points out the difficulties with the amount. If the ABTA could approve $16 million in one year for land acquisition for the benefit of Northern Territory Aboriginal groups, how far will $45 million annually go?

Those two funds—the ATSIC fund and the ABTA fund—illustrate the paucity of the allocation of $45 million, which is, as we know, only $24 million more than what is currently available through the ATSIC fund. I think I have earlier mentioned the New South Wales land fund. In the end, that will be of almost as much benefit to the people of New South Wales as the fund being set up under this legislation.

The Greens (WA) believe that the fund is extremely unlikely—I think I should speak of it in stronger terms, but I will not—to provide any degree of historical justice for the 95 per cent of Aboriginal people who will not gain anything from the recognition of native title because their native title has already been extinguished. So our Greens (WA) amendment A1 proposes that the House of Representatives amend the bill so that one per cent of total Commonwealth government revenues be placed in the land fund per annum for 10 years. This would see the government contribution exceed $11 billion at the end of 10 years.

We need to ask, and we would like to reply, why one per cent? The first reason for that is because it is a substantial sum, which could, we believe, satisfactorily address the land needs of Australia's indigenous people. One per cent of total revenue would see a government contribute about $1.12 billion per annum, a genuine billion dollar fund, not a spurious one.

Secondly, it was in 1890, when the British handed self-government to Western Australia, that there was a clause placed in the Western Australian constitution to ensure that the new government of Western Australia fulfilled its obligations to protect Aboriginal people. Under that clause, one per cent of total government revenue had to be spent on WA indigenous people. The clause disappeared in 1904 without that money being spent, and early this year a group of Aboriginal people began a challenge on this issue in the High Court. Section 70 of the Western Australian constitution provided that a sum of 5,000 would be set aside each year from the consolidated revenue fund for the welfare of the Aboriginal people of the state. I will give honourable senators the quotes because it shows that even in 1889 there was a sense of justice regarding the provision for the indigenous people of this country. The section states:

SPEECH.PARA: Provided always, that if and when the gross revenue of the Colony shall exceed 500,000 pounds in any financial year, an amount equal to ONE PERCENT on such gross revenue shall, for the purposes of this section, be substitute for the said 5,000 pounds in and for the financial year next ensuing.

It seems that the imperial parliament was not prepared to leave the well-being of the Aboriginal people to the whim of the colonial government and sought to make this permanent provision. How wise of it. Sadly, the colonial government sought to amend this section of the constitution almost as soon as signed copies were delivered from London. It was long accepted that at some point in the history of the state the attempt to amend the section was successful.

PARA.TAB: This notion is currently under dispute in the courts, but a decision is a long way off. In arguing for one per cent of federal government revenues to be set aside for the land fund, the Greens (WA) are using the imperial parliament's imposition on the WA colonial government as a precedent. We use it as a model. We have a rationale for our amendment.

What, may I ask, is the government's rationale? I suggest that how much it can afford might have been a more important imperative for this government. What will not affect the budget deficit in even the slightest way may have been another rationale. What will sound good is more intriguing. How did it ever fit on $1 billion, of which nothing but $450 million would ever reach Aboriginal people? A billion dollar fund sounds really good. In a letter to me dated 17 October 1994, the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The establishment of the Land Fund was agreed to at that time.
He is referring here to the time when the native title rights were recognised by the High Court and then introduced into Commonwealth legislation.

The Government is now establishing a unique set of arrangements including a commitment to future appropriations for 9 years and a permanently sustainable fund to meet the land needs of those who will not benefit from the Mabo decision.

In that letter he does mention the aims of the fund but he does not indicate how on earth he thinks his allocation of $45 million a year is ever going to meet that, so I would like to quote from his letter to me dated 11 October in which he sees that I have difficulty understanding the central importance of this paltry and disgraceful fund put in place by this legislation. He says:
This is why the Land Fund is central to the Government's social justice measures.
He has already said:
I was extremely disappointed to hear of your concerns in relation to the Land Fund Bill, particularly as we are both committed to pursuing justice for Australia's indigenous peoples.
He then goes on to say:

It is the major financial component of social justice measures arising from the Mabo decision, and is aimed primarily at providing land for the majority of indigenous people unable to benefit from the native title legislation.
He goes on to comment on my concerns:

I am aware that you have recently indicated a view that the money allocated is not enough. However in your submission in the Budget context, the Greens advocated an allocation of $1 billion over three years. In terms of quantum, the Government has more than met that requirement.

Now we have the answer to the third rationale I suggested that was a little more subtle. Why did the government choose $1 million? I think it chose it so that the Greens would in some way be pushed to support it, because it bore a very vague and superficial resemblance to our budget suggestion for Aboriginal people, which was $1 billion over three years. What we meant was that they would actually receive that amount of money, and we suggest-
ed, so that it did not blow out the budget deficit and did not cause any problems, that it could be given on the basis of a third each year for three years. We were not assuming it would stop there.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have become drunk with power, Senator Chamarette.

—I just think that, with the Prime Minister's rhetoric about the purpose of this fund, the Greens are entitled to have all sorts of opinions of what money would be there because, again, the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am confident that the Bill meets the aspirations of the great majority of indigenous people in relation to land.

That is why in our budget submission we asked for only $1 billion over three years. When we saw that all that the government was prepared to allow was $450 million over 10 years, but that it was calling it a billion dollar fund, we thought we should challenge the government and produce the rationale to make it a genuine billion dollar fund, that is, $1 billion each year. The Prime Minister agrees. He said:
It can of course be argued that no amount of money could be enough. However, given the need to be economically responsible—
I think that supports rationale No. 1—
the Government has decided on the amount specified in the Bill, an amount seen as satisfactory by the majority of indigenous representatives consulted.

I ask the Prime Minister: how many of those indigenous representatives consulted agree with it now when they realise that that billion dollar fund was a sleight of hand and it meant that they would be receiving $24 million a year more than they presently receive? I am extremely disappointed that the government, with all its high-sounding rhetoric, is unable to really respond to the needs of Aboriginal people. I have a graph, copies of which can be circulated to those present in the chamber, and I request that it be incorporated in Hansard, if it is technically possible.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The graph read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: [GRAPH OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 3120]

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the relative amounts that the government is prepared to be generous about in relation to its budget. From the graph we can see that even the total amount that the government is planning to retain in its own public trust account of just over $1 billion after 10 years is the equivalent of the current ATSIC budget; the cost of Parliament House is slightly less than one year's allocation of foreign aid; and in terms of defence expenditure—

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can she have another crack at it?
—Yes, she can.
—I do have another amendment, so I will come back to that.
—I have been fascinated by Senator Chamarette's contribution. I think that she should continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Campbell. We can see from the diagram I have had incorporated the dismal proportion of one year's allocation to the land fund. If we want to compare it with the 10-year amount that is going to remain in the government trust fund, we can simply look at the costs of Parliament House, which will give the 10-year equivalent. If we look at the annual defence budget we can see that what we are suggesting in the Greens amendment as an appropriate 10-year amount to be given for this land fund is the same as one year's defence expenditure. The allocation of $450 million in draw downs that Aboriginal people will receive under this legislation, providing administration and land management costs do not eat into it totally, will be approximately half of what we are quite prepared to pay for each Collins class submarine.

PARA.TAB: I hope the point has not been lost on my colleagues. What we are offering in terms of the money that the Prime Minister promised will redress the dispossession of Aboriginal people over 200 years and meet the aspirations and hopes of the 95 per cent of Aboriginal people who do not stand to gain anything under native title is appalling. It is appalling that the government is stating that there is any capacity in this fund to do anything but continue the squabbling over tea, flour and sugar which we gave to the Aboriginal people of this land. We have given them nothing over this 200 years that we have oppressed them in their own country. That comparison, I believe, is sufficiently vivid. I would like to close with my response to the Prime Minister's urging me to support his land fund. In my reply of 11 October to the Prime Minister I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Under the bill Australia's indigenous people will only get $24 million more a year than they already receive through ATSIC.
They will get that indefinitely. It will never increase beyond that amount—but it will be diminished. I said:

This money not only has to be used to acquire land but also to manage large areas of indigenous-held land across Australia. $3 million of it is also expected to be spent on running the bureaucracy. It is totally inappropriate to call it a `billion dollar fund' when the fund will simply be a paper exercise between ATSIC and the Department of Finance and the bulk of the money never leaves the public account. The total payments out of the fund over 10 years will not exceed $450 million and of that only $210 million can be regarded as additional to the current position.
I said to the Prime Minister:

Your Government's commitment to redressing indigenous disadvantage is seriously in doubt if the Land Fund is to serve as the central indication of your resolve. The Government's proposal can do little to provide—
and here I am quoting his words—
`land for the majority of indigenous people unable to benefit from the native title legislation'.
I said:
Aboriginal people can hold out little hope for the rest of the social justice package if this is, as you say—
and I again quote the Prime Minister's words—
`the major financial component of social justice measures arising from the Mabo decision'.

That is all I wish to say about the size of the fund. I will just speak briefly to amendment A2, which relates to the fact that the sum of money is so little, is in the public account and is totally tied away from the hands of Aboriginal people.

PARA.TAB: Amendment A2 seeks the relaxation of what investments the ILC can invest money in to any trustee investment in a state, territory or the Commonwealth. It still allows for only very secure investments. The clause also ensures that 75 per cent of the money provided each year under amendment A1 will be invested; that is, we are proposing that, if the government genuinely gives a billion dollars in its fund to Aboriginal people, we are happy for that billion dollars to be in the public account. What we are asking for is a draw down of 25 per cent of that amount, which would be approximately $250 million, providing the remainder is invested and available for investment in secure investments that retain that quantity.

I have just presented the case for the Greens' amendments. We are not anticipating any support in the chamber for our amendments, but I cannot stress more strongly that, if we support this bill with this amount of money, we are writing out the capacity for justice to be restored to the indigenous people of this land. We are writing it out not just for 10 years but forever. People will be denied acquisition moneys from this fund because, as I said in relation to the previous motion I put, the management component will eat into it in a very small amount of time. It really is denying justice to so many people in our country who have been dispossessed. We believe there is no way, unless the government is able to address this point, that anybody who cares about justice for Aboriginal people can support this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a case of lies, damned lies and Green statistics. This amendment is my proof for the assertion I made the other day that the Western Australian Greens are only visiting this planet. I have no doubt that the Greens would see the sense of this amendment, but I would like to point out the huge hole in Senator Chamarette's graph. It is a great big hole.

PARA.TAB: First of all, the graph does not include the $1.5 billion recurrent per annum which is allocated by this government on behalf of the taxpayers of Australia, who provided it in the first place. It does not include that at all. But that is not the biggest hole in this graph. I will tell the chamber what the biggest hole is. The money that we are appropriating for the purchase of land is exclusively for the benefit of the Aboriginal people of Australia; that is, one per cent to 1 1/2 per cent, depending on the statistics we accept—I think that was the last figure I saw—of our total population.

The allocation for the defence of this nation, the allocation that Senator Chamarette has given such emphasis to in this graph, is a defence allocation that is made on behalf of us all; that is, all Australians—Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal. The foreign aid budget that Senator Chamarette has referred to in this graph is for foreign aid provided for the assistance of people overseas on behalf of us all. The Collins class submarine—so named, I might add, because of its shape—is provided, again, for the defence of us all.

The big hole in Senator Chamarette's graph is that it totally ignores the fact that this fund is for the exclusive benefit of one small part of the Australian community, the Australian Aboriginal people.
