If we drew up a graph—and she might do us the courtesy of getting her Green statisticians to draw up one for us; it would be an interesting looking graph—which factored in the $1.5 billion of recurrent expenditure which is paid out by this government, happily, for the benefit of Aboriginal people, and we then converted this graph to a per capita graph, which is the only accurate way that we could portray this as a graph that indicates relative expenditure, it would be a very interesting looking graph indeed and one that would be substantially different from the one that Senator Chamarette has incorporated.

I am glad that Senator Chamarette has incorporated this graph because it indicates probably more effectively than anything I have heard in this debate so far—and I have followed it carefully from the time it started—just exactly where the Greens come from on this issue. Senator Chamarette gave three reasons why she picked on one per cent. I have dealt with the graph, but she gave two other reasons which the Hansard will indicate. First, it is quite a substantial amount—we cannot argue with that; and second, King George thought it was a good idea at the time. I do not think that either of the reasons Senator Chamarette put forward before she produced her graph is relevant to sensible debate or sensible economic management of this country, which we have a responsibility to carry out on behalf of all Australians. As I say, the graph is fundamentally flawed in its premise.

Senator Chamarette's figures are correct in terms of how much money would be available. The one per cent of Commonwealth revenues that this amendment calls for would provide a fund of $15 billion by the time the fund was completed. The figures that Senator Chamarette has given in terms of the draw down are correct. That would provide annual disbursements for the acquisition of land for the sole benefit of the Aboriginal people of Australia of around $450 million. Having been around the traps for a fair while and having seen how moneys are expended in Aboriginal communities, it would be an interesting exercise to see the ILC, or any other corporation, effectively, responsibly and beneficially spend $450 million per year.

This is a crazy amendment. I could not use words strong enough to describe how crazy it is. I emphasise this because I have been referred to statements made by the Greens that on an issue like this they are prepared to vote this bill down if they do not get it up. That is how fundamentally flawed our approach is as far as the Greens are concerned. The amount of money is so bad that the Greens would rather see no fund at all—these are the statements that have been made from time to time—than not see $450 million per year for land acquisition for Aboriginal people.

I will tell the chamber of a couple of things would happen. First of all, there would be an extraordinary impact on the marketplace. When it is known that there is $450 to spend, I imagine prices would go through the roof in areas where Aboriginal people express an interest in property. It would be like that movie—I cannot remember the title—where the star has to spend $1 million a day for a month to inherit the rest. That is the kind of craziness that Senator Chamarette is contemplating. I am amazed that she has not sat down and thought that through. How could any Aboriginal organisation, with the best advisers in the world, responsibly acquire land at the rate of $450 million each and every year for the benefit of Aboriginal people? It is just a crazy proposition.

It would totally blow out the government's deficit reduction strategy. If it was taken out of the public account—the other proposition that is being supported as part of the Green's package—it would add about $1.5 billion a year to the deficit each and every year. In my view, it would simply be totally impractical to even think that the corporation could responsibly spend the sums that Senator Chamarette is talking about—$270 million if it was to remain in the public account, and $1.5 billion if it was taken out of the public account.

There is another important issue that has to be put on the record; I have alluded to it once, but I will say it far more emphatically in the light of this amendment. The government has carefully considered the amount of money concerned. Senator Chamarette has provided her reasons as to why she determined that it should be one per cent: it is a substantial amount, King George thought it was a good idea, and this graph demonstrates why it should be paid out. The government's consideration was on a slightly different basis, and that was an amount which would substantially increase the current allocations, but at the same time could be contained within the government's responsible fiscal program—that is, managing a budget on behalf of all Australians.

There is another factor, and I referred to it earlier in this debate. At the end of the day, we want this program to be supported by most Australians. That is vitally important, as part of the reconciliation process. I hope the Greens give that as much credence as we do. My view—and it is a strong view—is that this land fund will succeed in doing that. I have put that view in cabinet and outside of cabinet.

The feedback I have got in the discussions I have had with, for example, peak pastoral organisations in Australia, indicate that if it is responsibly managed there is a general willingness around the place to support these proposals. Obviously, a lot of the constituent members are not very happy about it, but most of the peak leadership I have spoken to in Australia are prepared to give this a real good go in a totally positive way. I have had meetings with senior representatives of some of the major pastoral groups in Australia that have offered their assistance in making at least the pastoral side of these acquisitions a success. They have provided suggestions to me, which I have happily accepted and will continue to work on, about how various business arrangements could be entered into which will ensure that not only the land is secured for Aboriginal people but also an income is successfully secured for them and that jobs are provided.

I have been heartened by that response. I could not think of anything more determined or more designed to blow that process out of the water than this amendment. I have no difficulty in saying that I am utterly confident that the amounts of money involved here would be comprehensively rejected by the majority of Australian people and be completely contrary to the aims of the government—that is, to provide a substantive amount of money that will provide a significant boost to the land acquisition programs that are currently in place; to be supported by the majority of Australians; to assist not only in the provision of justice for Aboriginal people but also in the reconciliation process; and, the bottom line being, to fit that within a responsible fiscal framework of management of the Australian budget on behalf of all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree almost entirely with what the minister has said in respect of this fund. The crucial point he makes is that we certainly need to have a broad consensus on these matters if we are going to achieve the sort of reconciliation we all want and overcome the disadvantages suffered by many Aboriginal people. The minister made good points about the effect on the property market. He made a good point about the backlash that this sort of funding proposal would create. We only need to see what happens when funny money enters a property market. Look at what happened during the asset price inflation of the late 1980s in the Australian capital city property markets, with hundreds of millions of dollars of funny money entering the property markets—and the Australian property market is still recovering from that.

PARA.TAB: I have to say to Senator Chamarette in all earnestness and seriousness that the effect of the proposal—as far as funding goes, even though it is extremely well intentioned—would create a massive distortion in the property markets. We are dealing with the pastoral property market, the agricultural property market or the property market in the capital cities or regional towns. We cannot pump hundreds of millions of dollars a year into those property markets without having a significant effect on them. The longer term social consequence would be to create a backlash and we would not carry the community with us.

ATSIC has been running a land acquisition function for a long time. There are examples of where ATSIC has bought properties. Strelley is the obvious example which comes to mind. We have seen reports on channel 7 and channel 10 of people going up to Strelley and looking at this disastrous mess. This sort of thing allows people who are opposed to the assistance of Aboriginals to say, `This is what stuffs up.' Senator Chamarette does not want that to happen; neither does Senator Collins nor I.

The other issue—and I obviously cannot conclude this in 30 seconds, because it comes to one of the crucial points in this bill—is the point that Senator Collins made about the expertise and the achievement of the objectives for the fund. It would be impossible to find the administration required to invest hundreds of millions of dollars a year for the benefit of Aboriginal people; it could not be done practically. The Greens' objective is admirable. Senator Collins talks about only visiting this planet. We are all only visiting this planet. What Senator Chamarette wants to do is to find redress for these problems.
Progress reported.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Pursuant to order, I call upon matters of public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this afternoon to partake in the discussion on matters of public interest. The first matter I wish to raise is that of the Heemskirk Road in the state of Tasmania.
—What about all the other roads in Tasmania?

—Elements within the media in my home state of Tasmania have been attacking the state Liberal government for its initiative to construct a road linking Zeehan, a mining town on the west coast, with Smithton, a regional centre on the north-west coast of Tasmania. This link road will provide an important boost to the economies of the west coast and north-west coast of Tasmania. More importantly, it will provide a boost to the families and small businesses of those centres.

PARA.TAB: The west coast of Tasmania has been a vital part of Tasmania's infrastructure and economy. For in excess of a century it has been reliant on mining and fishing. In recent times, the tourist potential of the west coast has been recognised and appropriate developments are being undertaken. Indeed, some of my colleagues in this place had the benefit of visiting the north-west coast and west coast regions of Tasmania as part of a state wide tour of Liberal senators organised by my friend and colleague Senator Paul Calvert. I must say that Senator Calvert's organisational skills in organising that tour were nothing short of brilliant. Part of Senator Calvert's tour was a visit to the west coast. We accessed the west coast from Burnie through Ridgley after visiting North Forest's world class forestry research station.

This visit was no different to what a lot of tourists do: they proceed as far as Burnie and then they go to the west coast through Ridgley. Indeed, the national highway in Tasmania ends at Burnie. It is my view that it ought to be extended to the Circular Head region and the town of Smithton. The Circular Head area is a very productive area in Tasmania, specialising in the agricultural and forest industries. Unfortunately, its tourist potential has been stifled by the absence of a road linking it with the west coast.

The development of the link road between Circular Head and the west coast will provide a much needed boost to the families and businesses in both of those areas and, in particular, it will provide the opportunity for the development of tourist based establishments, thus providing a greater range and more employment opportunities to those Tasmanian communities. I noted with interest, when I mentioned this road earlier in my speech, that Senator Sherry sought to interject.

It is interesting to look at history. In 1983, the federal leader of the opposition, Mr Hawke, included this very road in a package of promises to justify stopping the damming of the Franklin River. It was clearly recognised over a decade ago by Senator Sherry's own party that such a road would be an important tourist link. Indeed, the Labor Party's failed candidate for Braddon in the 1983 election, Mr Lance Fee, said that the road would `mean a boost for tourism, both in Circular Head and on the west coast.' It also has the bipartisan support of the state Labor Party, so it is very interesting to listen to the comments of Senator Sherry. Expressions of support have come from a wide range of tourism operators and consultants, including some from the mainland. There is no doubt that this road will have great economic benefits for Circular Head and the west coast, and for Tasmania in general.

This link road is an important initiative. It is exactly the type of infrastructure development in which government ought to be involved: providing those developments which are beyond the reach of private enterprise, to allow for an environment in which family businesses and jobs can prosper. The project has the support of both mainstream parties in Tasmania. It is only the Greens, representing less than 10 per cent of the population, who are opposed to the project. If one were to read the print media stories and commentaries from certain Tasmanian journalists, one would think the project had no support at all. My state of Tasmania has suffered sufficiently without elements in the media trying to scuttle every proposal to make Tasmania's economy that little bit more dynamic and self-sustaining.

I now seek to turn to another matter which is of considerable concern in Tasmania. It is the proposal being peddled by the group know as Pedder 2000. Those who are suffering from drought around Australia know what a precious resource water is. Those who live in mainland states and suffer air pollution from the burning of fossil fuels for energy should know that the water generated power in Tasmania is providing a world standard for power generation. For Pedder 2000 to propose the draining of a huge and substantial water resource in times of severe drought and ever increasing concern over global warming shows a callous disregard for our nation's real requirements. The environment industry, funded by Labor to the tune of millions of dollars, has done enough harm to Tasmania. Over 35 per cent of our land mass has been locked away. The environment industry, not satisfied with slowing down Tasmania's progress, is now wanting to turn the clock back.

Lake Pedder has become an icon to the environment industry. It has some emotional `feel-good' qualities about it. As a teenager I walked in to see Lake Pedder before it was flooded. It took a day to walk in and a day to walk out through mud and button grass plains. The group I walked with was able to leave our car at the side of a road constructed by the Hydro-Electric Commission. Nowadays, the tourism potential is much greater, with fully made roads, a chalet, fishing, boating, walks and a host of activities. Whilst the environment industry promises thousands of tourists and economic benefits if Lake Pedder were to be drained, we in Tasmania have heard that promise before. We were told that if a certain section of the Franklin River were not dammed we would have a mass of tourists come and visit. Where are those tourists? I know one thing: they surely are not visiting the Franklin River.

Let us never forget that the main advocate for turning the clock back on Pedder is none other than Bob Brown. The Bob Brown who tells the world that it is impossible for a clear-felled forest ever to regenerate itself is the same Bob Brown who tells the world that even after 20 years of being submerged under water, the land will regenerate itself in a matter of a few years. What is the special quality of drowning land under water for 20 years which allows for quicker regeneration than clear-felling a forest? Methinks there are no such special qualities. Rather, people in the environment industry are engaged in `doing a Richo' and telling untruths when and if it suits their cause.

Although there may be warm and fuzzy feelings to be had by draining Lake Pedder, the consequences of such an action need to be understood by the residents of all the other states of Australia. It is important to remember that about one-half of Australia's emissions of carbon dioxide, the major greenhouse gas, are produced by the energy sector, making mainland electricity authorities leading producers of greenhouse gases. Energy far outweighs the combined total of all other sources, such as industrial processes, agriculture, land use change, forestry and waste, as sources of greenhouse emissions. Tasmania, on the other hand, has the only fully integrated, all-hydro system in Australia, producing clean, renewable energy from our abundant natural fuel source, water.

Lake Pedder is a crucial storage for Tasmania. It is one of only three major storages which protect the state when low rainfall or drought reduces rainfall from the normal run of river components of our hydro system. Not only is it an outstanding scenic attraction in one of the most beautiful parts of Australia's most beautiful state, it is also a key contributor to the Tasmanian economy. Lake Pedder holds 242 square kilometres of water at normal full level, 308 metres above sea level. This is about a third of a billion cubic metres of water. Gordon and Lake Pedder storages combined constitute 31 per cent of the total system energy storage in Tasmania. Lake Pedder itself provides 40 per cent of the average flow to the Gordon Power Station, representing about 65 megawatt average output.

Since commissioning in 1978, the Gordon development has generated more than 18 million megawatt hours, worth about $850 million at current oil prices. Of this total, Lake Pedder has contributed 7.2 million megawatt of electricity worth $340 million. Without the new Lake Pedder, there would be a serious risk of quite high levels of rationing under continued dry conditions. As most of Australia now knows, prolonged droughts are unfortunately a reality. To drain away such a valuable asset would be grossly short-sighted and negligent if not criminal. If replaced by fossil fuel power, there would be an addition to carbon dioxide emissions to the atmosphere of about 0.5 million tonnes per annum.

Given those facts, it is surprising that Bob Brown and the Pedder 2000 lobby are incapable of a bit of global thinking. That is something that they always ask us to do—to think globally and act locally. That is exactly what we in Tasmania have done. What would be better for Australia and indeed the world? Is it to maintain the clean, green, renewable energy source or to deplete the source and add a further 0.5 million tonnes of greenhouse emissions into the air each year? My children and future generations would never forgive us if we allowed the environment industry and its cohorts to destroy this environmentally friendly asset because of some tortured ideological hang-up about Lake Pedder in the minds of a few.

I suggest to the environment industry and those who are so anxious to see the draining of Lake Pedder that, rather than trying to destroy such a wonderful resource, they concentrate on the real and pressing environmental issues of the day: trying to find other energy sources which are capable of renewal which do not create the greenhouse emissions. I suggest that they concentrate their activities on the mainland rather than picking out the state of Tasmania all the time for their green-related agenda.

The people of Tasmania, and indeed Australia, have a wonderful resource in Lake Pedder. It ought to be protected because it combines all those qualities that we are continually told that we ought to achieve. It has the qualities of a tourist attraction, allowing people to gain access to wilderness areas and to enjoy the different rock formations, the different forest types, the different plains and to see the formation of the hills. At the same time, the new Lake Pedder development provides a much needed energy resource to the people of Australia without adding in any shape or form to the greenhouse gases which are now causing such a worldwide problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night in Brisbane a program entitled The Report was screened on Channel 7. The program contained a number of serious allegations, outlining details of how the justice system in Queensland was used to prevent an allegedly corrupt senior police officer from being prosecuted. Indeed, the program alleged not only that the police officer who was the subject of the allegations was not prosecuted, but that the two policemen who tried to lay the charges were themselves subject to court proceedings, disciplinary action and punitive transfers. In short, they had their careers destroyed, while the senior police officer who was the subject of the allegations was able to retire from the police force with full benefits.

PARA.TAB: The program alleged that these events occurred with the knowledge of the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission, senior police and government ministers. It also detailed incidents of state government ministers allegedly misleading parliament. These are very serious matters indeed. I am so disappointed that it appears the CJC has failed to support and protect whistleblowers, with the possibility that it may even have worked together with some police to actively persecute them. I am so disappointed, after so much work by so many people, that there appears to be an overall lack of accountability on the part of the CJC.

It is naturally of great concern when such allegations are screened by a reputable journalist. I have known the particular journalist, Chris Adams, for many years. He is a person of high integrity. I have confidence in the work that Channel 7 did in putting together this program and I am aware that the program has been in the pipeline for many months because the channel checked, re-checked and re-checked the information which was given. Thus it can be seen why one needs to take seriously the allegations which were made.

I do not intend to revisit the allegations in detail today. People can find these out for themselves if they wish to see the program. My concern is again a lack of government accountability. This caused so much damage in Queensland in previous decades and now it appears to be continuing unabated with the present state government. To some extent the issue is not whether or not these allegations are true, although that is obviously important, but the fact that they have been around for some time and have not been adequately answered or resolved.

The Australian Democrats have always attached great importance to the issue of accountability. The operations of the state—government, police, and the courts—must be open and fair in order for public confidence in the system to be maintained. As a Queenslander, I am well aware of the terrible battering which public faith took during the process of the Fitzgerald inquiry. The Criminal Justice Commission was established out of the Fitzgerald inquiry to ensure accountability. The fact that allegations such as these have been made, which unfortunately touch on the competence and reliability of the CJC itself, is a matter of great concern.

The recent report by the Senate Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing also expressed concern at the number of apparently unresolved whistleblower cases in Queensland. This concern was great enough for there to be a unanimous recommendation for an independent inquiry to be held. The case at the heart of last night's Channel 7 documentary is among those which caused such concern to the Senate committee, a committee containing members of the government, as well as the opposition and Senator Chamarette. Former policeman Gordon Harris has been to see me and I am thoroughly convinced of his integrity. There is no mileage in him continuing the allegations and continuing to seek justice. His life and his career have been ruined and yet he wants to see justice done. I have also put on the record on a number of occasions in the Senate the situation surrounding Kevin Lindeberg.

The Australian Democrats believe accountability in government is fundamental to our democratic system. Everyone in Queensland had hopes that the CJC would be the vehicle for ensuring greater accountability in government in that state. It may be that we have had an unrealistic expectation in hoping that the CJC could achieve this on its own.

As most senators would know, Queensland is the only state without an upper house. I do not think it is too self-congratulatory to suggest that the Senate plays a major role in ensuring at least some degree of accountability on the part of the federal parliament. It seems to me that reinstituting the upper house may be the only way to ensure some degree of accountability in my own state of Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter which is not only of public interest but I would suspect and hope is of considerable personal interest to senators and members of parliament. We all have in our offices new laser printers, on the side of which are a couple of labels which I doubt all members and senators would have read. On the side of our largest laser printers is a sticker which says:

SPEECH.PARA: This device conforms to CDRH radiation performance standards, 21CFR Chapter 1 Subchapter J.

It also complies with part 15 of the SCC rules. Intrigued by this, I asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health (Senator Crowley), upon notice, on 20 June of this year, whether there was an Australian standard for electromagnetic radiation emissions and, if so, what it is, what it applies to, and how it is measured? Although the answer that I received was lengthy, it was neither comprehensive nor illuminating. In fact, while the information may be accurate—I have no reason to suspect that it would not be—it does not help us decipher what is on the side of those machines, nor does it give me the confidence that the machines and those many hundreds of thousands that are similar to them—the many consumer owned, electric and electronic devices which may be capable of emitting electromagnetic radiation—are properly tested and monitored. The minister responded in part:

PARA.TAB: The National Health and Medical Research Council has released `Interim guidelines on limits of exposure to 50/60 Hz electric and magnetic fields (1989) as Number 30 in the Radiation Health Series.
The guidelines apply to human exposure to electric and magnetic fields at frequencies of 50 or 60 Hz.

We are told that they do not apply to deliberate exposures of patients undergoing medical diagnosis or treatment, et cetera. We are told that surveys have been conducted by the Australian Radiation Laboratory, Telecom, the utilities including National Electricity and private companies.

What we are not told is whether consumers are being informed about the dangers which may exist or whether there are, in fact, no dangers. We are not told what the levels are and the recommended modes or practices of operation, and we are not told whether the labels on the side of, for example, the laser printers of senators and honourable members mean anything, are relevant to Australia or should be enforced in any particular way or monitored.
We are told, however, in the answer that was given by the minister:

Important research is underway. The results from several major epidemiological studies are expected during the mid 1990s. A large animal tumour study being conducted through the Royal Adelaide Hospital should be completed during 1995. Magnetic field exposure studies have been conducted by ARL and NE.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not told what the results are, what is expected or what the progress is.

PARA.TAB: Because of that lack of information and because there is some community concern about this matter and there has been for some many years, I was interested when a proposal was put to me to conduct some research into this area. I am pleased today to be able to bring to the Senate comprehensive research which provides all the answers that are missing from the minister's answer. It is 40-odd pages long and is, I believe, of world standard in its depth and quality of research. It is entitled Non-ionizing electromagnetic fields and human health: are current standards "safe"? It was prepared for me by Mr Don Maisch.

I would like to ensure that those who are interested in this topic have up-to-date information. This report is available and I am prepared to share it with any of those who are interested. I suggest that all senators and members who have a laser printer, a photocopier, a fax machine, a computer, a monitor and other devices for potential EMF emission should be interested.
The reason they should be interested is as follows. A video produced by the Department of Employment, Education and Training states:

SPEECH.PARA: Many international studies have been unable to demonstrate any link between birth defects or miscarriages and VDUs.

However, upon looking at some of the studies that do demonstrate that link, I think we should be alarmed. I will quote from some of them. At the beginning of 1982, on behalf of the British Civil Medical Advisory Service, Dr Bernard Lee conducted a study of 803 women at the Department of Employment in Runcorn, Cheshire. These women worked at least 10 hours a week with VDUs in the three months prior to and the three months after conception. The results of these women's pregnancies were compared with those of a small control group of women of the same age who were working in the same office complex but who were not regularly using VDUs.

PARA.TAB: Dr Lee found that over 43 per cent of the pregnancies in women who worked with VDUs ended unsuccessfully. Among VDU operators, of 55 pregnancies there were 14.5 per cent miscarriages, 6.7 per cent stillbirths and 22 per cent malformations. This compared with a 16 per cent adverse pregnancy outcome in the control group of 114 pregnancies. The conclusions say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this does not enable us to state that there is a relationship between VDU operation and these obstetric problems. These figures however indicate that there is more than a 95% chance of there being a connection between VDUs and miscarriage.

In a further study, Alison McDonald and her colleagues from the Institute of Research in Health and Safety of Workers, in Quebec, reviewed 104,620 pregnant women who were classified into 42 different occupational groups. For non-VDU users, the average rate of miscarriages was 5.7 per cent. The rate of miscarriages for VDU workers ranged from 8.2 to 45 per cent. The length of time each spent in the vicinity of a switched on VDU appeared to be an important factor.

PARA.TAB: I think it is important to continue with a couple more examples. In May 1986, Ulf Bergqvist presented a paper at an international conference on work with VDUs in Sweden. The paper summarised reports from seven different international epidemiological studies on adverse pregnancy outcomes. Collectively, this involved 27,500 VDU workers. The average miscarriage rate of these VDU workers rose to 52 per cent compared with a 10 to 20 per cent miscarriage rate amongst the local population of non-VDU users.

In a Swedish study, 4,117 female clerks at social security bureaus were split into five groups ranging from those with no VDU exposure to those exposed to VDUs for a maximum of not more than 15 hours per week. This study concentrated on birth deformities in children. It does not include any details on the numbers of women who suffered miscarriages, nor does it include any details of stillbirths. However, group B, which comprised 412 women who used VDUs for not more than two hours a day, had a 100 per cent increase of significant birth malformations over the expected numbers.

Rather than read to the Senate the other results, which are quite detailed and significant figures, I will summarise them. Of the two groups, A and B, which used VDUs for a maximum of two or three hours daily respectively, the actual incidence of deformed babies was four times higher in group A, and 5 1/2 times higher in group B, than that of non-VDU users in the population as a whole.

That is the sort of information that is presented in this research paper. It has a series of recommendations including that we should not be complacent or apathetic about what is a serious risk to the health of ourselves, the people who work for us and the population at large. A very important part of that population is the considerable number—and it is increasing—of young Australians who are exposed to potential risks during their schooling because of the increased use of computers at school.

Having introduced this to the Senate—I also invite people to obtain copies of it from my office—I intend to pursue this matter further. I will make this report available to public sector unions, to the Department of Employment, Education and Training and to the Department of Administrative Services. I think the most useful things that should result are that this research be considered seriously, that it be aligned with the research which the minister has told us about, and that we all re-assess the way in which we allow this machinery to be introduced into our offices.

At the very least, we should take a personal interest in whether there is a set of guidelines on the operation of the machinery we find in our offices. I will take it further than that. I will ask that the minister adopt the recommendations of this report or find reasons and detailed explanations as to why we in Australia should not establish new electromagnetic radiation exposure limits which are relevant to both residential and occupational standards. I will also ask that greater consideration be given to the risk of electromagnetic fields in medical research and patient treatment, and that it be mandatory that all computer monitors sold in Australia have a limit on radiation emission levels.

The labels that are on the side of the machinery in our offices, while being cryptic in one sense, are useless because we have no point of reference to decrypt whatever message is on the side. If there is an Australian limit, and if there are standards, it should be publicised widely and the meanings of the messages should be interpreted for potential users.

I think it is important that we also consider another recommendation from this research report: that the monitors that are used in classroom situations should be at a lower level. We should take a precautionary attitude to the exposure of our children and we should pursue that with greater diligence. I think it is justifiable to do that because the long-term exposures are those which are potentially of greater harm and, of course, our children will be exposed to these over a greater period than we will.

The other recommendation I would have thought would already exist. This is the trouble. We assume things and we are always disappointed when we assume things; they never apply. I assumed that there would be a compulsory labelling scheme if we had standards but that is not so. I think there should be a compulsory scheme for labelling and informing consumers how these machines comply with whatever standards we have.

The other aspect of this piece of work is that, apart from it containing reports of international research, it also goes into a balanced and sensible discussion of the whole issue of how health is related to these potential risks. I commend it to the Senate. I seek leave to table the document.
Leave granted.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO THE NEW SOUTH WALES POLICE SERVICE (ACCESS TO INFORMATION) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 12 October, on motion by Senator Schacht:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not be opposing this piece of legislation. It is our view that the legislation does serve a very useful purpose. The outline of the bill is basically that it will amend two acts: the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988 and the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. This will enable information relevant to the terms of reference of the commission to be passed to the commission.

PARA.TAB: The proposed amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act will enable agencies with the power to conduct interceptions under that act to communicate relevant information obtained under warrant—and I think it is very important to stress `obtained under warrant'—to the commission. The proposed amendments will not permit agencies to conduct interceptions expressly for the purposes of obtaining such information, so there are protections of the rights of individuals contained in the bill. Instead, they will only be able to pass to the commission relevant information which they have obtained for their own purposes in the course of conducting interceptions under warrant. We do not believe that the bill opens the way for any overbearing invasions of a person's freedom. For that reason, the coalition will not be opposing the passage of the bill today.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly. I do note for the record that Senator Spindler wanted to contribute but unfortunately I think he was delayed at another function. I thank the opposition—the Liberal and National parties and the Democrats. I understand that this legislation has the full support of the Senate. I do not wish to comment any further.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Motion (by Senator Sherry) proposed:
That this bill be now read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not in the chamber when the second reading debate went on, so I will make some comments now. It is appropriate in the view of the Democrats that the Commonwealth assist in the investigation of allegations of corruption in the New South Wales Police Service, so the Democrats welcome the Royal Commission into the New South Wales Police Service (Access to Information) Bill. The bill is essentially a means of enabling the royal commission to access certain information held by AUSTRAC and a number of law enforcement agencies. It does this by amending two pieces of legislation: the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988 and the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979.

PARA.TAB: Clause 2 has the effect of adding the Royal Commission into the New South Wales Police Service to the FTR Act as a law enforcement agency so that the director of the cash tracing agency, AUSTRAC, may authorise the royal commission to have access to specified FTR information. Clause 6 includes the royal commission as an eligible authority for the purposes of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. This allows relevant information lawfully collected under the act to be provided to the royal commission. Significantly, the bill does not allow the royal commission itself to seek the issue of warrants under the TI act, or to conduct interceptions itself. This would have required the classification of the royal commission as an `agency' rather than merely as an `eligible authority'.

There is a good argument that the royal commission should have been given the power to conduct its own telecommunications intercepts. Indeed, the royal commissioner, Mr Justice Wood, argued that telephone interception has been made available to other investigative agencies such as the Independent Commission Against Corruption, the Queensland Justice Commission and all police services, and that it should have been extended to his royal commission. Mr Justice Wood also expressed the view that the arrangement whereby the NCA does the phone tapping and passes the information on to the royal commission `is not workable in practice or in principle'. The federal government's failure to take account of these matters raises serious questions about the effectiveness of the bill.

The Australian Democrats considered introducing amendments to declare the royal commission an agency for the purposes of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. However, it was made clear to us that we would receive little support for this either from the government or from the opposition. We also considered, as an alternative, the possibility of including in the definition of class 2 offences the term `official corruption'.

On the advice we received, this may have enabled the National Crime Authority to inquire into matters of direct relevance to the royal commission, rather than being restricted to gathering information merely incidental to the work of the royal commission. However, advice from the Attorney-General's office suggested that, in order to gather information directly for the benefit of the royal commission, the National Crime Authority would need a specific reference and no indirect means of accessing information on behalf of the royal commission would suffice. Further, it was made clear to us that any amendments that had the effect of widening the scope of the bill would be rejected and this would hold up the passage of the bill. This would have effectively denied the royal commission access to the information already on the files of the National Crime Authority and other agencies and may have severely hampered the investigations of the royal commission.

We also understand that the New South Wales government has been advised that the Commonwealth government would facilitate and support an appropriate New South Wales government reference to the NCA of the matters in the royal commission terms of reference to enable the royal commission to obtain all the information it needs via NCA intercepts. The ball is therefore very much in the court of the New South Wales government and it is on this basis that the Democrats are agreeing to pass the bill in its present form.

It must also be admitted that the government's reasons for not wanting to increase the number of organisations that have the power to conduct telephone intercepts to yet another organisation carry considerable weight. The power to intercept telephone calls is arguably one of the most intrusive investigative powers available and it would appear that no royal commission in this country's history has ever been given powers to conduct its own intercepts. The view of the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr), and I understand the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) agrees, is that a precedent should not be established here. As I said, this view carries considerable weight. Yet the point remains that there have been sufficient allegations of corruption in the New South Wales Police Service to warrant the appointment of a royal commission and we must be completely confident that we have given it all the support it deserves.

Thus, while the Australian Democrats will not be moving any amendments to the bill, we wish to place on record our support for a review of the measures that this bill provides, at an appropriate time in the life of the royal commission, to ensure that the commission can effectively complete its tasks. As I said, the Australian Democrats support the bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In the absence of Senator Hill, who is overseas on parliamentary business, I will be acting in his stead today and tomorrow.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government. I presume the minister is aware that Laura Tingle spilt the beans on the government's economic policy yesterday by revealing that Mr Keating `lied repeatedly about interest rate rises throughout 1988'. As Laura Tingle is a much more impartial and objective observer than someone whom Mr Keating has claimed to have had in his pocket for years, why should the public believe anything the Prime Minister says about interest rates? In view of the 75 basis point increase in US interest rates overnight, does even Mr Keating have the temerity to rule out a higher interest rate Christmas present for long-suffering Australians?

—I have only seen press references to Laura Tingle's book; I have not seen the actual text of it and I do not know the context in which she is talking. What I have seen from the press reports, however, is that Bernie Fraser, who is in a position—
—Quite discredited.

—a much better position than Senator Alston was to know exactly what was going on and who was telling the truth about what in 1988, rejected outright those suggestions in Laura Tingle's book in the course of the launch of it yesterday. So let us hear no more about that, unless and until Senator Alston can claim some greater credibility than Bernie Fraser—and I think we will be waiting till hell freezes over before that situation arises.

PARA.TAB: As to the implications of the latest increase in official interest rates in the United States, the recent rise in US official rates was based of course on the strength and the high capacity utilisation of the US economy. It has no automatic implications whatsoever for monetary policy in Australia. That monetary policy in Australia is set according to Australian economic conditions and it will continue to be adjusted as appropriate to reduce the risk of the economy overheating over the next 12 to 18 months.

The short-term cash rates that influence mortgage rates and prime rates and everything else in this country are determined by the Reserve Bank in consultation with the government on the basis of our judgment about the domestic economic situation here and the implications of the need for appropriate adjustments in order to anticipate and to deal with the possible inflationary increases; they are not based on what happens overseas. There may be some implications, as we said yesterday, for long-term interest rates which are put together by the market, taking very much into account developments that it sees operating overseas. But for the interest rates that are within the government's capacity to manage, there are no implications whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note with interest that the minister does not deny the proposition that Bernie Fraser has in fact been in the pocket of the Prime Minister for years, on his own assessment. But I refer to the other part of the question which is even more important and that is where the minister says that there are `no automatic implications for Australia' of a further increase in US interest rates. Given that we have pretty much the highest real interest rates in the Western world, does the minister now concede that it is all the government's own work and that it has nothing to do with the American economy? Therefore, why is the government not prepared to rule out an increase in interest rates before Christmas?

—Senator Alston's references to Mr Fraser are manifestly and palpably offensive. I know he will not withdraw them if I ask him to; I know he does not have to under standing orders. But it ought to be acknowledged just how offensive and inaccurate they are, and absolutely rejected by the government. Remarks of that kind do nothing other than to demean the person who utters them.

PARA.TAB: I have nothing further to add on the subject of the interest rate situation. There is no reason to make any assumptions about the course of official interest rate policy in this country. That course will continue to be followed by the government on the same basis that we have articulated and made clear. We will adjust, as appropriate, to reduce the risk of the economy overheating over the next 12 to 18 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I refer to the major announcement made yesterday in Jakarta by the leaders of the APEC countries, a decision which has been hailed as one which will have a lasting importance for Australia's economic future. In referring to that decision, I extend my congratulations to the Prime Minister, Mr Paul Keating, for the important role that he played in the deliberations which led to yesterday's announcement. Can the minister provide advice on what this announcement will mean, specifically for Australian trade prospects in the region, and, perhaps more importantly, for the flow-on to industry and jobs growth in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Colston is absolutely correct to congratulate the Prime Minister for his substantial contribution to this very significant outcome, because the Prime Minister yesterday correctly said that it is a triumph for Australia, as did the editorials in all the leading newspapers today, which talked about Australia's triumph. The Prime Minister, also correctly, gave great credit to a number of senior and middle ranking officials in the Australian government who made an enormous contribution to making this possible.In addition, it is a very significant triumph for the Prime Minister himself and a great contribution to the economic prospects of this country. That is the important point and the point to which Senator Colston correctly drew our attention.

PARA.TAB: Under APEC free trade, we estimate that Australia's real output will rise by 3.8 per cent and real national income by 1.2 per cent or between $6 billion and $7 billion annually. Let us look at some of the areas where there is contention, because in all areas of great change, as well as tremendous opportunities, there are always some challenges. Let us look at the motor vehicle and TCF industries. Australia has one of the lowest motor vehicle tariffs in this region. The capacity of our motor vehicle industry to export competitively

ANSWER.PARA: will be very significantly enhanced by these changes. In some APEC economies, for example, tariffs on motor vehicles are well in excess of 150 per cent and on motor vehicle parts and components they are of the same order—certainly well over 50 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is that easy, why didn't you bring them down a long time ago?
—That is the great significance of APEC—that they will start to come down. That is exactly the point; thank you very much.
—You could have done that years ago.

—Nobody else ever has. This is the first time that this sort of achievement has been possible. If, for example, by the year 2010, before the developing countries in APEC have to have achieved free trade, the tariffs have proportionately come down to, say, 50 per cent, we will find that the cost of an Australian car getting into those economies will be at least $20,000 less. We are already exporting cars successfully into those economies, over tariff barriers of 100 to 200 per cent. The capacity of our industry to build on that, as we gradually, over the next years, see those tariff barriers come down, will be a very significant enhancement to our industry.

PARA.TAB: Some ignorant people are saying, `But nothing is going to happen for 20 years.' I thought I just heard one. The fact is that no country is going to sit on its hands and say, `Good, we'll wait until 2019 and then abolish everything.' What people have said is that the existing momentum for trade liberalisation in this region will be accelerated by this change. The reductions that have happened this year, for example, in Indonesia and Malaysia, will be accelerated and made more significant as a result of these changes. That is what the leaders have committed themselves to.
Australians must remember that the domestic market alone is not sufficient to ensure

ANSWER.PARA: economies of scale for industries like our TCF industry and our motor vehicle industry, because the TCF tariffs that our exporters face are once again often more than 100 per cent. The capacity of our successful manufacturers to compete in that industry is adversely affected. That is why we have seen significant increases in manufacturing output, even during the period of tariff reductions. The doomsayers will always see the challenges but there are enormous opportunities. History shows that the challenge has led to improved performance. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a chart showing the increase in manufacturing output as the effective rate of assistance for our manufacturing industry has gone down.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
