TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate.

—My question is a serious drought related question directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I ask: when will the government respond to yesterday's urgent call by the National Farmers Federation for the implementation of a national core breeding livestock retention grants scheme? Will the minister acknowledge that the drought and interest rate problems are now decimating Australia's primary industries, and when will he take a special submission to cabinet guaranteeing the preservation of Australia's breeding flocks and herds?

—I hope that the opening qualification by Senator Tambling was not meant to indicate that his other questions are not serious because all questions relating to drought are serious. The federal government has received no detailed proposal yet and, in fact, I understand from having attended the NFF function last night—
—For the drinks, not for the dinner.

—I say to Senator Vanstone that I would have stayed longer but, unfortunately, I had to come back for Senate estimates. The NFF is in the same position as the federal government. There is currently no detailed proposal. The national core breeding livestock retention grant, which is the title given, can be simplified much easier than that title. It is, in fact, a proposal for a fodder subsidy.

PARA.TAB: A press statement issued by the association yesterday said the grant would be aimed at keeping the nation's core breeding stock and herds alive during the drought. The statement was issued following a survey conducted by the NFF that showed massive destocking operations had been under way and that the national core breeding herd of sheep and cattle was under threat. The statement contains absolutely no details of costs or how the scheme would work, apart from the fact that it should be done.

There is no question at all that the severe drought in Queensland and northern New South Wales is causing significant hardship for sheep and cattle producers. There is no evidence available to me yet of any massive destocking. I receive constant updates from ABARE on what the position is nationally. I have made the point before that these figures are national figures and this association is talking about what is a national problem.

The figures indicate, as ABARE told me, the highly regionalised nature of the current drought in that the most severely impacted areas are in about 40 per cent of the state of Queensland and northern New South Wales. The latest figures that I was provided with by ABARE yesterday show that national cattle numbers—and these are assuming that the drought continues—are forecast to decline to 24 million head by March next year from around 24.6 million head in March this year. ABARE expects New South Wales cattle numbers to fall by around 450,000 head between March this year and March next year.

ABARE forecasts a fall in the total Australian sheep numbers to around 130 million head by March next year, compared with 136 million head at March this year, which reflects reduced lamb markings and higher sheep slaughter. They are the figures that have been provided in terms of the national situation. I have been briefed by ABARE on this, and ABARE has indicated to me in some detail that this is a reflection of the fact that the worst impacted areas of Australia are regionalised to this extent at this point in time.

Fodder subsidies, and that is what this proposed scheme is, are highly inequitable. One of the points made to me by a farmer last night—it is one of the huge holes in fodder subsidies, particularly when we consider the amounts of money that were being thrown around last night—
Senator Tambling interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I only have indicative figures because the National Farmers Federation has sent this proposal back to the New South Wales farmers and asked them to provide a proposal that is actually detailed so the NFF can consider it. That is the advice I got last night. So when the National Farmers Federation actually gets a detailed proposal from New South Wales to consider, I have no doubt that it will then forward that proposal to the government and we will have a look at it. One of the points made to me last night by a grain producer was that one of the difficulties in schemes like this is they do not help anyone except stock producers. (Time expired)

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the minister's acknowledgment that much of the disaster and the crisis is regionally based and regionally identifiable, how has the minister been able to look at the particular areas that are regionalised, particularly on the basis of those ABARE figures? I also ask the minister to address the second part of my question: when will he be prepared to take this matter back to cabinet and argue the farmers' case again?

—People must have cloth ears in here. I have said at least 20 times, and it has been published in most of the major rural papers, that I will be taking the next submission to cabinet on the twenty-eighth of this month. That is still on track. It has been said in question time, it has been published in most of the major national daily newspapers, and certainly in all of the rural press—the twenty-eighth of November.

PARA.TAB: I just want to repeat: I will wait until I get a detailed proposal on what New South Wales is considering. Currently, the National Farmers Federation does not even have that. It has asked the New South Wales people to actually provide that.

From the figures that I was given last night by some of the people who were involved in this proposal, it is estimated that this scheme would cost around $10 million a week, or somewhere between $40 million and $50 million per month. One of the problems with that level of resources being directed to a fodder subsidy, as some of the grain growers pointed out to me last night—not that they needed to—is that there are many primary producers in drought affected areas whose primary source of income is not stock and who would not be helped by that scheme at all. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer to the Port Hinchinbrook development in North Queensland and to the proclamations which were made last night under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act. I ask the minister: what prompted him to take this action and what are the implications for the development at Oyster Point?

—In response to Senator Reynolds's question concerning why I sought to invoke provisions of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, I indicate that my purpose in seeking the proclamation was to put a stop to the clearing of mangroves until further scientific assessment can be made about impacts on the seagrasses and other World Heritage values in the adjacent area.

PARA.TAB: Late last week my department received further information about the probable impacts on the seagrass communities of mangrove clearing on the site. As I indicated in the Senate yesterday in response to a question from Senator Kernot, I raised the matter with the Queensland government and the developer, Mr Williams. As I also indicated in my response to the supplementary question, I appreciated the need to act urgently and, based on the advice of my department and the rate of mangrove clearing, I took action to initiate a proclamation.

I took this action as a last resort after having exhausted all other options to secure a halt to mangrove clearing. The act provides that, where the Governor-General is satisfied that the World Heritage values of an identified property are being or are likely to be damaged, he may issue a proclamation in order to prevent any further damage or destruction. The Governor-General was satisfied and a proclamation was issued which came into effect last night. The developer and the Queensland government were informed by letter last night.

Turning to the second part of the question, about implications, the act specifies a number of activities which cannot be carried out by a corporation in the proclaimed area of waters. For example, a corporation cannot carry out any form of excavation, including dredging. Acts by corporations which occur outside the proclaimed area but which nevertheless damage the proclaimed area are also unlawful. For example, the current removal of mangroves from areas just adjacent to the proclaimed area and which are damaging the proclaimed area would be unlawful. At this stage the Commonwealth is relying only on provisions of the World Heritage Act based on the corporations power of the constitution. To this date it has not relied on the external affairs power.

Regulations are currently being drafted which would prevent the same activities being carried out by individuals unconnected with corporations. These regulations might also make other activities unlawful if they are likely to damage proclaimed areas. It is important to note that many of the activities which are occurring on land just adjacent to the proclaimed area and which have no effect on the proclaimed area would not be unlawful. The proclamation will remain in place until the Governor-General is satisfied that there is no longer any threat of damage to the proclaimed area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. It has been claimed that all work on the site will have to cease, and I understand that that is not the case providing that that work is appropriate in terms of protection of World Heritage values. Could the minister clarify whether all work has to stop or only work that is inconsistent?
—There is no intention to stop all work at the site, certainly only that work that will have an impact on the World Heritage value of the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage area.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. In the principal answer, the minister referred to some additional evidence and advice he had received, and he did it yesterday too. On television this morning he refused to divulge that. I wonder whether we could ask the minister to table that further evidence.
—It is not a point of order.
—But I am asking whether he would table it.
—It is a request; it is not a point of order. It is up to the minister whether he will table it or not.

—Mr President, on the point of order: that may be a true statement of the facts, but the fact is that he was requested to table a particular document. He ought to indicate whether he is prepared to do it and, if not, why not.
—I am not proposing to table any document.

—My question, too, is to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and also concerns Port Hinchinbrook. I preface my question by congratulating the minister on his courageous decision to apply a World Heritage order. I ask the minister—this may assist Senator Ian Macdonald—has he seen a leaked Queensland government report on seagrasses and the Oyster Point development, completed by the Queensland Department of Primary Industry scientists and commissioned by the Office of the Coordinator-General? Does this report say that a rare species of seagrass found in only 20 locations, all of them in Queensland, exists in two places off Oyster Point and that losses of these seagrasses must be avoided? What date was that report received by the Queensland government and what date was it received by the federal government? Finally, given that the World Heritage order was made effective at about 9 p.m. last night but that, according to media reports, lights were erected at the site and the clearing of old-growth mangroves by bulldozers and chainsaws continued until 3 a.m., are there any penalties which the developer faces under the World Heritage Properties Act? (Time expired)

—My department had access to a draft of the report that Senator Kernot is referring to in the formulation of its advice to me on this matter. The answer to Senator Kernot's second question is yes. I cannot answer the question as to when the Queensland government received that particular report. That is obviously a question properly addressed to the Queensland government and one that it would, I am sure, be able to answer. With regard to the date that I received the draft report, I can indicate that my office received an incomplete copy of the report by facsimile on 9 November 1994. I understand that my department received a complete copy of the draft report on either 11 or 14 November. I can have that point checked for Senator Kernot and I will provide that information to her as soon as I receive it.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the final part of Senator Kernot's question, my understanding is the World Heritage Act does not contain criminal penalties. Once the proclamation was made, various activities in relation to the site were made unlawful.

This proclamation was drawn to the attention of those who were working on the site, and I understand that the work then ceased. If unlawful activity were to commence or recommence, then it would be open to the Commonwealth to seek an injunction stopping the activities. If a corporation were to act contrary to such an injunction, then I assume it would be in contempt of court.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What time was the developer informed? Was the developer not informed until 3 a.m.? Because I understand that work went on under lights, specifically, until at least 3 o'clock this morning?

—The proclamation was gazetted at around 11 o'clock last night and the developer was informed after that. I will establish for Senator Kernot a precise time in relation to the cover sheet on the fax when that was provided.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What is the current situation in the Gulf following the withdrawal of Iraqi troops to their pre-crisis positions? What is the Australian government's reaction to the Iraqi government's recent decision to recognise formally Kuwait's sovereignty and international borders? Will this lead to the lifting of UN sanctions against Iraq?

—As to the current situation in the Gulf area, as is well known, Iraq has now withdrawn all its troops to their pre-crisis positions, and in that sense the immediate military threat to Kuwait is now over. I note that the United States has announced that it will begin to withdraw some of its forces from Kuwait from the end of this month. However, the US and the United Kingdom have warned Iraq that, should it attempt to reinforce its military capacities below the 32nd parallel, they will consider military action.

PARA.TAB: The US has also announced that it will continue to preposition military equipment in Kuwait, particularly `Warthog' anti-tank aircraft. The Australian government, of course, strongly supports UN Security Council Resolution 949 adopted on 15 October in response to the movement of troops by Iraq towards Kuwait. That condemned the recent military deployments, demanded that Iraq not threaten its neighbours or UN operations in Iraq, and demands that Iraq cooperate fully with UNSCOM, the UN Special Commission.

As to the implications of the recent announcement by the Iraqi Parliament and the Revolutionary Command Council that it formally recognises Kuwait's sovereignty in the internationally demarcated border, our reaction is this: the announcement is certainly a step in the right direction and indicates, I hope, a realisation by Iraq that cooperation with the Security Council rather than threats of military action against Kuwait is the only way to achieve the lifting of sanctions.

However, the announcement is not enough in itself to warrant the lifting of sanctions, as the Security Council itself decided a couple of days ago on 14 November. Iraq still needs to fulfil all remaining aspects of the Security Council resolutions, including the return of missing Kuwaiti prisoners of war and Kuwaiti property stolen during the Gulf War and the payment of reparations for damage caused by the 1990 invasion.

Iraq must also maintain its cooperation with the UN Special Commission, the body charged with overseeing the identification, destruction and ongoing monitoring of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction capacity. The lifting of sanctions has to be dependent on Iraqi compliance with all its obligations under UN Security Council resolutions.

While not specifically linked to the lifting of sanctions, Iraq must also comply with the UN Security Council resolution 688 of 5 April 1991 which demands that Iraq discontinues its repression of minorities, particularly the Shiites in the south of the country and the Kurds in the north. I repeat that the recognition by the Iraqi government is very welcome, certainly a step in the right direction, and we very much hope that Iraq will take the further remaining steps that are necessary to enable, in effect, its return in full to the international community.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer him to the proposed pre-Christmas national strike by the Transport Workers Union being discussed in Melbourne today. Does he accept that such a strike would have a devastating effect on Tasmanian families which, because of their isolation, could face a Christmas deprived of family reunions and traditional Christmas groceries? Will his government publicly condemn this pre-Christmas strike and make it clear to the TWU that it is unacceptable and un-Australian?

—What we would make clear to the TWU is that it should abide by the new wage bargaining system which allows for enterprise wage bargaining. The legislation, of course, also allows industrial action after a mandatory cooling down period. Of course the government would not encourage the union to pursue its industrial claims by way of strikes that would affect not only Tasmanians but anyone else. We expect the union to follow those guidelines in accord mark 7 and abide by the new Industrial Relations Act.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the minister give an assurance to Tasmanian families and tourism operators that his government will take the necessary steps towards ensuring that Tasmania is exempted from any national Christmas strike by the TWU?

—What I indicated—I do not know whether Senator Calvert was listening—was that any transport strike would affect anyone in Australia. Our preference would be for the enterprise wage bargaining process to be taken to its finality without resort to industrial disputation. But the current Industrial Relations Act allows, after a mandatory cooling down period, strike action.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Mr Lyndon La Rouche and Mr Webster Tarpley

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The American extremist Lyndon La Rouche was recently released from prison on parole after serving five years of a 15-year sentence; and part of his sentence was for fraud and tax evasion. I ask the minister whether Mr La Rouche has applied for a visa to Australia and, if so, has the visa request been granted? I also ask the minister about the visa status of an associate of Mr La Rouche—Mr Webster Tarpley—and whether Mr Tarpley is permitted to participate in political activities while in Australia?

—I can say to Senator Jones and to the Senate that my department has no record of Mr Lyndon La Rouche applying for a visa to visit Australia. Given his criminal record—I believe he was sentenced to imprisonment for some 15 years in 1989 for scheming to defraud and for default of payment of more than $US30 million in loans—I am advised that it is very unlikely that he would be successful in meeting the requirements for the grant of a visa as set out in the Migration Act and regulations. With respect to Mr Tarpley, I am informed that he was granted a tourist visa in Washington on 7 November 1994. He arrived in Australia on 11 November. With respect to him, I can say nothing more than that we expect people on tourist visas to undertake activities of a recreational nature. People undertaking political or promotional activities are normally expected to apply for other visas. Of course, Senator Jones, we will take any implication in your question on notice for further assessment.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. People with haemophilia are continuing to experience a critical shortage of blood products. For example, all elective surgery in New South Wales has been cancelled since September. In Queensland, only essential surgery has been possible for the last six months. Western Australia will provide surgery on only a very restricted basis. And yesterday in Melbourne a preventative program for 12 children was cancelled because of the lack of blood products. In view of the fact that the government refuses to acknowledge the current crisis and fund a recombinant product resolving the situation, can the minister deny that she is turning her back on this small group of people who have a disorder through no fault of their own?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question, as I understand it, mainly goes to the challenge of—could I make it clear whether Senator Herron is referring to mainly blood products for haemophiliacs?
—Yes.
—I thank the senator. I have here an answer that refers to a report which raises issues of historical—
—I got an answer four weeks ago that did not address the subject.

—Yes. There is a report which talks about the challenge and the difficulties that are being faced. It is very negative and keeps referring to earlier times when matters relating to blood contamination caused problems and difficulties in the area of blood products across the world as a whole.
—That is the wrong answer.

—Senator Ferguson will find it is not, if he just waits a moment. Since that time, technology has been introduced, new standards have been required and the best possible action has been taken to ensure the maintenance of quality, safety and efficacy of the products concerned. Blood plasma now brought into Australia for contract fractionation by CSL on behalf of other countries is not pooled.
—You have the wrong brief.
—I will speak when Senator Patterson is quiet. All plasma fractionation by CSL is subject to strict therapeutic goods administration control under the Therapeutic Goods Act.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The answer has no relevance at all to the question that I asked. I would be happy to ask the question again so the minister can get the correct brief.
—Senator Crowley, do you wish to speak on the point of order?
—It is a bit of both, Mr President. This is the answer provided to me to deal with this matter.
—Irrespective of the question?
—No. The matter refers to whether or not CSL is sufficient, and it does pick up on previous programs.
—That is hopeless.
—No, it is not, and I will continue the answer.
—Mr President, on the point of order: is the point the minister is making that Senator Herron is out of order because he failed to ask the right question?
—That is an interesting conundrum, but I am certainly not in the position to make fine judgments about haemophilia.
—I say by way of continuing my answer that the Secretary-General of the Red Cross, Mr Jim Carlton, a former federal health minister, stated recently:

ANSWER.PARA: We are perfectly satisfied that the contribution that CSL makes to the quality of the blood supply in Australia was good enough for us to go into partnership with them.
As I understand it, the question concerns whether or not there is a sufficient supply of blood products, in particular Factor VIII, to deal with the needs of haemophiliacs in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—I beg Senator Herron's pardon. I ask him whether he would like to again put the question to me.
—That answer was a farce. It had nothing whatsoever—
—Put your question.
—My question was about haemophiliacs, a recombitant factor and 500 children who are being denied access to this recombitant factor. It had nothing whatsoever to do with—
—Ask your question.
—I am asking it. If Senator Cook listened and cleaned out his ears, he would hear the question. It is about recombitant Factor VIII and nothing else.
—In the light of what I have here and what Senator Herron has asked, I suggest that I do have something which will assist him, but I will take the question on notice and come back to him later.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask: have the recent tensions and disturbances in East Timor affected Australian aid projects there? Are aid personnel under any threat or danger from any anti-Australian feeling? Have any of Australia's aid personnel been directly affected as a result of the violence which has taken place? What measures has the Australian government taken to ensure the safety of all Australians presently working in East Timor, including the possibility that they may need to be relocated if the situation further deteriorates?

—I am advised that all personnel, including Australian nationals and their families, associated with Australian aid projects in East Timor are safe, although a Filipino employed by one of our projects was slightly injured in a disturbance at the Turismo Hotel on Sunday when rioters thought he was Indonesian. Fourteen Australian nationals in all—consultants and their family members—are currently living in Dili. They are associated with three projects: the East Timor water supply and sanitation project, the eastern islands veterinary services project and the regional planning project.

PARA.TAB: The Australian embassy in Jakarta has maintained close and regular contact with the Australian project team leaders in Dili since the civil disturbances commenced on Saturday. Indeed, some of our on-the-spot information concerning the situation in Dili has come from them.

The decision as to whether the aid personnel should stay or leave was left to the judgment of the project leaders, who are really in the best position to assess the risks. That remains the case. As a precautionary measure, though, some Australian project personnel and their families, including some deemed as possibly at risk given the ethnic nature of the violence to date—as they are either non-Timorese Indonesian or South-East Asian—elected to leave Dili until the situation improves. Three of them flew with their families to Kupang in West Timor yesterday and are staying with aid personnel there; another has gone with his wife to a conference in Bali.

The aid personnel themselves who have gone to Kupang are planning to return to Dili tomorrow, but this, of course, will be subject to the security situation prevailing at the time. Other Australian personnel were either already out of the province or elected to stay. The personnel who remained in Dili have been staying in accommodation assessed as safe, but are taking normal precautions and staying away from potential trouble spots.

As I indicated in my answer to Senator Bourne on Monday, the origins of the current disturbances appear to have been predominantly ethnic tensions between East Timorese and Indonesians from other parts of the archipelago. There has been no identifiable anti-Australian feeling manifested in any of the disturbances to date. We will, of course, be continuing to monitor the situation closely and take any necessary steps to ensure the protection of Australian project personnel.

I should perhaps take a moment to bring the Senate up to date on the current overall situation in East Timor since my answer on Monday because there appear to have been two further significant demonstrations at the East Timor university—one on Monday and another one yesterday. In the first, up to 600 students clashed with security authorities after the authorities tried to detain some students on the campus. Yesterday, a smaller group of perhaps 300 pro-Fretilin students demonstrated at the university, but it appears that there were no clashes with the security forces on this occasion.

We have no information which indicates that there were any serious injuries, let alone fatalities, at either of those demonstrations. Again, it must be said that the security forces do appear to have acted with restraint. As for the approximately 80 people arrested at disturbances over the weekend, I understand that the ICRC—the Red Cross—sought and was granted immediate access to them.

The situation in East Timor still appears to be volatile. We can all only hope that it will soon calm down; that the Indonesian authorities, in the meantime, will continue to show restraint. Similarly, might I add that I hope that no-one, including representatives of the international media allowed to visit the province, will do anything deliberately to provoke any further deterioration in the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. Could the minister please explain to the Senate why the drug calcitriol costs women $16.20 and men $104 for the treatment of the same disease?
—I have no way of being able to answer that on behalf of the minister. I will get an answer for Senator Knowles at the end of question time.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Not only does this minister represent the minister for health, but this minister is also a medical practitioner herself.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook, go and play elsewhere. Why does this minister, as both a minister and a medical practitioner, not know the answer? Why will this government not recommend to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee that men with osteoporosis receive the same benefits and the same drugs as women? Why is there such discrimination?
—I will see that that is included in the answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I, too, ask in relation to the Hinchinbrook Channel issue: how much damage has been done to the mangroves and the surrounding areas? How is the minister going to investigate the extent of the disturbance to the World Heritage values? What took the minister so long to act, since it was five days ago that he was made aware that bulldozers and chainsaws were threatening the mangroves and that protesters were being arrested? Is the minister going to review his processes and procedures in the light of the fact that he may well have been too late? Will this be a sad but salutary lesson?

—My responsibility in relation to this area is, as I have said, the protection of the World Heritage values of Hinchinbrook Channel. When the area was nominated for World Heritage Listing, the nomination specifically referred to the importance of seagrasses. Seagrasses are not abundant on the Great Barrier Reef—the reef, of course, is dominated by coral—but they are a very important food source for animals such as fish, turtles and dugong. In the Hinchinbrook Channel there are extensive seagrass beds which are important feeding grounds for these fauna.

PARA.TAB: When my department became aware of evidence that the clearing of the mangroves was likely to have a significant adverse impact on the seagrass beds, which form an integral part of the World Heritage values, it put a recommendation to me. The department was satisfied that there was sufficient scientific information for us to conclude that a proclamation request to the Governor-General would be successful. The gist of the recommendation was that I should secure a halt to clearing to allow a consensus of scientists and marine managers to be developed. I have acted on that recommendation.

Having now secured a proclamation, the best way forward is to hold a round table discussion, as suggested, as quickly as possible in order that our expert scientists can develop a consensus situation. I have worked closely and cooperatively with the Queensland government in relation to this development. I expect that sort of cooperation to continue.

As I have made clear, my responsibility and obligations, as the federal minister for the environment, are to protect the World Heritage values of the channel. That is the approach I have consistently taken in relation to this matter and that is how I have acted. When the advice became available, I can assure Senator Chamarette, I acted extremely promptly upon it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I appreciate the minister is under pressure to act, but my question was when and how he will be able to investigate the impact of the current destruction. I do not dispute—as some others do—that the minister had sufficient evidence before he endeavoured to secure a halt. My problem is that, unfortunately, he did not call a halt and the damage went ahead. Instead of protecting, he has, in reality, failed to protect the area because he was not able to prevent the destruction of the mangroves and then, presumably, the destruction of the World Heritage values attached to the seagrass beds.

—I have to say to Senator Chamarette that that is an absolutely preposterous conclusion for her to draw. I have indicated in this question time the course of action I have taken, when I have taken it, why I have taken it and the sorts of processes that I see proceeding from today. I really cannot make it any clearer to Senator Chamarette than I have in my answer to her question and in answers to other questions in relation to this issue that have been asked of me in the chamber.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and also relates to Port Hinchinbrook. Did Valentine not report to the minister on 12 August about this problem with mangroves and seagrass? If that is so, why did the minister not do something about it then if it is such a serious problem? Is it not also a fact that in the tripartite agreement—which he had for some three months, I think, and Mr Goss delayed signing for three weeks so that the minister could look at it—this problem was again identified? If it is so serious, why did he not do something about it before last night? Why did he wait until all the mangroves had been cleared from the area before he took any action? Does this show that it is not really a problem and he is just grandstanding to the green movement? If it is a problem, why did he not do something about it before when he was warned about it by Professor Valentine and others?

—I have indicated to Senator Ian Macdonald and other senators in this question time the processes that have taken place in relation to this matter. It is true that my portfolio commissioned a report from Mr Peter Valentine into the issue of the World Heritage values of the Hinchinbrook Channel. As a result of that report being made available, certain conditions were placed upon the developer and the development, particularly in relation to the dredging of a channel through the seagrass beds, which was in fact in the World Heritage area, as the honourable senator would be aware. The boundary of the World Heritage area is the mean low-water mark of the Hinchinbrook Channel. The proposal for this marina development was to see a channel dredged.

PARA.TAB: As a result of the information made available by Mr Valentine in his report, which went to World Heritage values and identified the need for baseline assessments to be made so these impacts could be established, a number of baseline studies have been undertaken. As Senator Macdonald would probably know, there is a requirement that no dredging of the channel take place until those baseline studies have been concluded which go to the issue of not only seagrass but also turbidity and water quality. Those processes are under way.

The seagrass study has been completed, but there is an issue in relation to the impact of the clearing of the mangroves on the seagrass and hence the World Heritage values of the channel. There also is an issue as to the nature of the clearing that was undertaken by the developer without a proper level of control, which also can have an impact on the channel and those World Heritage values. I have tried, even for someone as thick as Senator Macdonald, to explain the processes that have operated in relation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, do I need to take the point of order? It is abundantly clear that he is out of his depth but he does not have to resort to personal abuse to make the point.
—I withdraw.
—The minister has withdrawn. You could not have made the point better but you did not have to make it.

—I took action in relation to this matter based on the assessments and the recommendations of my department. This in turn was based on the baseline studies conducted by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and other independent scientific assessments that have been made available to my department recently. The assessment in relation to those matters was made available to me. The departmental advice was made available to me late on the evening of Monday of this week.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister completely avoided the question. Professor Valentine was not the only person who warned the minister of this—other people in this chamber asking questions of the minister have raised this issue. If it is so serious, why did the minister not act before this? Further, can the minister table or advise us of the additional evidence which he says he has received in the last couple of days? He has been asked for this publicly on television and he has been asked for it here; he has completely avoided it. The implication is that he does not have it and that he has simply made it up to try to overcome his own incompetence in dealing with this particular matter.
—I have indicated that the advice that was provided to me was determined on the basis of the Queensland DPI baseline studies, as well as other independent advice made available to the department.
—Tell us about them.
—I am telling you about them.
—Give us some names.

—I can give Senator Macdonald plenty of names, if he likes. The first report, as I have mentioned, was the one from the Queensland Department of Primary Industries. There has also been advice from Dr Preen, who is a research fellow at James Cook University. That became available recently. The point about this advice is that it has come into the possession of the department in recent times. As a result of that advice, this particular action has been taken.(Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The forecast for business investment in 1994-95 at the time of the last budget in May was for growth of 14.5 per cent. The September quarter Access Economics investment monitor released recently also implies strong investment growth. Can the minister inform the Senate of the outlook for investment in light of recent economic data and private sector forecasts?

—I thank Senator Foreman for his question. As the Treasurer said yesterday, the fact is that the Australian economy is going exceedingly well. We are witnessing a high quality recovery in the Australian economy. Overall, GDP grew by 4.3 per cent in 1993-94, which was close to the highest of any country in the OECD. This week's Economist magazine contains a table on page 126 which calculates the average of the forecasts of a group of international economists for each of the 15 OECD countries under review. It is a forecast of what the experts think, in other words. That poll shows that the country with the highest average forecast for economic growth for both this year and 1995 is Australia. Those forecasts for Australian growth are considerably below what some Australian economists have observed is presently occurring in Australia and what is likely in the new year. I draw attention again to the ANZ Bank's forecast.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. In a spirit of goodwill we will give the minister leave to have that page from the Economist magazine incorporated in Hansard so that the people of Australia can see the inflation forecasts and the balance of payments forecasts as well.
—It is up to the minister whether he wants to do that.

—It comes terribly badly at the end of a sitting day when those opposite have to resort to that sort of thing. I also draw attention to the ANZ Bank forecast that GDP growth is currently around 5.5 per cent. The quality of this growth is very robust. It is a very robust growth picture. With regard to the low inflation rate—and the question of inflation has been raised—Australia is going through a sustained period of low inflation. We are experiencing that and locking it in as a permanent feature of the Australian economy. Jobs growth is coming on strongly accordingly. Australia's inflation rate has been brought down by this government from about 12 per cent in 1983—
—Show the Australian people how our unemployment rate is the highest in the free world.

—Since Senator Campbell is interjecting, I remind him that the last coalition government delivered to this country an inflation rate of 12 per cent before it went out of office. The current inflation rate in Australia is 1.9 per cent under this government. That low level of inflation is now a permanent feature of the Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: Moreover, the 1.9 per cent inflation level to which I have referred compares extremely favourably with levels in the rest of the industrialised economies of the world. We have faster growth and have been experiencing economic recovery for longer than they have. What is more, the percentage CPI price rise forecasts in the Economist poll, which is one of the points that the interjectors have taken up, show Australia with average or below average inflation levels for 1994 and 1995. The forecasters see Australia meeting its self-imposed target of keeping inflation at two or three per cent over the period of the cycle.

On the jobs front, the Australian economy has produced over 300,000 jobs in the past year. Record numbers of people are now in employment, and the unemployment rate is steadily declining—something that all Australians should be pleased to see. Furthermore, the indicators show that this will continue. The ANZ job vacancy index is now 41 per cent higher than it was a year ago.

Now that I have shown that the economic picture is extremely positive, let me turn to investment. As a consequence of these fundamental factors, business confidence has improved considerably. Rising corporate profits, reduced debt levels and higher rates of capacity utilisation all point to strong investment. The Access Economics investment monitor confirms this assessment. It shows the total value of investment projects ranging from possible to under construction increased by 4.3 per cent in the September quarter. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the table that the minister referred to.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Herron this day, relating to blood products unsed in the treatment of haemophilia.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crowley gave me a non-answer to the question I asked about haemophilia. I referred specifically to haemophilia. That was in my question and, if Senator Crowley cares to read the Hansard, she will see that that is what I asked. I should inform Senator Crowley that Factor VIII, which I referred to, is one of the proteins in the blood which enables blood to clot. People who have absent or reduced amounts of Factor VIII in their blood suffer from haemophilia.

PARA.TAB: This condition results in spontaneous bleeding, often more than once a week, into muscles and joints causing chronic deformity. Haemophiliacs also bleed as a result of injury, surgery, teeth extraction or trauma. Treatment is given in the form of Factor VIII concentrate. Factor VIII is extracted from plasma collected by the Red Cross blood transfusion service either through whole blood donations or through specific plasmapheresis programs.

At the health minister's meeting in June some acknowledgment was given towards recognising problems of recurrent shortages of Factor VIII in Australia. The matter was referred to the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council working party to consider if and/or how additional amounts of Factor VIII could be supplied, distributed and funded. There appears to be tension between federal and state health departments regarding this funding. The paradox is that this working party will report to AHMAC in March next year. That was the minister's response. The Haemophilia Foundation today produced a booklet titled Crisis Point in Treatment of Haemophilia in Australia. There is a crisis today in the treatment of haemophilia in Australia.

In my question I pointed out the delays that are occurring. I pointed out that in Melbourne yesterday 12 children had their preventive treatment stopped. This treatment, which involves being given an injection twice a week, is needed to stop bleeding in the joints—the knees, ankles and elbows. This will be an intolerable problem for them. The destruction of joints will occur unless they are given preventive treatment.

But the preventive treatment has stopped, because the government has done nothing about this. It has known of the problem since June this year. I asked a question in October. I gave the government notice three weeks ago, and nothing has occurred since. The minister has been approached and we have been given the same stonewalling, idiotic response. That response is not as idiotic as the one I was given today, because today's answer was just a farce. The minister read from a piece of paper that had no relationship at all to the question that I asked. I do not want to dwell on that.

There is a crisis in relation to haemophiliacs today—not December or next March. It is not a recurring problem. The minister said, `Oh, this is a problem that occurs every year.' It is a problem. It is an increasing problem because the number of blood donors has decreased in recent times.

The minister also said that we were up with world standards. We are up with the standards of Czechoslovakia and Poland, but not with those in England, the United States or Canada. The Haemophilia Foundation's information sheet says:

SPEECH.PARA: For this reason all people with haemophilia in Canada now have access to high purity factor VIII concentrates. All people in the United Kingdom with haemophilia and HIV are treated with high purity products.
The recombinant factor that I was talking about is artificially produced; it has no plasma at all. But I was given a stupid answer from the other side about it having something to do with plasma.

PARA.TAB: Obviously, the minister did not understand the difference between recombinant factors and did not understand about monoclonal antibodies. It is alleged that she was a medical practitioner. She was a medical practitioner 20 or 30 years ago perhaps. I do not blame her for that; it is very difficult to keep up with the latest advances. But surely to heaven there is some medical practitioner in the department of health—even Dr Geraghty might have known, although he is out of touch, too—with some knowledge in this area.

I am speaking on behalf of the Haemophilia Foundation of Australia and on behalf of the 500 children around Australia affected by this program. It is no good saying, `We will report in March next year.' The damage to those children's joints will have occurred by then. Something has to be done and it has to be done urgently because this is a problem affecting more and more children.

Hopefully, the television and newspaper coverage of the press conference today will make the public aware of this problem so that the incompetence of the minister in the other house and the incompetence of the department will be brought to light. I hope it is, because then something might be done for these people who are in urgent need.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support the remarks of Senator Herron today with regard to the disastrous situation for haemophiliacs because of the shortage of Factor VIII. This has been an issue now for nearly 12 months. For nearly 12 months the Haemophilia Foundation has been trying to get a foot in the door of the office of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) but has been unable to get a fair hearing on this issue.
—No-one can get to see her.
—No, as Senator Newman says, no-one can get to see her. I thought that the present minister might have had some sympathy for these families and these children—
—Why?

—I thought she presented the image in the media of being concerned and so on. I thought, when the change of ministry occurred with this portfolio, that at long last this important issue might get some attention. But no, things have not changed.

PARA.TAB: As long ago as April, I raised this issue by writing to the minister and drawing to her attention the dreadful impact that this shortage was having on haemophiliacs. The matter had been drawn to my attention by constituents with two children suffering from this particular disease. But this shortage of blood products has been going on since before April and still nothing has been done. The shortage of this important clotting concentrate, Factor VIII, has been a national problem at least since that time.

It is therefore time that the government took some action. As I said, the Haemophilia Foundation, going back to early this year, was seeking some redress from the previous minister and subsequently sought attention from the current minister on this issue. Yet it is still being ignored. As Senator Herron said, without this very important Factor VIII synthetic treatment for haemophilia, children suffer extensively. They have a very painful life without it and there is the need for surgery and other difficulties.

It is now more than 12 months since the Haemophilia Foundation first raised this issue. In fact, it goes back to about September or October of last year. But still the problem goes on. Nothing has been done and nothing is being done, yet the government has responsibility for the people suffering in these particular circumstances.

There is a need for both an increase in funding and also, obviously, an increase in supply of the important Factor VIII clotting concentrate. The product is available from overseas sources, and yet there is no ready access to it in Australia as a direct consequence of this government's failure to recognise the problem and its consistent refusal, as I said, to respond to the requests of the Haemophilia Foundation on behalf of the 500 children to whom Senator Herron referred. As a result of this shortage, clinicians are being forced to use basic maintenance therapy, which is an inadequate treatment for this problem which so many children suffer. So again we find that children suffering from haemophilia are not able to lead a normal life.

If this product were made available to these children in the quantities required, they would be able, despite suffering from haemophilia, to lead a normal life. It is very similar, of course, to the treatment which sufferers from diabetes have readily available to them so that they are able to lead a normal life. The same situation applies to haemophiliacs with regard to Factor VIII. It is simply the shortage of this product which is restricting their capacity to lead a normal life, to which they are entitled.

I think it is time that Senator Crowley, as the representative of the minister in this chamber, took this issue up and did not simply talk to the minister about it but demanded that the solution that is readily available be provided so that these children do not continue to suffer in the way that they have been suffering now for more than 12 months as a result of the neglect and the lack of care of this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make just a couple of points. I notice that Senator Alston rose in the course of question time today to suggest that personal abuse was not a very smart way of answering questions or playing politics. I would like to ask the two senators opposite to reflect on the amount of personal abuse they have passed over the chamber.
—You are outrageous.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! Senator Chapman, you will withdraw that comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, there was no reflection on—
—Senator Chapman, you will withdraw the comment.
—I withdraw.
—Thank you. Take a seat.
—Which comment are you referring to?
—You have withdrawn it; take a seat.
—He is a great thick boofhead.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I would appreciate it if the minister would detail the way in which she was subject to any personal abuse by either Senator Herron or me. We did not refer to her personally in any way, shape or form. We referred to the neglect of the minister and the neglect of this incompetent government.
—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: when Senator Chapman was talking about clots, he was talking about blood clots and was not referring to the minister.
—The word that I asked him to withdraw related to being outrageous; it had nothing to do with clots.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: when Senator Chapman rose, the minister at the table made a highly unflattering comment about Senator Chapman. I ask you to ask him to withdraw that comment.
—I did not hear any comment.
—I did say `the great thick boofhead'. It was thoroughly deserved but entirely unparliamentary, so I withdraw it.
—Take action against him.
—This is a very serious matter.
—Order! The honourable leader has withdrawn.

—If Senator Crowley thought that was some sort of abuse, I apologise. I am sorry for her if she believes that is abuse. I think it is a sad reflection on herself that she considered it so. But if she considers it abuse, I apologise to her.
—Order! When I called Senator Crowley, I presumed that she was going to speak on the motion that was before the chair. If she wishes to speak again, she requires leave.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I would like to ask you how long the word `outrageous' has been unparliamentary. When was that ruled on last? Or are you ruling it is unparliamentary from now on?
—As far as I know, it has been ruled on before.
—Further on the point of order, can I be told when it was ruled upon before, Mr Acting Deputy President?
—I will have some inquiries made to see whether it has been. Senator Crowley, are you speaking to this motion?
—Yes, I would like to continue my remarks in reply to the comments made by Senators Herron and Chapman to take note of an answer.
—She has already done it.

—No, I have not, actually. The point that I was making during question time, and it is a point that is picked up by Senator Herron, is that over the last few years we have seen a reduction in the amount of blood collected in this country and a reduction in the amount of products previously made to treat haemophiliacs by fractionating blood. I would like the record to note that Senator Herron nods in assent with what I am saying.
—I said that in my speech. I can only agree with myself.

—Absolutely. That is the answer that I was referring to. The interesting point is that we have had the AIDS scare in all blood supply places around the country, which is one of the reasons why that answer was not without relevance. It is also why the relevance is that we have a reduced supply of blood in this country. The point Senator Herron makes is very important. The government, I am advised, is very aware of the difficulty and it is looking at how best to make the balance in providing—

PARA.TAB: Senator Herron interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not entirely right. A lot of the Factor VIII and other haemophiliac requirements in this country are supplied from within Australia, and with that I think he would agree. At the moment we have an insufficient supply within Australia of all the needs that come from time to time. I have been advised that over time they do level out, and at the moment we have a clearly recognised need—
—That is not true.

—What I am trying to say to Senator Herron is that there is clear recognition by government that we have a problem in providing blood clotting factors, particularly Factor VIII, to certain haemophiliacs in this country. That problem is recognised. The answer I gave before was that I would seek any further information I could provide to Senator Herron, and I will certainly do that. But it is not without relevance to the falling number of blood donors we have in this country and the capacity of Red Cross and CSL to provide blood products of that sort. Those points need to be made and taken into account.
—It has nothing to do with recombinant Factor VIII.

—No, it does not, but it does have to do with whether we are sufficient in our own supply and whether we move to making recombinant Factor VIII in our own country. The government recognises that it is a matter of the greatest concern.
—Why don't you do something about it?
—I understand Senator Herron's question and I appreciate its importance, particularly for haemophiliacs.
—It is at crisis point.

—I am merely responding to Senator Herron's comments to take note of an answer. We do recognise the difficulty. I will certainly see if there is anything further that the minister can provide to me to provide to the Senate.

—I want to raise one practical matter. The problem is very real and, as Senator Herron has said, it is a matter of crisis. A number of people, including myself and no doubt a number of other honourable senators and members, are blood donors, although in my case I regret to say that it has been rather intermittent over the last couple of years. From my experience there is not sufficient information provided by government authorities about the effect and the benefit to people of giving blood. My wife is also a blood donor and she indicates that there is no real information, even in the Red Cross centres, that is very visible about the benefit of the plasma program, which is of great importance to haemophiliacs.

PARA.TAB: The government spends millions of dollars on what I believe is useless advertising on a lot of things including, with respect, the advertising that has gone into the Year of the Family. It is advertising that seems intended only to make people feel good. I think a lot of that money, and a lot of money that is spent on useless advertising by the government, should be used to run an advertising campaign urging people to donate blood and also indicating to the people that it is important that they consider going on to the plasma program, which is of great benefit in both the long run and the short run for haemophiliacs. I raise that point for consideration by the government in support of Senator Herron's very real concerns, which I believe are shared in the chamber. I congratulate him for raising the question.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Before I call Senator Ian Macdonald, could I just mention that when I asked Senator Chapman to withdraw a word in relation to `outrageous', I was under the misapprehension that it was unparliamentary. On reflection, what I was probably thinking of was when senators here have said to other senators, `You are a disgrace.' I should not have asked you to withdraw the comment, Senator Chapman. Therefore, I do apologise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I will reinstate the comment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), to questions without notice asked by Senators Reynolds, Kernot, Chamarette and Ian Macdonald this day, relating to Development at Port Hinchinbrook Island.

SPEECH.PARA: I have move this motion because this whole Oyster Point fiasco raises three very serious questions that really need to be addressed by this parliament. The first is the sovereignty of the state of Queensland, which has jurisdiction in relation to that development. That government—the Queensland Labor government, I might stress—looked into this project very seriously. It had environmental reports done, it made all the assessments on the issue and then it gave permission for this particular work to go ahead.

PARA.TAB: What sort of message does this action of the federal government and this very inexperienced junior minister send to potential international investors in Australia? It says that they can plan, with proper authority and proper approvals, investments into major developments and then have another government and a very junior inexperienced minister come in over the top of a sovereign government and say, `All of that is finished; you must stop work.' That is a very serious question and a very serious problem for Australia as to what we are going to do with future investment in this country.

The second issue of major concern is employment. The area of Cardwell in the state electorate of Hinchinbrook has a very high rate of unemployment. The town of Cardwell for many years has languished. This development came along and is totally supported by the people of Cardwell. There have been public meetings there which have overwhelmingly supported that development. The people supported it because it provided jobs and it had been approved by the Queensland Labor government, not only on economic and building grounds but on environmental grounds as well. Because of all that, the people of Cardwell are entitled to think that this project was going to go ahead and much needed jobs were to be created.

I know that the Democrats do not have much interest in jobs and I know that the Labor Party does not have much interest in jobs either; but it is a factor that should be taken into account, particularly when this project was approved by the Queensland Labor government as a building site—as a development—and on environmental grounds.

The third element that this chamber needs to consider is this: if perchance Senator Faulkner is at last right and if the removal of the mangroves is really going to cause untold and everlasting damage to the environment or to the World Heritage values, why has it taken him until the very last moment, when all the mangroves have been destroyed, as Senator Kernot pointed out, to take any action? If it is as serious as Senator Faulkner is now telling us it is, why did he not take some action when Professor Valentine reported on this in August? Why did the minister not take some action when he had the tripartite agreement, which he had for three months, which Mr Goss held up from signing for three weeks to allow Senator Faulkner to look at it, and which clearly said that these mangroves were to go? Why did Senator Faulkner not do something about it at that time? Why did he not do something about it when Mr Haig came to see him last week with all the evidence he no doubt had? Why did Senator Faulkner not act then while there were still some mangroves standing?

It seems incredible to me that, if the matter is as serious as the minister now says it is, he did not do something about it when he had a chance to stop the mangroves being destroyed? I understand from press reports and from what Senator Kernot has said today that the mangroves were destroyed this morning at 3 o'clock. The whole lot of them are gone; they are absolutely finished. So it is great for Senator Faulkner to now put a stopper on this after they are all gone. I think this shows the shallowness of Senator Faulkner and the Labor Party on this whole issue. It shows that they are prepared to grandstand for votes where it suits them. But if they had any real interest in the environment and if it is as much of a concern as Senator Faulkner now says it is, they would have done something before. On those three grounds, I think this is a very serious matter for the chamber. It is one that the Senate should take up with greater debate. Unfortunately, our program this week will not allow that, but it is something that we really need to address.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not often that I agree with Senator Ian Macdonald, but I agree that we should be debating this for longer than we have this afternoon. I wish I knew which side of the fence Senator Macdonald is sitting on. He seems to not be able to make up his mind whether he is against the clearance of the mangroves or whether he is pro development. He really does not have that clear in his own mind. This afternoon he interjected on the minister's answers, saying, `Why didn't you act?' Then, in the next breath, he talked about stopping development and the issue of jobs.

PARA.TAB: There are three fundamental issues that the Senate should consider. First of all, the state government processes through the Office of the Coordinator-General were inadequate. As a Labor Party member, I am sorry that I have to say that but they were inadequate. Within the bureaucracy, the state coordinator-general's department did not appreciate the very sensitive nature of this development, and it was fast-tracked through without the necessary thought being given to the fact that the development abuts two unique World Heritage regions. That is most unfortunate.

There was never an environmental impact assessment. There was only an environmental review. People who do not know anything about environmental assessment processes have probably never heard of an environmental review. The first thing to acknowledge is that the coordinator-general's department did not get it right. However, Minister Molly Robson and Minister Faulkner have been working cooperatively for a number of months to try to retrieve what was not the best possible beginning to this project. I believe that both Minister Robson and Minister Faulkner have done their best to work cooperatively to try to ensure that the development would proceed and that an appropriate scale down of the project would ensure that World Heritage values were protected.

The second point relates to the question of jobs. There is no reason why ongoing jobs will not be generated by this project, but this project has to be consistent with World Heritage values. Work does not have to stop this afternoon or tomorrow morning. Jobs do not have to be lost. But it is appropriate for this unique region that the development be scaled down accordingly and that certain features of Keith Williams's development—for instance, the beach, the marina—which we are told by scientists will have dramatic impacts on the unique value of the seagrass beds and endangered species, will not go ahead as he has planned. I have to say this: one really has to doubt the credibility of any ecotourism developer who would take in the bulldozers at midnight and not finish until 3 a.m., when forced to do so by legal action. Finally, over 70 scientists have written an open letter on this subject. I seek permission to table that letter.
Leave granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Reynolds for her comments in relation to the nature of my cooperation with the Queensland government. I have worked closely with the Queensland government on all matters relating to this development, and I hope and expect that this level of cooperation will continue. There is no doubt that the Queensland government inherited a very difficult situation from the previous National Party government in relation to the approvals that were issued for this development.

PARA.TAB: My responsibilities go to the protection of World Heritage values, and it is incumbent on me to take action to protect those values where and when I think appropriate. The Valentine report drew attention to the potential impact of the development on World Heritage values but, as I said in question time, it also drew attention to the fact that there is a lack of information in relation to those impacts. That report recommended that baseline studies take place. The Queensland government agreed to a series of baseline studies, and the first of those studies was conducted by the Queensland Department of Primary Industries on seagrasses. The results of that study have only recently been made available to us and they establish for the first time that seagrasses are present in the area adjacent to the development—including one particularly rare variety. That in itself is significant new information but, in addition to that, other independent advice has been made available to the department since the Valentine report was presented to my portfolio.

I have said that this advice has been thoroughly assessed by my department and has led to the recommendations it made to me. I would reinforce the view that Senator Reynolds expressed in relation to the manner in which the developer went about clearing the mangroves. It drew attention in a very, very dramatic way to the obvious potential for adverse impacts on the adjacent seagrass beds. I believe that the comment that Senator Reynolds has made in that regard is one that will stand scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few brief comments in relation to some of the points that have been raised. I will go straight to the first issue that Senator Ian Macdonald raised—the issue of jobs.
—Sovereign risk was the first one.

—I am sorry, the second issue. There is no reason for saying that jobs will not continue if the developer is prepared to re-think the way he is doing this development. There was no reason for him to have gone in first up and cleared the mangroves. That was not the obvious need in his project development. He has done it rather provocatively. The fact that he erected lights in the evening and the early morning to enable him to continue that destruction is a continuing provocative act.

PARA.TAB: In the development debate we always hear that jobs will be lost. It is true that there are a lot of jobs in the early construction phase; there is no denying that. But I think we need to be a little more honest about the continuing jobs that exist. I know that the Cardwell Shire Council has said that there is a multiplication factor of 2.7. In time we will have to look at that and measure it.

When we heard about the space port we were told jobs, jobs, jobs. Then we found out that most of the people were being flown into the site and would be leaving again. There were very few jobs on the ground.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is still a job, though.

—Yes, it is still a job, but do not overestimate the number of jobs involved in each of these projects. Senator Macdonald is right in saying that this case is rather symbolic of the failure of processes. He drew attention to the sovereignty of the state of Queensland, and the role of the Federal government and local governments. This is something that we urgently need to sort out in this country. Phillip Toyne addresses this question remarkably well in his book The Reluctant Nation. This is one of the reasons why we have to seriously consider unravelling this huge jigsaw and starting again. We have to give the Commonwealth government an environmental head of power so that these disputations and all this blurring of the line of responsibility is not allowed to continue in this country in perpetuity.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Knowles this day, relating to osteoporosis and the drug Calcitrol.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue I raised at question time today about the drug calcitriol being so differentially priced for men and women is exceptionally serious. This drug for the treatment of osteoporosis is priced at $16.20 for women and $104 for men. It is about time the government took this whole issue back to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee to have it look at this issue again.The most important factor is that the rate of osteoporosis among men over 50 is between eight and 10 per cent. Previous research had noted an osteoporosis rate of about five per cent, with one male case to every 10 female cases. Osteoporosis, as most would know, is caused by a bone loss, leading to an increased risk of fracture. Up to 60 per cent of Australian women and 30 per cent of men over the age of 60 will suffer from that type of fracture. So we are not talking about a small number of people, we are talking about a significant number of men who are affected by this disease. Therefore, I call on the government not to treat this with distain but to treat it very seriously, look at that price differential and take it back to the PBAC.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
