SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the ANL Guarantee Bill 1994 is to ensure that ANL is able to continue to trade in an orderly fashion, especially during the restructuring process in which the company is currently involved.

On 22 August 1994, immediately following the receipt of a due diligence report on ANL which revealed the company was in a difficult financial and trading position, the Minister for Transport announced measures designed to restructure the company and provide it with the opportunity for a viable commercial future.
One of the measures taken was the appointment of a new Board with the specialised skills necessary to undertake the reconstruction task.

Another important measure was the announcement, which the Treasurer confirmed in writing to ANL, that the government intended to guarantee all existing debts of the company and any further draw-downs required on its promissory note facility.

It was recognised as critical to the reconstruction exercise and the company's ongoing operations that ANL's financiers could have complete confidence that their dealings with the company were secure and that the company's operational lines of credit should be maintained.

This legislation achieves these objectives by providing the Treasurer with the power, required to satisfy section 70B of the Audit Act 1901, to make determinations guaranteeing payments in respect of loans to ANL.
Consistent with the announcement of the Minister for Transport, it is envisaged that the exercise of these powers would be limited to guaranteeing ANL's existing debt and promissory note facility.

While the legislation does not specifically address the issue of loans to ANL from international financiers, it is intended that this legislation should also enable the provision of guarantees in respect of any such loans.
I am confident that, in underpinning the restructuring process now under way, this legislation will assist ANL to become a viable, commercial operation.
The government appreciates the important contribution an efficient and competitive ANL, and Australian shipping industry as a whole, can make to the Australian economy.

In this respect ANL will be particularly well placed to benefit from initiatives being explored by the government and the maritime unions to improve the competitiveness of Australian shipping by reducing costs and improving efficiency.
In taking such action the government is continuing to build upon the very successful program of consensus reform that has occurred since the 1980s.

The government remains committed to the development of a competitive and viable Australian shipping industry operating safe and efficient ships under the Australian flag with Australian crews and Australian award conditions.
I commend this bill to the Senate and present the associated explanatory memorandum.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Panizza) adjourned.
Consideration resumed.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—The committee is considering the Greens (WA) amendments and requests numbered A1 to A4 moved by Senator Chamarette.

DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

TALK.START.PARA: —When this debate was last before us we were speaking about the Greens' amendment to increase the amount of money in the land fund to one per cent of total government revenue. Senator Chamarette gave a rationale based on two major points. She gave her version of a government rationale based on three points and concluded that, if we did not vote for this amendment, then we would write out forever the capacity for justice for dispossession for indigenous people.

PARA.TAB: We have heard both the government and the opposition say that, in their view, such a request would impact on the deficit and on the deficit reduction strategy, and that there would be an effect on the property market. I agree with Senator Chamarette that the money is not sufficient. I do not agree with previous speakers that carrying the community with them on such decisions is one of the most important reasons to justify voting or not voting for a particular amendment. But I have heard the opposition talk at length in this place about government budget legislation and the role of oppositions and other parties with respect to the changes we should make to that. I agree with some of those comments.

However, in the long run we come down to the fundamental question, which has been raised here before, of whether this is worse than nothing. It is not worse than nothing, in my view. It is something which is not adequate—and probably never can be—but it deserves support. We need to consider that if we were not to support this, if we were to say, `Vote against it because it is worse than nothing,' we would be saying goodbye to a 10-year appropriation that is locked in. If we were to force this amendment on the committee, the government would walk away from it and we would loose the opportunity for a 10-year appropriation to be locked in. I think that is something we should consider.

While I hear the rationale and I regret that in this country we do not have the proper dialogue about how we ought to raise revenue so that more money could be available for legislation like this, and while ever we have a government and an opposition locked into the lowest common denominator approach of never addressing the question of revenue raising in this country, then it seems the political reality—

TALK.START.PARA: —What was Fightback all about?
—Fightback? Raising revenue? It was not about grappling—
—The trouble with Fightback was that there were only three people in the country who understood it.

—Yes, we all heard that about the Liberals, Senator Collins. I do not want to be diverted. We do not have in this country at the moment the sort of discussion that we ought to have about what we think is important to pay for and where we are going to get the money. Every time a government of the day raises that subject, the opposition of the day says, `They're talking about raising new taxes.' We just cannot go on doing that forever.

PARA.TAB: Because we keep going on year after year, election to election, doing that, we do not have enough money. We do not have a pool of capital to adequately reflect what we should be spending on dispossession. So that is the political reality. As I said, I do not agree that it is worse than nothing; it is something, and it is something of which Aboriginal people will make some use.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not quite finished before the suspension of the sitting for lunch. I do not want to delay the committee because I share the view around the chamber that we really do need to have this legislation dealt with before we adjourn this evening.
—Hear, hear!
—As Senator Collins would admit, there has been no delaying on this side of the chamber; we have been earnestly trying to get this through.
—How long did you speak for last time?
—I spoke for only four minutes just before lunch; I spoke for 3 1/2 or four minutes. I am now wasting time by responding to the honourable senator's interjection.

PARA.TAB: In the 3 1/2 minutes before lunch, I did not mention the effect on the deficit. Of course, that is an important matter that does affect the wellbeing of all Australians. As to the effect on the property market, I do not think that either Senator Collins or I would want to be misrepresented by someone saying that we think that some sort of adverse effect on the property market is an economically rational way of saying why we should not spend more money.

The problem with the effect on the property market is that it actually adversely affects the people for whom one is trying to buy land. If one bids up the price of pastoral leases or any other property all around the country and any property vendor or property agent gets a sniff that a few hundred million dollars are about to turn up on the doorstep, all of a sudden the prices will go through the roof. So one does need to bear that in mind, not because one is a hard-nosed economic rationalist but because one actually is humanitarian and caring about how one intervenes on behalf of people in a market that is effectively a rational one. And I think Senator Collins and I are both 100 per cent in agreement on that.

I do not think Senator Kernot is right on the backlash question. One has to understand that, unless these sorts of programs are administered properly, run effectively and achieve the objectives that I think just about all Australians would share for them, then one will get a backlash which will be counterproductive to the overall objective—and that is a matter of serious concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can show leadership though, can't you?

—One can. I think Senator Kernot is right, to the extent that it is probably impossible to overcome the problem of dispossession by using money. I think Senator Chamarette is genuinely trying to say, `Look, it is a big problem and we need big amounts of dollars to try to make a better fist of it.' But the coalition's view on this—and I have said it a couple of times—is that we have never philosophically opposed a land fund; we never philosophically opposed land acquisition within ATSIC. Senator Panizza and lots of others draw attention to maladministration and so forth, which is the proper thing to do. I do not think Senator Collins would disagree with senators of any party raising concerns about maladministration in those sorts of programs, because in the end they do assist the programs.

PARA.TAB: I concluded just before lunch talking about the observation that we are `only visiting this planet'. The reality is that all of us are only visiting this planet, and no matter how we are painted in the media or painted in our parties as being right, left or centre, there is amongst those who focus on Aboriginal affairs, regardless of their perspective, a genuine concern to do something constructive.

We all have different perspectives of how to do that. I think anyone who reflects on others' motives in that regard is not really being fair to the overall cause. I believe that the Greens' proposals in relation to funding would adversely affect the cause. With regard to whether a resolution of the issues that have been in conflict in this debate can be achieved, we have had some resolution of a number of the amendments. We have had government support for a number of the coalition amendments, which we welcome. We realise it cannot live with a number of the amendments but we have done our best to inform the parliament and the people of the reason for those amendments. The reality is that this bill can make a difference. It can achieve some of its objectives. In that respect, I hope we will have achieved something through this lengthy debate.

In relation to the amendment that is before the chamber at the moment, there is no doubt that more money may be of more assistance and that the point that the Greens are making is an important one. But I think the radical nature of the funding proposal that they have put before the chamber at the moment would actually be counterproductive. The good thing about this bill, as amended, if it can work its way into legislation at some stage in the next few months—obviously subject to a lot more work—is that it will make a difference. It will be better than what Aboriginal people have at the moment. I recommend that it be supported on that basis. To do it in this way would be very counterproductive in all of those areas that Senator Collins mentioned and that I have supported. If you do not carry the community with you, it just will not work, and it is very vital to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond briefly to the comments that have been made. Senator Collins indicated that he could not understand this. I admit that we were quite tickled to hear that Robert Tickner called it the biggest amendment that had ever been made by a minority party in any parliament in the world, a most ridiculous amendment, or something. I want to respond to some of the—
—Hyperbole.

—Yes, the hyperbole and the criticisms. The reason why I did not compare it with the ATSIC budget when I was indicating that the scale of the land fund over 10 years was nowhere near the $1 billion expended on Parliament House was that there has been quite a clear differentiation all along by the government and the Democrats that citizens' rights, health, housing, et cetera, which are covered by ATSIC are in no way comparable to a land fund. Believe me, the amount is in no way comparable, either. What ATSIC gets in one year, the land fund will not get in even 10 years in terms of the amount that is actually distributed. The amount that is actually expropriated from the so-called $1 billion fund will only ever amount to a maximum of $450 million, and that is after a period of 10 years. So there is no comparison.

PARA.TAB: Another point made by Senator Collins was that the defence budget which, as we pointed out, in one year gives what the Greens' amendment would give in 10 years, is for all Australians. Similarly, Senator Collins said that the foreign aid that we give each year, which is $1.4 billion, is for all Australians to give to people overseas about whom we have concerns in relation to their human rights and for other assistance. That, again, is for all Australians. Of course, a Collins class submarine is for all Australians. May I say that reconciliation is for all Australians. Any genuine attempt to redress the injustice of 200 years is for all Australians. I believe there are many people in the community who feel that it is perfectly appropriate and for all Australians.

I take offence to the monotonous repetition of `exclusive benefit of one small part of Australia', meaning Aboriginal people, because `exclusive benefit' for a start implies that the money that is actually going to be given is going to Aboriginal people. Well, it is not; the land is. The money is going to non-Aboriginal people—to taxpayers and people whose properties are purchased. The money that is being given, which is what the government is begrudging, is money that goes straight to non-Aboriginal people—not to Aboriginal people—to compensate them for the purchase, at market values, of their properties.

I object to the phrase `exclusive benefit'. I also object to the use of the term `one small part of Australia'. With regard to the use of the term `exclusive benefit of one small part of Australia', it is only the indigenous people of Australia to whom we are referring, only the owners of this country, whose land was taken without any recompense, without any money being given to them. Therefore, we must be very careful about our language because we might give the lie, which I think is there in ample evidence in other parts of the legislation, to the purpose which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had intended for this bill.

With regard to Senator Collins's concern that we are talking about a per capita grant, I say to him that it is very clear from the details that we gave in our statements that because there are approximately—and this is a very underestimated census, I believe—265,459 people of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander descent, according to the last census, this means they represent 1.6 per cent of the total population. What we are planning to give them is one per cent of the total government revenue which has been earned by the benefits that we have derived from their land. I could refer to a quote which illustrates how much we should be grateful for what this land has given us. The one per cent figure represents simply some kind of token rent to those people who have survived the ravages of what colonisation has done to this country.

Senator Collins tried to promote the idea that the Greens were being a bit petulant about this—that if we do not get this, we will vote the bill down. I did not say that. What I said was that the bill is a disgrace and it does not deserve support.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said you would consider voting against it.

—We are against it but we are not implying that it is simply the passage of our amendment that is critical to it. We want to see the government's rationale for the amount that it has set aside. Senator Collins did not actually give that. I think Senator Kernot was the only person who actually referred to the rationale that underlies the land fund quantity. We want to see a test of the government's credibility—whether it is willing to raise it one iota from the point it is currently at. If it remains in its current form, as we have said all along, it is insupportable. If the government is prepared to make changes, that would be its own credibility being demonstrated. It is not that the Greens believe we could get it. As I said when we presented the amendment, it is a model for which we at least had a rationale which we felt was based on justice and the restoration of justice; that it would be a positive amount that would actually meet the rhetoric of the Prime Minister when he talked about it.
—Are you going to vote against the third reading?
—The statement of the minister that I am correcting is the one he made that implied that our support for the bill is contingent on the passage of our amendment. I have said that is not correct.

PARA.TAB: Finally, the minister said that people are prepared to give it a really good go, especially the pastoralists, and that everybody is willing to support this bill; however, this amendment, if passed, would blow it out and it would not have support. I think it is because it is so negligible that it is very difficult for anybody to object. I do not agree with Senator Kernot when she said that it is not adequate but it is better than nothing. As I have said, I believe it is worse than nothing. I think that to have 10 years locked into a pittance is worse than nothing and that it is, for Aboriginal people, a matter of saying goodbye to any chance of really looking at their needs.

I will now switch to Senator Campbell's comments. He was concerned and will not support the Greens' amendments for reasons similar to those of Senator Collins: the effect on the property market, the impact that funny money might have and the distortion that occurs in property markets. While he disagreed with what I will say next, I actually think those arguments serve to prove that economics in this instance is more important than justice. He expressed that that was not his view; nevertheless, I think we have to be very careful. If the major reason we cannot increase the amount is the effect it will have on the property markets, then I think we are saying economics is more important than justice. He is also saying there will be a backlash—

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be more money going to the current owners of the properties.

—That is true, I know, but it may actually allow more Aboriginal people to gain properties than currently do, unless Senator Campbell is postulating that the inflationary effect will entirely cancel out any increase of the distribution of those funds. If we have so much expertise that is so good at predicting how it will boost the property market, surely we have sufficient expertise to get around it as well. Why can we not? Why do we have such a concern about $250 million a year being released onto the market? There must be ways of dealing with that, apart from giving almost nothing to Aboriginal people. That is the extent of the amendment that the Greens propose—an extra $250 million a year.

PARA.TAB: In a discussion I had with Mr Geoff Clark from Victoria, he talked about the amount of the fund. Every single Aboriginal group that has been talked to about this admits that this money will go nowhere across the whole of Australia. When I talked about the per capita numbers of people in Australia, I did not mention that. But if we actually divide up the amount that is currently under this legislation, it means $124 per Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander person. If we multiplied that by ten times, we would be giving them $1,000 a year for ten years. For goodness sake, how is that going to impact in any way on meeting their land needs?

I thought what Geoff Clark said was quite important because he had an alternative rationale to that of the Greens. We were going from the one per cent figure of the constitution of Western Australia, but Geoff Clark was going simply from his own community. He said, `Look, we've been thinking about how our community could get some kind of restoration of connection with land of some sort, some kind of economic base. We've worked out the minimum we could use is $2 million. We've also worked out that there's approximately 2,000 communities like ours around Australia.'

Why has the government not worked out how many communities there are—how many people it is thought do not have any land or any connection with land? Why has the government not worked it out on a smaller unit that would not necessarily scare the property market whatsoever? It would simply be giving autonomy to local communities and giving them the land fund in their hand instead of waving it around and pretending they are going to get it. It is a bit like drought relief and some other measures—it never gets into their hands.

Money is not the issue; land is the issue. The reason we are raising the amendment about the quantity of money is in order to restore the land in some kind of meaningful way to the number of people who have been dispossessed. We have to tackle the restoration of land if we are going to meaningfully work for the restoration of justice for the indigenous people of this country, and we have to work meaningfully for the restoration of justice before we can talk reconciliation. We have to be able to share. We cannot just have empty words and legislation if we are going to talk about reconciliation following it.

The government needs to stop pretending and start telling the truth, which is, `(a) we can't afford it; (b) we don't want to blow out the deficit, or; (c) if we give too much all at once, or if we give anything significant, it will blow out the property markets and won't benefit the people we intend it for.' The government can start telling the truth and say it is just going to double the ATSIC current allocation instead of setting up a $3 million dollar bureaucracy, increase the money or give the land back and keep the money. The latter option is my favourite position, which is the position put by Clarrie Issacs. He said, `Christabel, don't worry about the money. We don't want the money. Aboriginal people don't want the money. We want the land. Just give us back our land and use the money in the land fund to pay the people who you take the land from.' Now how would we get a backlash?

If the non-Aboriginal people in Australia knew that all they were going to get each year to recompense them for Aboriginal people getting back their legitimate land was $24 million extra a year, what an outcry we would have. I think that is the real message. If this government has any sincerity at all, it should be talking about land and restoration of culture to Aboriginal people. The government should give them their land; use whatever money it is prepared to put aside to that to recompense the people who may be using that land, or who might be inconvenienced by them regaining their land; and legislate to give back their land—any crown land that is vacant. If the government has any sincerity at all, it should give it back, increase the money or stop pretending to Aboriginal people that this land fund will provide anything but a pittance to a few people who are the first cabs off the rank.
Amendments and request negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: AA1.Clause 3, page 23, line 34, omit "Division 9—Staff", substitute "Division 9—Administrative expenditure and staff".
AA2.Clause 3, page 23, before proposed section 192S, insert the following section:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Expenses of day-to-day administration of the Indigenous Land Corporation

PARA.TAB: " `192SA.(1) In the first category A year, expenditure by the Indigenous Land Corporation on the expenses of the day-to-day administration of the Indigenous Land Corporation must not exceed $3 million.

`(2) In the second and any later category A year, expenditure by the Indigenous Land Corporation on the day-to-day administration of the Indigenous Land Corporation must not exceed the amount worked out using the formula:

SPEECH.PARA: Indexation factor x $3 million

PARA.TAB: where:

SPEECH.PARA: "Indexation factor" means the indexation factor for the year worked out under section 193D.

PARA.TAB: `(3) Subject to subsection (4), in this section "expenses of day-to-day administration" include:

TAB.TAB: (a)the salaries, wages, remuneration allowances, expenses or any other payments made to employees of the Indigenous Land Corporation;
(b)any expenses arising from the acquisition, lease or use of:
(i)any interest in land acquired, or leased or used by the Indigenous Land Corporation to provide office accommodation for the purposes of the Indigenous Land Corporation; or
(ii)any vehicle or aircraft for transportation, land surveys or similar purposes by the Indigenous Land Corporation; or
(iii)any plant, equipment or thing for the purposes of Indigenous Land Corporation;

(c)any fees, allowances, expenses, charges, retainers, honorariums or any other costs arising from the engagement, use or retention of independent legal practitioners, real estate valuers, land surveyors, engineers, financial or managerial advisers, or consultants of any kind for the purposes of the Indigenous Land Corporation;

(d)any costs, charges or payments of any kind to, or to an instrumentality or authority of, the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory, or to any local government body within a State, for any goods or services used by the Indigenous Land Corporation;
(e)any costs or expenses payable by the Indigenous Land Corporation arising from the creation of a subsidiary within the meaning of section 191G;
(f)without affecting section 192A, any other administrative expenses incurred by the Indigenous Land Corporation.

PARA.TAB: `(4) To avoid doubt, it is declared that expenses of day-to-day administration do not include:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)any moneys paid under a contract to a vendor for the acquisition by the Indigenous Land Corporation of an interest in land acquired for the purpose of making grants under paragraph 191D(a);

TAB.TAB: (b)any grants of money paid to:
(i)an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation; or
(ii)Aboriginal persons; or
(iii)Torres Strait Islanders; or
(iv)trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts;

SPEECH.PARA: for the purposes of section 191D;

TAB.TAB: (c)expenses directly incurred in performance of land management functions under section 191E;
(d)grants or loans for the purposes of paragraph 191E(1)(d) or (e);
(e)interest payable on any moneys borrowed under section 193L.".

SPEECH.PARA: AA3.That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Clause 3, page 25, proposed subsection 193(1), formula, omit "$121 million", substitute "$124 million".
AA4.Clause 3, page 26, proposed subsection 193A(1), line 27, omit "$25 million", substitute "$28 million".
AA5.Clause 3, page 27, proposed subsection 193A(4), formula, omit "$24 million", substitute "$27 million".
AA6.Clause 3, page 27, proposed subsection 193A(6), line 32, omit "$24 million", substitute "$27 million".
AA7.Clause 3, page 27, proposed subsection 193A(6), line 33, omit "$45 million", substitute "$48 million".

This set of amendments is another series which is, again, simply a test of credibility for this government. It is an alternative `A' series, which relates to separate appropriation for the administration cost of the ILC. These amendments provide for a separate appropriation of funds to be used by the ILC for administration.

PARA.TAB: The amendments do several things. Firstly, they provide for a separate appropriation of money to pay for the administration costs of the ILC so that it is effectively quarantined from the moneys available for land acquisition and management. Secondly, in so doing, the amendments define the types of administrative functions which are to be paid for by this appropriation, and that is a way of quarantining the costs of the administrative appropriation. Finally, the amendments make a request for the House of Representatives to vary the appropriation under clause 193 for an additional $3 million a year to pay for the administration costs.

The need for such amendments is obvious. If passed, the amendments will place a cap on the amount of money soaked up by the administrative costs of the Indigenous Land Corporation. The appropriation clause holds the government to its rhetoric that the money being made available is for the land fund and not for a duplicate bureaucracy, as Senator Campbell pointed out so clearly and forcefully earlier.

The Greens (WA) see that by proposing the amendments we are giving the parliament, particularly the government, the opportunity to show some degree of latitude over the funds being made available. By moving them, we are not walking away from our commitment to see a substantial increase in funds for a land acquisition fund. We are merely giving the parliament an opportunity to show a small degree of goodwill towards Australia's indigenous people.

We have already pointed out in our other amendment, where we tried to quarantine the amount of management funds that would be eating into this overall fund, that there would be some remaining acquisition funds to people after all the management needs of indigenous held country is dealt with. This is merely a way to prevent what Senator Campbell pointed out at the time we circulated the graph, which showed the diminishing amount of acquisition money with the administrative costs staying constant. He actually said that he thought there could well be an increase in the administrative costs. This is a way of guaranteeing there is not. This is a way of guaranteeing that at least what is eaten into of the acquisition amount of this fund of approximately $21 million this year is not going to be at the expense of the acquisition and to the benefit of the administrative costs.

That is the purpose of these amendments. I would urge all honourable senators who agreed with me that the amount of money is too small but who have also said that they do not think it is avoidable that this is one way of avoiding a minimal part of that eating into the acquisition capacity of the funds. At least in their first year they will be eaten into by the management component forever after, but we should quarantine off from it the administrative costs of setting up this new duplicate bureaucracy.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, nothing could demonstrate more the completely contradictory approach that the Greens are taking to this legislation. The Greens have been insisting throughout this debate that they want the ILC freed as much as possible from government interference. Yet this amendment says quite up front, `We cannot allow the ILC to have the same control over its administrative expenses as any other organisation. Through the parliament we will impose a completely artificial restriction on the ILC by legislating for a maximum amount of money to be spent on administration.'

PARA.TAB: The ILC has to account to parliament. The amount of money it spends on its administration is open to criticism from all. I can say from personal experience that nobody will be quicker to criticise any indigenous organisation that spends more money on administration than it should and not enough on the ground than the constituents of that organisation—the Aboriginal people themselves; they are very good at it. We only have to look at ATSIC to see the effective way in which Aboriginal organisations can manage their administration. ATSIC has a record comparable with any other organisation of a similar size in having reasonable constraints on its administrative costs. The runs are on the board. Why do the Greens want to legislate for parliament, with this blunt measure, to determine the administrative responsibilities of this organisation? It completely contradicts everything else that they have said in this debate—not that that is news, as far as the Greens are concerned.

Senator Chamarette has said consistently that she wants to free this organisation from government control. Now she wants to legislate to say that it cannot spend more than $3 million. I ask Senator Chamarette what else she has been saying it is vitally important for this organisation to do? The answer is: consult. I can tell Senator Chamarette that one of the single most expensive administrative costs for Aboriginal organisations is consultation. In pulling together one meeting of the Northern Land Council, charter costs alone are between $80,000 and $100,000. It is a very expensive business, flying around consulting people.

Senator Chamarette has moved and supported amendments to this legislation to `give priority to the most severely dispossessed people'. How can that be done without determining in the first instance who those people are? That can be done only through extensive consultation. There are already enough arguments in the Northern Territory over who the traditional owners are—who should be on the list and who should not—and those disputes, which have been running for years now, can only be properly addressed, as they are being addressed by the land councils, through extensive consultation. That consultation costs money.

Senator Chamarette has also said that this bill needs to have regard to health, housing et cetera and that the ILC has to consult traditional owners before acquiring land. Through the amendments she has proposed, Senator Chamarette is imposing very significant additional consultation requirements on this organisation which, as I know from personal experience, will be horrendously expensive to implement because of the degree of consultation that has to take place. Of course, the Greens have a fundamental position: if they can find one Aboriginal person who has not been consulted, we have to go back and do the whole thing again. At the same time, they want to shackle the organisation by putting a completely unreal legislative bar on the amount of money that can be spent. This is an absolute nonsense and the government will not be supporting it.

We believe that this organisation, like ATSIC—which, I have to say, has a commendable record on administrative expenses—should be exposed to the same scrutiny as any other organisation. It should be prudent in its administration, which I have no doubt it will be. It should have to account for how much it has spent, put that up in lights and then have people either commend it or attack it for the level of expenses that it allows.

I conclude by saying that nobody will be more rigorous in imposing control on this organisation than the people who get maximum benefit out of having most of the money spent on the ground—the Aboriginal people of Australia. They will be far more severe critics of that organisation if it goes overboard with administration than this parliament could ever possibly be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether Senator Collins could give us an idea of what the administrative costs of the ILC will be, if not in monetary terms then as a percentage of the annual expenditure?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be so speculative as to be not worth very much. I might add, that indicates the stupidity of legislating for an amount.

PARA.TAB: This is a unique organisation. It has never existed before. It has a whole set of demands to which amendments carried in this debate have added. All we can sensibly do is expect the organisation to come out with results comparable with most other organisations of a similar type.

As I have just said, why would we want to impose these restrictions when the Aboriginal organisation already established—ATSIC—which administers billions of dollars in public funding, administers it well and very accountably, already has a commendable record in keeping its administrative costs to a reasonable level? I might add that ATSIC has not been criticised even by the opposition—how could it be—for excessive administrative costs. There have been criticisms about how some of the multitudinous programs that ATSIC administers have operated in particular areas but it is a fact that its administrative costs are reasonable and within the bounds one would expect of any other comparable organisation.

We know perfectly well that this organisation will have the same limits. To put a figure on it, I would say that the government would expect that, in respect of the consultation arrangements required of this organisation, the bounds of its administrative costs would be in the same order of those incurred by ATSIC.

TALK.START.PARA: —What percentage are they?

—I do not want to be held to this but, going from my memory of previous estimates hearings, I think it is in the order of 10 to 12 per cent. The one thing I do know, because it has been debated, is that those costs are on a par with the costs of any like organisation. In other words, they are considered by all to be reasonable administrative costs.

—We think that there is some inherent benefit in what the Greens are proposing, even though we are not entirely comfortable with it. Since the Senate has agreed to go down the road of having two land funds for the next three years, clearly the administrative expenses are going to be higher than they would otherwise need to be.

PARA.TAB: Page 42 of the ATSIC annual report shows that land acquisition expenditure for the year of the report was $17.229 million. The total cost of the land acquisition program, which includes some commercial assistance, was $38 million. Of that amount, $2.4 million was for running costs. So I assume that the administrative expenses for the land acquisition programs of ATSIC would be considerably less than $2 million or thereabouts. We need to know whether the government would expect the administrative expenses of the new ILC fund to be in excess of $3 million, bearing in mind that there is $24 million of new money. We are saying that the administrative expenses would be something like 15 per cent of $3 million, which is an enormous administrative expense.

Bearing in mind that we already have a body of knowledge, expertise and experience within the land acquisition programs of ATSIC, I wonder whether it is not reasonable to say that $3 million is not an extremely broad and generous cap to have on administrative expenses. The nub of what Senator Chamarette is saying is that it is not only the capping of the administrative expense but also the fact that the Senate would be requesting a further $3 million, as I understand it, plus indexing.

The coalition is not averse to that doing that. We think it is not unreasonable. We think it is also fiscally responsible. But I just cannot understand the logic of the minister's argument. He is talking close to a 15 per cent administrative expense over and above the millions of dollars in administration within ATSIC already. I think they are important questions for the Senate to understand, and certainly for the opposition to understand, before we make a decision on this.

I also foreshadow that one of the problems we have with the amendment as moved by the Greens is that if we give bureaucratic organisations—indeed, any organisation, even if it is a private sector organisation—a cap on a budget of $3 million for administration, it will find a way of spending $3 million on administration. I suggest to the Senate that it consider putting into the proposal put forward by the Greens an incentive within the organisation for the administrative expenses to be minimised. The sort of thing we would be proposing—I do have amendments drafted to this effect—is firstly, to request that the administration seek to be efficient and minimise its cost, and secondly, to require that any savings out of the administration budget be applied to land acquisition. I foreshadow those amendments to the Greens' proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that what we have just been given?

—It probably is. I did ask for it to be circulated as an amendment. I ask the minister quite seriously whether he could address his answer to my question about whether or not he would, in his wildest dreams, envisage that administrative expenses to the ILC would be anywhere near $3 million.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed that Senator Campbell would think that whether or not that is the case is even relevant to the arguments that I put against this amendment. I am sure that on reflection Senator Ellison and Senator Campbell will agree that it is not. The answer to his question is no, I do not. All I am saying is that it flies in the face of what everyone is saying about allowing this organisation to get on with its job and not to impose unnecessary government restrictions, that we are providing unique conditions on this indigenous organisation that we do not provide on others. I am expecting that it will not go beyond that.

PARA.TAB: I have just said two or three times that I expect the administration will be kept within the same responsible bounds that ATSIC has succeeded keeping its administration. I guess what we are suggesting is a radical proposal. We are suggesting that we let the organisation start its operations, give it an opportunity to demonstrate whether it can be responsible about its administrative expenses and then, at some later stage, take any corrective action that might be necessary. That is a normal approach we have in here.

I might add in passing that that is why it is a nonsense for Senator Chamarette to suggest that she will vote, presumably to confirm she is opposing the bill—that is what she said she will be doing—despite the fact that she claimed that she is not opposing the bill. It is a legislative nonsense for Senator Chamarette to say that she would want to vote against this because this process is `locking in' anything. One of the differences that Aboriginal people point out between their system and ours is that their laws and cultural mores, while not immutable, take a long time to change, and ours can be changed here in an afternoon. For example, as far as locking in these amounts, of course this legislation does nothing of the sort. If a future Green government wanted to increase the amount and could persuade both houses of this parliament to do that—

TALK.START.PARA: —As successfully as I have done today, I presume.

—She has to get a few more numbers first; she has her work ahead of her. But if a future Green government did want to change it, there is no locking in in this legislation. That applies to this as well. I do not think it is unreasonable to propose, on the track record of the organisations already established that have not been criticised for excessive administrative expenditure, that we allow the organisation to start; we let it find out how it will handle all of the new tasks we are assigning to it; we review its operations, which we will through the Senate committee system apart from anything else, after it has been running for a year; we scrutinise its administrative expenses with an intense scrute, as we do through the processes of this chamber; and if we find it to be unsatisfactory, we either suggest that the organisation makes corrections or, failing it doing that, we take some measure to fix it. But let us not judge the organisation in advance.
—I do not think this amendment is necessary because we have already passed an amendment on the objects and principles of the bill. The very last one of those, 3(e)—
—It is a request for three million more dollars, though.

—Yes, but we have said to the ILC that administrative costs should be kept to a minimum and duplication of administrative capability should be avoided. Opposition senators said it was rudderless, without a framework. They gave it that framework. I think we should let it check that it adheres to those principles.

—I am having difficulty working out what the minister is really saying about the administrative funds or the component of this fund that is going to be available for administrative purposes because he seems to be saying there is no limit, that it is not even locked into the $3 million, which we were told was the component that was expected to be addressed to the administrative costs of setting up this new board, this new bureaucracy. At every point we have been told that $3 million is the amount that is expected.

PARA.TAB: What he is saying to me now is not only have they never limited it to $3 million but they actually object to it being limited to $3 million. Not only that, they object to the amount of the fund being increased by $3 million. Senator Kernot is saying the same thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's an indicative amount for the purposes of the budget.

—It was an indicative amount, and it was stated. But what concerns me most of all is that when I showed the graph in the chamber, and I used the so-called indicative amount to indicate that there would be a constant drain of $3 million away from the fund altogether, there was no discussion about that except Senator Campbell suggesting that, as more and more of the fund got used up for management, the administration costs may well increase. What I was pointing out at that point was how quickly the money allocated for acquisition would disappear—so quickly that the people who were least capable of mobilising themselves to make requests of the fund would be most penalised.

PARA.TAB: Now what we are having is direct confirmation of what Senator Campbell said, which is that there is a refusal by the government to even contemplate tying it into less than $3 million or increasing the amount for acquisition by $3 million. Thank you very much; that is exactly what I wanted the government to indicate—its degree of commitment to land acquisition.

I must say that when I pointed out to Senator Gareth Evans the gross discrepancy between management and acquisition that was likely to result in this fund, instead of saying,`Oh no, we have investigated. There is a mechanism to ensure that acquisition components will remain in this fund,' he said, `Well, you will notice, Senator Chamarette, it's not actually called the land acquisition fund; it is just called a land fund. So if the entire $45 million is swallowed up by management and administration, that is just too bad for the people who have not got themselves around to asking for a measly $1 million to purchase something like a pastoral lease, a shopping block or a piece of land.'

I am just outraged further. I want the minister to clarify for me why the amount of $3 million was set in the first place, what has caused it to change and why there is nothing whatsoever within the bill to determine that at every point there will still be some money in this fund for acquisition of land for those who have none. I want the minister to clarify why the government seems to be absolutely militating against that acquisition in favour of, on the one hand, management costs for all indigenous held land whether acquired by this fund or not, and, on the other hand, an administration which he is not prepared to lock in to a three per cent cost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think one of the issues that is being either avoided or ignored in this debate is that what Senator Chamarette's proposal seeks to do is not so much to quarantine the administrative expense, but to quarantine the moneys available for land acquisition and management. The coalition opposed limiting the management expenses because we thought it was unreasonable to make those sorts of judgements in advance. There may be periods when land acquisition may not be the most sensible use of the money in a particular fiscal year, and there may be very good reasons for spending more money on management. So we thought it was unreasonable to constrict the management of the fund and the corporation in those terms.

PARA.TAB: When it comes to administration, the coalition would have a different position, and that is because administration is quite often a centralised, bureaucratic institution that can, if it is done properly, be minimised and made efficient. The coalition's leaning on this amendment is to say that if we are going to be giving $24 million for land acquisition in the coming years—$24 million new—then there is merit in saying, `Let's minimise the administration impact.' It flows very much from the impassioned plea I made earlier this day in relation to setting up two funds.

The coalition shares the view of the Greens that it is the quarantine of the land acquisition and management money, the money that actually gets to the ground and that does the good, we hope. The key issue, therefore—and this is the question that has not been answered by either the government or the Democrats, and I would be interested in an answer to it—is, is the government opposed to the cap and the principle of quarantining the land acquisition and management money or is the government opposed to allocating $3 million new plus indexing for the administrative expense?

The reality is that Senator Collins's point makes Senator Chamarette's point. If it proves that all of this terrible consultation is going to ensure that the administrative expenses blow out from seven, eight or ten per cent, which is what we might hope they would be, to 15 or 20 per cent, then it is something that can come back to this parliament. But it is probably more likely that the administrative expense will come back and be looked at than the land acquisition and management amount, and of course, there is nothing to stop both coming back.

What we are really doing is saying we are capping the bureaucracy—we are capping the photocopying paper, we are capping all of the bureaucratic expenses that do not particularly, significantly and directly help Aboriginal people—but allowing the quarantining of the amount for land acquisition and management. The coalition is quite happy to support that. It shows our bona fides as far as the direction and the effect of the fund goes. It shows that we are fair dinkum about ensuring that the assistance is there.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the point you made about spending up to the three million?

—The point I make about that is that the minister said he could not possibly envisage that they would spend up to $3 million, so we are saying that $3 million is a reasonable cap. We are not making some outrageous sort of attempt—

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I had addressed that. That is where our amendment seeks to put upon them an incentive to save money on administration because part (6) of what would be the new clause in the amendment, which I think is now called AA8, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where, in any category A year, as a result of subsection (5), expenditure by the Indigenous Land Corporation on day-to-day administration is less than the amount provided for by this section . . . the savings are, as far as practicable, to be used for land acquisition functions in the following year.

So this is giving them an incentive. Say they only spend $2 million on administration, the other $1 million would go to land acquisition in the next year. I think that is something that is missing from the amendment as it stands, and would ensure that there is a very real incentive for the corporation to minimise its administration expenses so that it can maximise its land acquisition functions.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the best thing we could do is probably vote on this. But I do have an obligation to answer some of the questions, and I will try to be brief. Senator Campbell has just provided, in that last minute or two, the absolutely compelling reason why we should not be supporting this sort of stuff. It is not only totalling unnecessary to do it, but also it can effectively shackle the process of this organisation for acquiring land.

PARA.TAB: For example, members of the organisation may have to fly somewhere to consult, but the organisation may have exceeded, for whatever reason, the $3 million. it happens to be a fact in the real world—not the world that Senator Chamarette lives in—that one of the consistent problems the land councils have in the Northern Territory in negotiating the land matters that they have to negotiate is the very significant consultation they have to undertake, for example, when new amendments are passed in parliament putting time limits on negotiations and so on. The request that is often made for supplementation is in respect of the necessity for them to consult with their constituency.

I noted what Senator Campbell said casually a few minutes ago. This is the same argument that was used when we were talking about the problem of proroguing parliament and interfering at that point with the ILC. The fact is that this is a legislated amount. There is no discretion here. The ILC cannot, by law, go one cent over $3 million.

Senator Campbell might think that it is an easy matter to amend an act of parliament and get it through both houses on every occasion, but the facts are: if it is for legitimate reasons, the organisation will be dealt with in the same way that every other organisation is dealt with that spends too much on administration. I have to say that the scrutiny processes of this parliament are as good as any in the world, and fairly effective. Senate estimate committees are effective in terms of the almost limitless scrutiny that they can apply to these kinds of things, and of having administrative expenses put under the microscope.

The problem with legislating for it is that if, for the best reasons in the world, the ILC has to charter aircraft—and they are not cheap, I can tell Senator Chamarette: to get a twin engine aircraft these days costs between $1,000 and $2,000 a day to go anywhere, pretty much—and it has reached the $3 million legislated mark, it cannot do it. It has to stop until we amend an act of parliament to allow it, from time to time, to go over its administrative expenses.It is an incredibly blunt instrument to use to tackle what Senator Campbell is talking about.

I want to conclude on an important point with which I am in total agreement with Senator Campbell, and that is the question of management which he and Senator Chamarette alluded to. That has been sensibly left to the discretion of the board. I am glad that the opposition did not support that amendment. I do want to emphasise this, because I have strong personal views on it.

It is absolutely vitally important that the board sensibly provide for the circumstances in which it is relevant adequate management support after the acquisition. I have said publicly, I have said it in the cabinet room, outside of the cabinet room and in here, that the single most effective reason why there has been, regrettably, a profound failure of many Aboriginal enterprises, particularly pastoral enterprises around Australia, and it is an identified reason, is that there has been a concentration on acquisition without adequate follow up with management resources then applied to these properties.

The Kimberley Land Council will tell Senator Chamarette that as will the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council. I am glad that amendment was defeated, but Senator Chamarette has made another reference to management. It is vitally important that the board be left with the discretion to apply adequate funds for the management of these properties for the benefit of the Aboriginal people that will get them and, I might add, for the credibility of the program. I am not frightened to say that again, although Senator Chamarette is very dismissive about it. One of the reasons why credibility of land acquisition programs has suffered badly in the public forum is that there were some, unquestionably, profound failures, in terms of management of properties which were acquired for the benefit of Aboriginals, which meant that the intended beneficiaries got nothing out of it except bad press.

It is vitally important that that management component is given high priority by this organisation. I put to the chamber again, with as much reasonableness as I can, that it is extraordinary and unique situation to impose on a commercial statutory body a legislative restriction on its administrative expenses before the body has even started, to test whether it can be responsible. It will require, if for the best reasons in the world it goes beyond its administrative expenses, an amendment of an act of parliament to allow it to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the $3 million for administration?

—That is about seven per cent of the $45 million. As I have said before, I have every confidence in the body. I will not respond to any more interjections, Mr Temporary Chairman, because we are trying to cut that down. The processes of this parliament to scrutinise that aspect of any organisations established by an act of parliament are more than adequate. They are, I would have to concede—even as a government minister—effective in bringing this to public attention wherever it happens. I think it is unreasonable and unnecessary to shackle this organisation with a legislative provision in terms of administration before we even give the organisation an opportunity to demonstrate that it can effectively manage its budget.

PARA.TAB: One other matter—and I will conclude on this, as I do not want to place too much weight on it—is that the organisation does have a capacity to borrow, for the purpose of giving it additional flexibility in land acquisition, up to $100 million in the first three years and $200 million beyond that. It will be an interesting exercise to see what will happen if, for perfectly legitimate reasons, it determines to exercise that power, which I think has been supported here, to make those borrowing limits to increase its acquisitions, which by necessity will require additional administrative expenses and consultation but will still be shackled by the $3 million limit set by this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment on the minister's remarks. I would like to say that on the whole the level of debate in this chamber has been excellent. People have respected the views that have been put and have not tried to denigrate and insult people, simply because they disagree. I do not mind Senator Collins disagreeing with me; I do not mind him disagreeing with me strongly. But I do not think it adds to the credibility of his argument for him to pretend that I do not know what I am talking about.

PARA.TAB: If I do not know what I am talking about, I would like the minister to clarify it for me because I am being led to understand that there is no way in which the minister will protect the money that is given in this land fund for acquisition and management from the increasing costs of administration as the consultation needs arise. I would like to know what his explanation for that is. I am more than happy to have amendments to my amendments so that we do not restrict or cap the administration costs.

The main thrust of my amendment is to quarantine the administrative costs from the land fund moneys that are to be given for acquisition and management. If the minister would like to ask for an additional $3 million that can be added to and not capped if the administrative costs rise, I have no objection to looking at a rephrasing of my amendments. The point I am trying to make—and I do not think the minister has adequately answered it—is that it is all very well to get angry about administrative costs blowing out because of the need for consultation, but if the administration costs blow out into the whole fund, there is nothing to administer. So then the fund will have lower administrative costs because there will be nothing to give out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting they would spend $45 million on administration?

—No, I am not saying that. I am saying that approximately $15 million has already gone on management. If we estimate that an increasing proportion will be used for management, and if more than $3 million is required each year for administration, the amount available for acquisition is never quarantined from invasion on those two sides. That is my point. I would like the minister to explain to me how much he thought the administration of this fund would cost, why he did not attempt to make it an additional administrative cost, and why he pretends that this is somehow some kind of beneficent gesture that is not going to swallow up the money available to those people who have been dispossessed of their lands.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Out of courtesy, I indicate that the government will respond through Senator Evans to those points. I have to go to Sydney, so I ask Senator Chamarette to address her questions to the leader.

—The sum of $3 million relates only to the $24 million; it does not relate to the $45 million. The estimates statement I have for 1994-95 for ATSIC states quite clearly that in its land acquisition program $2.4 million is allocated for administration. That leaves the other $21 million which is used for land acquisition. So if we are going to talk about the total of $45 million, we would have to say that total administration costs would be $5.4 million. What we have done is quarantine the money available for expenditure on land acquisition and management. That is $24 million. As to this being a unique provision; it is. The legislation is unique. There is nothing quite like it on the statute books.

PARA.TAB: What is quite innovative might require innovative measures. To set the administrative costs with a cap of $3 million is not unusual when we compare it with the ATSIC statement because the ATSIC statement really has administration costs running at 10 per cent, maybe 10.5 per cent. The $3 million cap over $24 million runs at something like 12.5 per cent. So we have allowed an extra two per cent margin. If we accept Senator Collins's comments that $3 million is not enough, we would have to be conceding that the Indigenous Land Corporation needs a greater percentage for administrative costs than ATSIC does. In fact, we would have to be conceding that it would be starting to run into inefficiency problems. If administrative costs got up to the realm of 15 per cent, we would need to have a serious look at this corporation.

Another thing I might say is that the consultative process will require some resources. Nonetheless, in the drafting of the amendments which have now been accepted, we can see that the Green amendments mention in part `as far as practicable, as far as possible'. This did not place an absolute mandate for the ILC to go out and exhaustively consult until there was no-one left standing who had not been consulted. What the document said was that in the circumstances the ILC had to do its level best to make sure that everybody was consulted.

One of the constraints on that is its budget. If it had an administration budget of $45 million, it could individually interview, I dare say, every Aboriginal person in this country. But the budget does not allow it to do that. The Greens in their amendments recognise that with the essential phrase `as far as practicable'. I refer senators back to the J series amendments. The consultative process will cost money, but it will not blow out the administrative costs as mentioned.

The cap of $3 million is reasonable. As proposed in the further amendments to come, there is a review mechanism after three years whereby, if this is not enough, a necessary amendment can be made. I dare say that inflation will not be running rampant in the next three years, if the government is to be believed. If inflation stays in accordance with the projected analysis of the government, $3 million will remain $3 million and will not be worth only $2 million or $1.5 million in three years. I am saying that this is a reasonable figure. It has been looked at in comparison to ATSIC. An extra two per cent has been allowed on that administrative cost. I believe the idea to cap administrative costs is innovative and we could well look at it in some other areas of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's indexed anyway.

—As Senator Campbell says, it is indexed anyway. But what the coalition really dreads is that we could have that $24 million being eaten up by administrative costs and we would get what we have across the board in Australia today: the complaint that the taxpayers' dollar is not finding its mark, that the taxpayers' dollar is being eaten up in administration.

PARA.TAB: There is also an incentive in Senator Campbell's foreshadowed amendment that the ILC will keep its administrative costs to a minimum because, if it does, there is a bonus. The bonus is that what is not spent goes into land acquisition and land management. That would come up in the review, and everybody would say what a great organisation it was because it had managed to keep its costs down and thereby afford more money into the general fund for the purpose for which it was set up. I think the proposed amendment is sensible. Those who are voting against it are really saying that they do not want to protect that $24 million which is set aside for land acquisition and land management. It is really a grant of a further $3 million per year. It would lessen the strain on the funds which are there for land acquisition and land management.

TALK.START.PARA: —One good thing about this whole debate is that each clause that is in contention is being discussed logically, sensibly and, in most cases, with restraint. The last contribution was an example of that, as indeed was Senator Chamarette's contribution prior to that. I will not contribute a great deal to the debate except to indicate that I have the view that this amendment has an important thrust, and that is that it says to the government, to the people of Australia and particularly to the corporation that we want this money to hit the dirt. That is what we are talking about. We want it to hit the dirt. We want the dirt to be the acquisition, and we want the money to be used for acquisition purposes in particular.

PARA.TAB: I am very interested to hear Senator Gareth Evans's responses to those quite important contributions to this debate which have dealt with the amendment moved by Senator Chamarette and the amendment foreshadowed by Senator Campbell. Senator Ellison has indicated that Senator Campbell's amendment has that bonus implication. I think it is a very well thought out amendment. I do not know whether Senator Chamarette has indicated her agreement with it—yes, she is nodding her agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —All the points that the government wishes to make have already been made by Senator Collins, and I think I would simply be being repetitive. There are two thrusts here: one is to set a limit, effectively, of $3 million; the other is to provide for an amount of $3 million to go into the pool in addition to that which the government has been prepared to commit so far—both, on the face of them, worthy and not totally unreasonable objectives but, in practice, I am afraid, amounting to just that.

PARA.TAB: The budgetary dimensions of this whole affair have been thoroughly worked out in terms of all the other constraints upon us in terms of running the government. It is a pretty cavalier kind of enterprise—particularly for the opposition, which is always telling us so much about fiscal responsibility—to, with a stroke of the legislative pen, commit us to another $3 million a year.

It was always anticipated, of course, that there be a reasonable component of whatever moneys were drawn down from the fund that would have to be devoted to administration. Obviously, it is in everybody's interests that that amount be minimised and the maximum be left for the land acquisition and land management functions. From that point of view, I certainly have no quarrel with the proposed additional amendment AA8 that has been foreshadowed by the opposition to the extent it states that stricture in those sorts of terms. But to in effect be dragging another $3 million out of the government's consolidated revenue for this purpose when we have indicated already how far we are prepared to go and when that has been an element, obviously, in all the consultative processes—everyone has understood that there is an administrative component in it—I think is to place an unreasonable burden upon the government, given all our other responsibilities.

As to whether the amount of $3 million, or as indexed in subsequent years, is an unreasonable constraint, let me make the obvious point that, as a percentage of total cost, three on 24 is only 12 1/2 per cent at the moment but three on 45, which will be the situation three years out—

TALK.START.PARA: —But then we have the review and that can be changed.

—Yes—there will obviously be only half that percentage. A figure of the order of six or seven per cent I do not think in anyone's estimate is an unreasonable proportion to devote to administrative expenses. This is an organisation that has to go through start up and has to hit the ground running, and those sorts of costs will simply be involved. I think it is only nauseous repetition for me to go through this if the Senate majority's mind is made up. It is just another problem to add to the pile we will have to confront later on. I do not think there is anything more I can usefully do to persuade senators.

—I ask senators to consider all the amendments that we have made. Under the J series we have no land acquisition until the establishment of strategies, we have all the work that has to go into the formulation of strategies and we have all the layers of consultation and research that we have imposed through this legislation. Now we are capping the amount to be spent. This is in addition to set-up costs. I do not think opposition senators have realistically looked at the cumulative effects of the other amendments we have put in place. The council for reconciliation and ATSIC have conducted a round of social justice consultations. This is one proposal, and already it has cost over a million dollars.
—Do you want to propose to make it $4 million?
—I think the opposition is being unrealistic about—
—Be reasonable; will you make it $4 million?

—No, I think it is unreasonable to say it has to be this amount, given what we have done to the processes through this bill. I understand the principle about not eating into the land acquisition total—
—Do you support that?
—Yes, I do support that principle, but I do not like the way the opposition is doing this. I cannot vote for it; sorry.

PARA.TAB: Amendments and request agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of proposed section 192SA, add the following subsections:

"`(5) It is the wish of the Parliament that, as far as is reasonable and practicable, consistent with the efficient and effective performance of its functions, the Indigenous Land Corporation and the Indigenous Land Corporation General Manager are to minimise expenditure on the expenses of the day-to-day administration of the Indigenous Land Corporation.

`(6) Where, in any category A year, as a result of subsection (5), expenditure by the Indigenous Land Corporation on day-to-day administration is less than the amount provided for by this section for that year, the savings are, as far as is practicable, to be used for land acquisition functions in the following year.'.".

This amendment has been circulated. I will not debate it any more. It has been canvassed. It effectively requests the ILC to minimise its expenditure on administration as far as practicable. Part (6) says that, where a surplus is achieved by its efficiency, that money will be applied to land acquisition functions in the following year.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 3, page 26, after proposed section 193, insert the following subsections:

I made some comments earlier explaining why we have withdrawn amendments 1 and 2—the reason being that we have been willing to replace them with this amendment. The thrust of this amendment is to hold the government to its claim that the fund will be self-sustaining over 10 years. We want to legislate to make sure that that is the case.

PARA.TAB: To achieve an appropriate level of self-sustainability, a four per cent real rate of investment is required. If the fund fails to achieve that target amount over the 10-year period, this amendment would require the government to top up the fund to achieve what would be the expected value of the fund at that point in time. The target amount is defined in the proposed clauses 193(2)(b) and 193(2)(c) as $1.1 billion indexed to inflation. That represents the net present value of the fund, assuming a seven per cent return over the next 10 years. This is all based on calculations from the Department of Finance. The result of the government's guarantee, by way of this amendment, would be that at the end of 10 years the land fund would be worth more than $1.4 billion.

I think we are entitled to be concerned that we could not get a four per cent real return on cash instruments with the land fund without purchasing higher levels of risk, but it is worth pointing out that the Minister for Finance is authorised under section 62B of the Audit Act to invest in other investments. If the cash instruments do fail to achieve four per cent averaged over several years, I would expect that the minister might seek in the future to use the provisions in the Financial Management and Accountability Act—which we will be debating in the Senate next year—to improve the investment performance of the fund to avoid the possibility of a large top-up at the end of the process.

Under this amendment the top-up would be paid on the first business day of the year 2005-06. It would be based on the Minister for Finance's assessment of the value of investments as at that point. In making that assessment, the minister will be required to have regard to the audited financial statements of the fund. Hopefully, this will ensure that the minister does not overvalue the book value of the investments to reduce the top-up.

The consolidated revenue fund would be automatically appropriated for the top-up amount under section 193(5) as it presently reads. I think it is satisfactory that this guarantee is included in the legislation, that it carries with it a standing appropriation, and that it cannot be changed without the consent of the Senate. That is probably as strong a guarantee as the government can possibly provide—particularly to the effect that a four per cent real return can be achieved, thus resulting in a sustainable land fund. That was the promise, and we merely seek to hold the government to that promise.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition, in line with the principle of maintaining and quarantining the value of the fund, will not be opposing this amendment.

—The government also supports this amendment. We are confident, of course, that the land fund under the existing formula in the bill will build up to over $1 billion in 1994-95 dollars by the end of year 10, thus enabling the continuing drawdown of $45 million to be sustained. We are certainly prepared to accept this thoughtful amendment prepared by the Democrats in the interests of ensuring that the land fund does achieve the objectives that we all want for it, even if real interest rates are not maintained at the level that is anticipated in the bill. For the reasons which have been well stated by Senator Kernot, we support the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

These amendments deal with the situation where payments are made out of consolidated revenue to the ILC under proposed section 193A, and when similar payments are made to ATSIC under section 193B. These amendments ensure that there is a single annual payment made rather than two instalments, thus giving the ILC and ATSIC the money at the beginning of each calendar year. This will allow the ILC and ATSIC the flexibility of being able to invest or disburse the money. It is an attempt to optimise the money that will be available. My understanding is that the government has indicated some support for this principle. Certainly, I think the government mentioned that it would agree with amendment C1 and, as amendment C3 is identical, I should not imagine that it would present a problem. I hope to have the support of the Senate for these three amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before responding to Senator Chamarette, I seek confirmation that she has withdrawn the rest of her series B group of amendments in deference to the series C amendments?
—Yes, I have withdrawn the C series.

—Under those circumstances, I indicate ecce mirabile—marvellous to behold—that the government does in fact accept this particular amendment from the Greens. It was the subject of a cooperative approach that we adopted earlier on in the hope of larger rewards; but nonetheless, it does intrinsically stand up in its own right. It will add a small additional amount in practice to the fund by virtue of having earlier access each year to the full amount, and we are prepared to go along that path.
—The coalition supports the amendments on the same basis.
