SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 9.Clause 3, page 32, proposed subsection 193G(1), line 21, omit "once", substitute "twice".
10.Clause 3, page 32, after proposed subsection 193G(2), insert the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: " `(2A) A person who is, or is to be, a participant in a meeting convened under subsection (1) may request the Minister to provide to each participant in the meeting such information as is specified in the request. The specified information must relate to the management and/or performance of the investments of the Land Fund. The Minister must comply with the request.".

SPEECH.PARA: I am doing this because I have withdrawn our amendments to set up a committee of advisers. That came under amendments 1 and 2 which we discussed earlier. The committee would have allowed the ILC another Aboriginal member, as well as probably some private sector business investors to monitor the performance of the fund. This recognises that the land fund has two lines of accountability for its financial performance. The first is a trust fund within the public account. There is a responsibility to the Minister for Finance and, through the minister, to the parliament to ensure that the funds are kept appropriately and invested prudently.

PARA.TAB: The second line of accountability is to the ILC and, through the ILC, to the Aboriginal community who want to see a sustainable land fund delivering the highest possible returns with the lowest possible risk to maximise dispersals to the ILC. This amendment seeks to beef up slightly the second line of accountability. It seeks to provide that the consultative forum meets at least twice a year and that it is able to ask questions and receive answers on the hard questions regarding the investments of the fund.

We need to read this provision along with the top-up provision that we have just passed and which was added to section 193. If the fund was failing to meet its four per cent benchmark, I imagine the ILC directors would have the opportunity to ask some very serious questions of those making investments under this section. As the bill in section 193F allows the minister to delegate his investment powers to an officer of ATSIC, I would expect that the elected commissioners of ATSIC would also keep a close eye on the performance of its commercial division; although, of course, the elected commissioners could not override any directions of the Minister for Finance. It is just a way of beefing up the second line of accountability.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is prepared to accept both of these amendments. We have no in-principle objection to twice-yearly meetings of the consultative forum on investments of the land fund. We also believe that it is reasonable for the minister to provide information to that forum on the management and performance of the investments of the fund. So, for the reasons specified by Senator Kernot, the amendments are acceptable.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (42)Clause 3, page 33, after proposed paragraph 193I(2)(d) insert the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(da)such other information as either House of the Parliament may require, such requirement to be specified in a resolution of that House;".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment deals with proposed paragraph 193I(2)(d) and entails the insertion of subparagraph (da), which deals with the annual report of the land fund. This requires that, further to all the other specified subjects which are to be covered in the annual report, there should be the catch-all provision that there be `such other information as either House of the Parliament may require, such requirement to be specified in a resolution of that House'. So a majority of the house would have to resolve that some subject of information or some aspect be included. It could be a specific detail or a bit more general. Nonetheless, it allows parliament to inform itself of other aspects which it thinks are pertinent, other than the matters mentioned in proposed paragraph 193I.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators will see that proposed subsection 193I is quite specific in what it covers in relation to the annual report. It was thought perhaps not to limit it to such matters. Quite frankly, the particulars of amounts paid out of the land fund—its investments and the realised returns—are all quite sensible and should be included. But the coalition thought that there may be matters which parliament needs to inform itself of. That is what this proposal allows. It is not something which can be requested by just one senator alone; it requires a resolution of the house which would have to be supported by a majority. It furthers the way in which parliament can inform itself of how the land fund is progressing. The amendment is a commendable one.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment put forward by Senator Ellison. As I see it, the report must include those matters specifically listed, plus provide any other information as required by regulations. So the government is able to request and to ensure that the fund contains whatever other information it may require or it thinks the public may require. This extends that provision so that either house of the parliament may require such information to be contained in the annual report. I support that. As Senator Ellison says, it gives that additional flavour to this particular subsection and it indicates that the parliament is very interested in this matter, in the corporation and in acquisition and land management, and wants to be kept informed of various matters.

—This is another example of a rather innocuous-looking little clause which, unfortunately, packs more of a punch than the government is prepared to accept. We see this as a very unusual requirement and one that is totally unnecessary as an additional imposition on an agency which already has to satisfy and demonstrate the highest level of accountability pursuant to a whole series of strictures that presently lie upon it. The bill, as has been said, already requires detailed information on the operations of the land fund to be provided to parliament and allows regulations to be made—as Senator Harradine just pointed out—to require the provision of further information, if it is thought appropriate for that to be pursued.

PARA.TAB: The proposed amendment, as we see it, places unnecessarily onerous further requirements and does not add in any necessary way to the stringent accountability requirements which are already there. There is no provision in legislation for comparable or similar statutory authorities. In fact, the draftsmen tell us that they are unable to find or to recollect any similar provision in any other piece of legislation. When resolutions of the parliament are specified, as they often are in legislation, it is always in reference to both houses of parliament. The amendment, as drafted, requiring a resolution by either house, could, among other things, lead to a situation where the two houses were passing contradictory resolutions—thereby conceivably creating even more unnecessary confusion and difficulties in compliance.

We see this as another exercise in hindering—whether intentionally or not—the workings of the land fund by imposing upon it stricter accountability and reporting requirements than apply to comparable agencies. There will be ample information available to parliament not only through the annual report but also through the Auditor-General's report and through the Senate estimates process. There is ample opportunity for parliament to gain more information if necessary not only through those processes but also, I guess, through the native title committee, which will be looking at the land fund, and through questions asked of the minister in the normal way. So with all those things going for us, we need this additional requirement like the proverbial hole in the head. For all those reasons, the government does not and will not support this requirement.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: E1.Clause 3, pages 34 to 36, proposed subsections 193L(2) to (10), line 27 (page 34) to line 8 (page 36), omit the subsections.
E2.Clause 3, pages 36 to 38, proposed section 193N, line 22 (page 36) to line 3 (page 38), omit the section.

These amendments are aimed at removing borrowing and guarantee limits placed in the legislation. We have heard a little about how the board does not want to be restricted, and every time the Greens suggest something that will restrict it we have a loud outcry. So here is one example where we are giving it more flexibility.

PARA.TAB: The bill, in its original form, limits the capacity of the ILC to borrow money. The Greens (WA) believe that the ILC should be free to make its own decision on borrowings as a normal commercial borrower. These amendments remove the restrictions on the ILC to borrow money and to act as a guarantor for loans by indigenous people. We believe that the ILC should run the gauntlet of the markets. A $100 million borrowing amount would certainly be inappropriate, if the money and the fund were to be increased. The Greens would not want to disallow that possibility. We believe that the borrowing limit should be left up to the markets, dealt with in a sensible way and does not need to be restricted in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to have to say that these are more amendments that do not appeal to the government, for the following reasons. They have to do with accountability and they have to do with appropriate limitations for bodies of this kind in the interests of maintaining fiscal rectitude. Most Commonwealth statutory authorities cannot borrow money without specific approval from the Treasurer. The ILC does not require such approval. But there is, nonetheless, a need for the Commonwealth to ensure that the ILC does not incur significant debts which might have to be paid back from general revenue. It would be quite irresponsible, under those circumstances, for the government not to place some limit on the borrowing powers.

PARA.TAB: The combined limit on borrowings and guarantees is approximately four times the ILC's annual drawdown from the land fund. In years one to three the limit is $100 million compared with drawdowns of $25 million in year one and $24 million in years two and three. In subsequent years the limit is $200 million compared with drawdowns of $45 million in years four to 10. The limit has been set at a level which ensures that the corporation is able to meet its financial commitments but, nonetheless, allows it to operate in a commercial manner using its anticipated income stream to take account of opportunities as they arise.

Removing borrowing limits on the ILC would leave the corporation vulnerable to significant debt. One assumes responsibility, of course, on the part of corporation members, board members, but, in the interests of good sense and looking far ahead into the future and at basic principles of public administration, it is not desirable to leave it open-ended in this way. Were the ILC to get itself into debt, one might then have pressure upon governments to abolish the whole operation on the basis of some unacceptable drain on public moneys. One does not want to necessarily paint the worst case scenario but one has to anticipate that possibility—prudence and caution demand as much.

The same point that I have been making in relation to borrowing limits really applies equally to guarantees, and there is no need for me to separate the arguments out. The government opposes the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —For similar reasons, the coalition opposes the amendments. We think that limitations are sensible and, clearly, if there was not some sort of restriction in place then we could end up with a disaster on our hands. It is not to say that we do not trust the board that is being appointed but, quite frankly, the limits are generous in the view of the coalition and it would be potentially disturbing if those limits were exceeded.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (46)Clause 3, page 40, lines 14 and 30, omit "or" (last occurring), substitute "and".
(47)Clause 3, page 41, lines 11 and 26, omit "or" (last occurring), substitute "and".
(48)Clause 3, page 42, lines 10 to 17, omit proposed subsection 193S(7), substitute the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: " `(7) Subsections (3) and (5) do not apply to the disclosure of information, or the production of a document, if the disclosure or production, as the case requires, is for the purposes of a criminal proceeding.".

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments really are quite similar. Amendments Nos 46 and 47 deal with section 193S, subsections (3) and (5) respectively. The amendment is identical in either case: it seeks to omit the word `or' and replace it with `and'. This has the effect of making it cumulative and not an alternative. This deals with an ILC officer not disclosing certain information. It is reminiscent of the print media inquiry: it deals with this aspect of commercial-in-confidence.

PARA.TAB: In subsection (3) there is the requirement that an ILC officer must not, either directly or indirectly, disclose to any person any information concerning the affairs of another person acquired by that officer where—and this is the crucial part—it was either acquired by the officer in the performance of his or her duties in connection with an application for the giving of a guarantee, et cetera, or, secondly, the disclosure of the information could reasonably be expected to prejudice substantially the commercial interests of the other person. It is the coalition's view that it should be a cumulative test and not a test on an either/or basis.

The coalition's view is that disclosure should be prohibited if the information was acquired in the course of the officer's duties and that the disclosure could substantially prejudice the commercial interests of another person. I am looking at similar provisions in the home savings grant and banking acts. The insertion of the word `and' fits more comfortably with similar provisions in other Commonwealth statutes.

Really, the test in the first instance that the information was simply acquired by the officer in the course of that officer's duties is perhaps too low a threshold. One should really make out some sort of prejudice to be suffered before the disclosure of that information is prohibited. It deals only with commercial information; it does not touch on those matters which might be of significance to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

Similarly, under subsection (5), an ILC officer must not disclose to a court of law information which is acquired in the same manner. The coalition's view is that the disclosure of information to a court of law is very serious indeed because it goes right to the core of evidence that might be required to try an issue. If the court does not have that information before it, it might not arrive at a decision which is just in all the circumstances. It has to be very serious indeed before parliament prohibits information going before a court.

This is tied in with amendment 48, which relates to 193S(7), which deals with the disclosure of information for the purposes of criminal proceedings. That is even more serious because one is dealing with criminal proceedings there. The proceedings I have just mentioned I take to be civil proceedings. In our legal system we always place perhaps more emphasis on criminal proceedings because the liberty of an individual might be at stake, which makes it all the more important to make sure that the ends of justice are served. I can appreciate that these amendments might have to be put separately, but I thought I would address them as a package in order to save time.

With regard to the government's position, subsection (7) says that the prohibition on disclosure does not apply for prosecutions under the Crimes Act—but only certain prosecutions. They are offences against sections 5, 6, 7, 7A, 29C or 29D or 86(1), and also prosecutions in relation to the act or regulations.

It is the coalition's firm view that the disclosure of information—that is not the information which might be of a cultural or sensitive nature to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people; this is strictly nuts and bolts information dealing with transactions, loans, guarantees, et cetera—should never be prohibited from being disclosed to any criminal proceedings.

I might just give the committee an example of a case in which I was involved at the beginning of last year. That was where an eastern states criminal syndicate used an Aboriginal person as a front man to acquire a pastoral lease for the purposes of growing a large crop of marijuana. Of course, the Aboriginal person applied under certain aspects of state law for the pastoral lease. Once the syndicate got it via their front man, they then grew a cannabis crop, cultivated it, ran it and did everything else that was needed. Nonetheless, during the very lengthy trial, the prosecution needed to get and bring forward application forms, the forms that were used by the department in granting the pastoral lease to prove that this person had in fact made the application, the dates on which it was made and the purpose which was stated on the application form.

What I am saying is that the Crimes Act is not enough because there are other acts of parliament touching on criminal law which could well impinge on this section. I am not saying that it will happen in the future, but I have given the committee a concrete example of where an Aboriginal person was used by a syndicate—and the court recognised, I might say, in the subsequent decision which it came to, in the sentences that were handed down, that this person was used as a front man. I know that to be the case because I represented the Aboriginal person who was used as a front man. It was useful for the defence, not just the prosecution, to have information brought to light because there were allegations made which needed to be ventilated.

It is not just essential for the prosecution of an offence, but it could well be absolutely essential to the defence to have documentation brought before a court. It might be that the prosecution says that there was a matter of fraud in another matter and that there was a conspiracy to acquire land and sell it at an inflated value, or that there was a conspiracy to commit another crime on this land, and that the person concerned who is accused signed a piece of paper in the furtherance of that conspiracy. The person says, `I never signed any piece of paper.' That person would need to have available the opportunity to bring the piece of paper, the form, into the court of law and say, `There is the loan application. I didn't sign it. I was not a party to that.'

The way that the bill sits at the moment could well prohibit that and could well severely impede the interests of justice. I think that is a most serious situation. I do not think the government has done this deliberately. I think it is really an oversight. In any case, documents should never be withheld from criminal proceedings because at the end of the day the most superior jurisdiction of all is the criminal jurisdiction and the most serious sanction a state can levy on one of its citizens is imprisonment. Where that person might have their defence thwarted by not having access to documentation, I think it is a serious state of affairs.

The other two matters are somewhat different. I put 46 and 47 in a different category. I believe that the test should be tightened. It was during the print media inquiry that we saw the test of commercial-in-confidence—that the government was able to withhold documentation from a Senate committee of inquiry. I do not want to go down that political burrow again. Suffice to say that parliament needs to be informed of certain things. Before you cut off the availability of documentation to parliament or before you cut off the availability of documentation to a court of law, you must be very sure indeed of what you are doing. I think the test must be a very high one before you say that a document cannot come before a court of law in proceedings.

I think in this case the test is simply too weak a test. If it is something that was acquired by the officer in the performance of his or her duties, it cannot be disclosed or it cannot be brought before a court of law. I think that test is too low; the threshold is too low. It should be strengthened and it should be made cumulative with the second part of the subsection, which says that it must also have the potential to substantially prejudice the commercial interests of another person. So the test must have two elements to it and they must be cumulative and not seen as alternatives. That is the reason for proposing that. Mr Temporary Chairman, it may be that these amendments have to be put separately; nonetheless, I have addressed them cognately in the interest of saving time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sad to say that the government has difficulty with these amendments—not the same order of difficulty as with some of the other things that have gone to the fundamental workability of the legislation. Nonetheless, we think, on balance, the bill is better drafted as it is. Let me explain why.

PARA.TAB: As to 46 and 47, this little substitution of `and' for `or' really does make quite a significant difference to the operation of this provision. If the amendment were to be carried, it would require that an ILC officer must not disclose information about another person where that information was both obtained in the course of his duty and where disclosure could prejudice commercial interests of the other person. The proposed amendment, by virtue of that additional cumulative requirement, waters down the protection for commercially sensitive information. That is something we ought to be very reluctant to concede.

The amendment would adversely affect, in that sense, the ILC's ability to operate in a commercial environment, in particular, by opening up the possibility that commercial-in-confidence information acquired by ILC officers when performing land management functions could be disclosed. It would not prevent disclosure of such information; for example, if the ILC manages a property under a commercial agreement, an ILC officer would not be prohibited from disclosing information acquired about the landowner's affairs that could affect the market value of the property because the information would not have been acquired in connection with the giving of a grant, loan or guarantee.

By virtue of making the requirements cumulative in this way, one limits the capacity to protect certain categories of information which are prejudicial to others but may not have been acquired strictly in the course of this duty. We wanted to make that limit in order to improve the commercial viability of the ILC. Where we have a body like this which has a mixture of both commercial and non-commercial functions, this kind of drafting does make some sense. It is based on a similar provision in section 114 of the development allowance assistance act 1992. I hope the opposition might be prepared to reconsider it on that basis.

As to amendment 48, it is about quite a different subject matter, as has been acknowledged. The subsection as it is now drafted is to the same effect as other secrecy provisions in the ATSIC Act which apply to ATSIC itself, and to the Commercial Development Corporation. I am referring to sections 90 and 191. This allows, under the present drafting, disclosure of ILC information and documents only if there is a prosecution for an offence against this act or certain other Commonwealth offences which relate to this act. The amendment, as Senator Ellison has said, would change that to allow disclosure for the purpose of any criminal offence, including offences under state or territory laws.

There is a nice question of balance here. There may be individual cases which one can cite, as Senator Ellison did, where, on the face of it, there has not been any particular harm done in the disclosure and which has advanced the cause of a legitimate prosecution. But it is a matter of weighing and balancing the other competing values here—that is, the need to, so far as is humanly possible, keep sensitive financial commercial information confidential.

There is also the additional reinforcing concern when one is dealing with Aboriginal legislation of this kind that a lot of the information one is dealing with is extraordinarily sensitive on cultural grounds.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is dealt with separately.
—I do not know where there is a specific provision for it which would not be overridden by this.
—I refer to (3)(b).
—Which section are you referring to, Senator?

—I refer the minister to (3)(b), which the opposition does not want to tinker with, where the information is considered sacred or otherwise significant. We are not tinkering with that at all. We are saying that that should be left alone and we are only dealing with the commercial stuff.

—I want to take some advice on that because, on the face of it, that is a good answer. The difficulty, I am told, is that subsection (7) applies to a wider class of information than that which is subject to the sacred protective provision in (3)(b). I will have to take that particular assertion on trust because I cannot find (3)(b).

PARA.TAB: We will consider the validity of that aspect of the matter. The main point that we want to make is that, when talking about protection of financial or commercial information, there are always questions as to how far that protection should reach, what weight should be given to the competing claims of administration of criminal justice elsewhere and whether there is a key desire to preserve confidentiality here. That balance has been struck in favour of preserving the integrity of the financial information. The judgment is presumably made that any criminal prosecution where this sort of information is likely to be relevant is likely to be very few and far between; they would be most unusual cases rather than mainstream ones, and that risk could be borne.

As I say, it is a nice matter of judgement. I am not pretending that this is a major issue. It is one, however, that the government would prefer to err on the side of drafting caution and follow the precedents that have been set in the other legislation which I have described.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make my position clear in regard to the opposition's amendments 46, 47 and 48. I oppose 46 and 47 and support 48 for the reasons that have been advanced. This is quite a serious question which involves the integrity of the courts—which are as important to Aboriginal people as they are to anybody else. However, the matters raised by Senator Gareth Evans have persuaded me to oppose amendments 46 and 47.
—We get you on the big ones!
—Do you support 48?
—Yes I do. But I do not support 46 and 47.

—I am indebted to Senator Harradine for that contribution. I have not been indebted to him for too much else during the course of this debate, but we are grateful. As to amendment 48, having had a chance now to look at the terms of the bill, I have to say that the protection for sacred information in clause 193S(3)(b) cannot override the prosecution exception that is set out in subclause 7 of that same clause.

PARA.TAB: Subclause 7 says that subsections (3) and (5) do not apply to the disclosure of information if that information is required for the purposes of a prosecution in the context of this legislation. Subclause 3—including 3(b), which is the protection of disclosure of sacred information—is overridden by the clauses presently drafted. Since the opposition would widen out clause 7 in this way, it overrides it again. It is only a debating point, but the sacred information does come into play. We are worried about the disclosure of that inadvertently through this sort of process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of that, I will look at subclauses 3(b) and 5(b). They deal with the `sacred or otherwise significant' information and have a cultural basis. The coalition would be willing to amend subclause 7 to say `subsections 3(a) and 3(c) and 5(a) and 5(c)'. That then deals with the information that I referred to earlier. It would have to include 3(c) and 5(c), because (a) and (c) respectively in the discrete clauses deal with the commercial aspects only, whereas (b) and (d) in the two clauses deal with the other information. The coalition made it clear in earlier debate that we did not want to impinge on cultural matters which were significant and sacred matters which were confidential. I seek leave to amend opposition amendment No. 48.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Subclause 7 will read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraphs 3(a), 3(c), 5(a) and 5(c) do not apply to the disclosure of information, or the production of a document, if the disclosure or production, as the case requires, is for the purposes of a criminal proceeding.
Does that change the government's position?

TALK.START.PARA: —No. I gave Senator Ellison leave to amend amendment No. 48 because it makes it less obnoxious to the extent that I no longer have my cultural argument, but I still have my commercial argument. We will keep on opposing the amendment on that ground. I was happy to grant leave to limit the effect of it in the way that Senator Ellison proposed.

—I want to indicate the Greens' position. I think we initially told the opposition that we would support all three of these amendments. The reason we did was that we assumed they were in connection with criminal proceedings only. We thought there was some validity to that.

PARA.TAB: However, having listened to the discussion, we do not feel inclined to support amendments 46 and 47 with the change of the `or' to `and'. The reason I have been given is that the change from `or' to `and' does not protect third parties. While I am not familiar with the legal reasons why that is an objection—I do not understand the intricacies of it—I can understand it. For that reason, we now indicate that we are not happy to support 46 and 47, but we are prepared to support 48. Can Senator Ellison confirm for me whether my impression is correct: if we support 48, are we simply working to provide protection in criminal proceedings and to protect the sacred information from disclosure?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can confirm that. Amendments Nos 46 and 47 are civil matters dealing with commercial information only. Amendment No. 48 is purely criminal which deals with commercial information only. Whilst we are on this subject, I see the importance of these amendments in descending order to be thus: 48 is most important, because it deals with the individual's liberty, guilt or innocence; 47 is next important, because it deals with the court of law and a civil action; and 46 is least important, because it is simply disclosure to the world at large.

PARA.TAB: I can understand the arguments that Senator Gareth Evans has raised in relation to No. 46. But in relation to 47, I maintain that there could be a situation where one person is suing another person and, during the course of that litigation, it comes to light that essential evidence is tied up in the ILC grant. The case might not relate to the aspect of a grant of land.

Often we see cases in courts of law where the evidence has to be produced from other sources, matters or transactions. For instance, I can cite to you family law where third parties are often brought in. A husband and wife may have gone into business together but, when they have a disagreement, they often have to involve third parties. In the interests of justice, those third parties have to be brought into it; otherwise, justice between the husband and wife could not be meted out pursuant to section 79 of the Family Law Act, which is a property law settlement.

I have just given an instance of family law. I can give a commercial instance. Someone might say, `You entered into a contract for me on the basis of something else happening.' That something else might have been that a third party, who might have been the recipient of a grant of land under the scheme, was going to do other things. For that third party, with terms and conditions attached to the grant of money, the loan or the guarantee might become relevant to the contract that the former two parties went into. I ask the committee to bear in mind that quite often in litigation, whilst pursuing matters for the defence or for the plaintiff, relevant information can come up which is entirely removed from the proceedings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ellison put his case fairly persuasively but I think I agree more with his order of priorities. I think it is most important for us to first address opposition amendment 48 because we can come back and look at amendments 46 and 47. I guess he was right to say that, given our experience on the print media committee, it would be hard for me to vote against this one as a matter of consistency.

PARA.TAB: Amendments 46 and 47 negatived.
Amendment 48 agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Democrats amendment No. 6 is very similar to opposition amendment No. 49A. While both amendments say that a review is necessary, we say, horror of horrors, that this wicked minister, this agent of government, should have the right to appoint the person who is to conduct the review, whereas the opposition says that it should be the Auditor-General who has that right. I do not have an in-principle objection to that, except to say that the Auditor-General's efficiency audits have a primarily financial focus while the sort of review we are talking about here needs to go further than financial matters and look at cultural, social and land policies and political issues.

PARA.TAB: I should point out that our review clause follows on from our original objects clause, which was not passed—it was the opposition's objects clause that was passed. I wonder whether it might be better drafting for the opposition's amendment to mirror its objects clause. That might be more appropriate but I am not going to die in a ditch over this.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have nothing to add.
—I want to indicate that the Greens are not intending to support the Democrats amendment No. 6 because we are intending to support opposition amendment No. 49A.
—I suggest that the committee hears discussion on the opposition's amendment. After that discussion, Senator Kernot may change her mind about moving her amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the benefit of all honourable senators, I will outline opposition amendment No. 49A, which has been circulated. When we said earlier in the debate that we would not impose a restriction on the land management amounts available, as proposed by the Greens, we also said that when this very important review takes place, to be conducted by an independent person, under our amendment that person would be appointed by the Auditor-General, taking things another step away from the minister's control, and that as part of their remit they would then look into the extent to which the object of this part has been achieved.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Kernot has pointed out, that links the objectives—or the beacon on the hill that Senator Ellison talked about—with part (ii) of the amendment, relating to the performance of the ILC in adhering to the principles, that is, whether it is effective, and part (iii), which relates to the balance between land management and land acquisition.

As a result of the agreement to our amendment to appropriate another $3 million for administration, and to cap that at $3 million, I formally move amendment 49A but add to it a new part (iv) to give the review the remit or the power to look at the appropriateness of that $3 million and the administration. I think that quite honestly puts into effect what we said during the debate on that particular amendment. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 42, after proposed Part 4A, add the following Division:
` "Division 15—Review

PARA.TAB: " `193U.(1) The Minister must cause a review of the operation of this Part to be conducted at 3 yearly intervals after the commencement of this Part.
`(2) A review:
(a)is to be conducted by an independent person appointed by the Auditor-General; and
(b)must assess:

TAB.TAB: (i)the extent to which the object of this Part has been achieved;
(ii)the performance of the Indigenous Land Corporation in adhering to the principles set out in section 191AB;
(iii)the appropriateness of the division of funding between the land acquisition functions and the land management functions of the Indigenous Land Corporation; and

SPEECH.PARA: (iv)the appropriateness of the provisions in section 192SAA relating to expenditure on day-to-day administration of the Indigenous Land Corporation.

PARA.TAB: `(3) The Minister must cause a copy of a report on a review to be laid before each House of the Parliament not later than 6 sitting days of that House after the Minister receives the report.".

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the principle of having the independent person appointed by the Auditor-General is an important one. I know that the government is not happy with it and I am sure that Senator Gareth Evans will say why.

PARA.TAB: The other important element in relation to what Senator Kernot has said about the Auditor-General's efficiency audits is that the Auditor-General also does performance audits and I think that the experience of that office in analysing the performance of these sorts of organisations is paramount. I remind the chamber, and Senator Kernot in particular, that we are simply saying that the independent person should be appointed by the Auditor-General. On my reading of the amendment, it does not say that the Auditor-General would necessarily do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am intending to move an amendment to opposition amendment No. 49A to delete `Auditor-General' and substitute it with `Minister'. That takes in the thrust of our amendment about who does the appointing and leaves the rest of the opposition's thrust. I move:

PARA.TAB: Omit "Auditor-General", substitute "Minister".

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's position is that we have no objection in principle to a review process. We were happy with the original Democrats proposal but we are not resisting amendment No. 49A as moved by the opposition, except in so far as the provision relating to the Auditor-General is concerned. For that reason, we will be supporting Senator Kernot's amendment to substitute `Minister' for `Auditor-General'. The essential reason for that is that the Auditor-General will already be reporting on the corporation in the exercise of his ordinary functions. We think that the kind of review contemplated and probably necessary here is more wide-ranging than the financial/efficiency audit that is the province and prerogative of the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: We really let the argument stand on its own terms. There is a lot more I could say about this but, in the interests of time and expedition, I think the point is clear. We prefer there to be the ordinary provision for reviews to be appointed by the executive government; they have to stand or fall on their own merits and credibility and I think that is sufficient guarantee and protection for the public interest in this exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I mentioned earlier, the Greens are supporting amendment 49A. We prefer that phrasing to the amendment that changes `Auditor-General' to `minister'.

—I understand what the minister is saying about the efficiency audits that are done, but I think, as Senator Campbell said, the Auditor-General is quite capable of conducting a performance review. I prefer the Auditor-General to an independent person appointed by the minister for another reason—because the Auditor-General is in fact a servant of this parliament. It takes that one step away from the executive government's power.

PARA.TAB: During this whole debate we have been trying to ensure as far as possible that the corporation operates without too much interference from or influence by the executive government. This to me is again indicative of the particular thrust of the amendments that have been moved. Therefore, I am supporting the amendment that has been moved by Senator Campbell in the belief that the Auditor-General is quite capable of conducting the type of wide-ranging—

TALK.START.PARA: —He appoints somebody.

—Yes, the Auditor-General appoints somebody. Obviously he probably will not do it himself, but he is quite capable of appointing a person who is equipped to conduct the sort of broad-ranging review that is envisaged by this amendment. It is a question of whether the minister appoints the person or the Auditor-General appoints the person. I am coming down on the side of the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: Amendment (Senator Kernot's) negatived.
Amendment (Senator Campbell's) agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I would like to make a suggestion because we are very close to our time limit and we are also very close to the conclusion of the running sheet. I understand that the Greens have some further amendments, as has the coalition. Perhaps we could debate them cognately and take the vote separately, of course. Let us try to cover the ground that is remaining, which is not that great, and try to knock it off by 6.30 p.m.
—By all means.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: P1.Schedule, page 50, before amendment of the Native Title Act 1993, insert the following amendment:
Subsection 50(2A):
Repeal the section.".
Q1.Clause 3, page 42, at end of proposed Part 4A, add the following Division:
"Division 15—Non-compensation for dispossession

PARA.EMPHASIS: Part is not intended as compensation for dispossession

SPEECH.PARA: " 193U.(1) Nothing in this part is intended as compensation for the dispossession that Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders have suffered.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Act does not prevent claims being made for compensation

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Nothing in this Act prevents a claim being made for compensation or restitution by Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders in respect of that dispossession.".
R1.Clause 3, page 42, before Division 2, insert the following Division:

PARA.EMPHASIS: "Division 16—Extinguishment of native title rights and interests to be disregarded
Extinguishment of native title not to apply

SPEECH.PARA: " `193V. Any extinguishment of native title rights and interests must be disregarded in any lands purchased, dedicated or set aside for the benefit of Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders, whether under this Act or any other law.'.".

I am prepared to debate cognately amendment Q, amendment R and amendment P. I note that Senator Campbell intends to talk to amendment 51. I do not think it will interfere with his intentions if I deal with my three amendments, especially as I am not overly optimistic about amendment P.

PARA.TAB: Amendment Q1 is very important in that it seeks to insert at the end of clause 3 a new division concerning dispossession. Currently the bill does not make it clear whether or not this legislation is intended to be compensation for dispossession. The Greens (WA) believe that this bill should not be seen as compensation and nothing in it should prevent claims for compensation being made in the future.

The Greens are concerned that the associated rhetoric from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) and the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) might lead people to understand that this is the major act of compensation for dispossession and this may then lead to the land fund being taken as compensation for dispossession. Compensation for dispossession does not come at $45 million a year. Compensation for dispossession would be incalculable. It certainly cannot be made into a neat formula that can be inserted in this legislation.

So the Greens see it as important that the legislation leaves the option open for compensation to be sought at another time and on different bases. Thus the legislation should include a clause which specifically states that this is not compensation for dispossession and that nothing in this bill prevents claims for compensation being made. That is basically our Q1 amendment.

Amendment R is also a very important amendment. It relates to the revival of native title. This amendment creates a new division at the end of part 4 of the ATSIC act, which deals with the extinguishment of native title on indigenous held land. This amendment statutorily sets aside any extinguishment of native title on any land which has been acquired, set aside or dedicated for the benefit of Aboriginal people or Torres Strait Islanders. In doing so, it provides for the revival of native title similar to the revival of native title on mining leases under the Native Title Act 1993.

If the object of this bill is to restore land to Australia's indigenous people, it is important that they have the land restored to them in terms which are appropriate to them. If this land is to be treated as indigenous held land, as the government keeps arguing, it should be treated as other indigenous held land, as land where native title rights remain.
Before I move on to amendment P, I would like to refer to two quotes. One is from His Honour Justice Brennan in his decision in Mabo (No. 2) v. Queensland, where he states:

SPEECH.PARA: As the governments of the Australian Colonies and, latterly, the governments of the Commonwealth, States and Territories have alienated or appropriated to their own purposes most of the land in this country during the last 200 years, the Australian Aboriginal peoples have been substantially dispossessed of their traditional lands. They were dispossessed by the Crown's exercise of its sovereign powers to grant land to whom it chose and to appropriate to itself the beneficial ownership of parcels of land for the Crown's purposes . . . Aboriginals were dispossessed of their land parcel by parcel, to make way for expanding colonial settlement. Their dispossession underwrote the development of the nation.

Although I wanted to refer to that quote earlier, it is appropriate that I do so now. The amendment has tremendous potential and is spiritually very meaningful. The idea for the amendment was provided by a group of people who wrote to the Aboriginal community. The letter stated:
Two key issues have come up: first, whether the $25 million will be anywhere near enough for the fund. It has been suggested that the Bill be amended to set the amount at $250 million.
Unfortunately, that amendment has been lost. The letter continues:

The second issue is what rights can be exercised over the land purchased under the fund. Currently, only the bare title will be purchased. It has been suggested that the Bill be amended so that native title revives on any lands purchased under the fund.

That letter is signed by Lucas Maynard, ATSIC Commissioner, and Michael Mansell, Aboriginal Provisional Government. It is endorsed by the Aboriginal Legal Rights Movement in South Australia, FAIRA, Queensland, and Framlingham Aboriginal Trust, Victoria. I think it is a very meaningful and significant amendment, and I would appeal to fellow senators to support it.

PARA.TAB: I might add that the people who were approached—Aboriginal brothers and sisters around the country—were not given any optimistic or unrealistic expectation that the opposition would support it, but I would like to ask it to. The letter also stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The government have not indicated support for these amendments. It is unclear what the Opposition's view would be, but it is not likely to be favourable.
If these changes are important, Government support is essential for them to be made law. Unless the Aboriginal community shows support, the Government will not move.
I hope that the government will move because of the spirit of the amendment. I commend that amendment to the committee.

PARA.TAB: The final amendment is also symbolic, but I think it has got less chance than the previous amendment of being passed. It deals with the repeal of the sunset clause in the Northern Territory land rights act. I have already discussed how I think that it was a disgrace that the sunset clause was put into the land rights act and that it passed through this chamber without a murmur. This is another chance for us to reassert our position on that particular issue.

This amendment inserts a provision in the bill to repeal section 50(2A) of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. The issue of the split of moneys between ATSIC and the ILC threw into the spotlight the whole issue of the sunset clause on claims under the Northern Territory land rights act. The whole reason for diverting half the money through ATSIC would appear to be to maximise the amount of land which can be acquired in the Northern Territory in the next three years so that it can be claimed before the sunset clause comes into effect.

I was shocked to discover that it was in fact the Hawke government which moved to place a limit on the time available for claims under the Northern Territory land rights act, which we know was introduced in 1976 under the Fraser government. I was shocked to find that there was a total absence of any opposition in either house of the parliament and I ask: why should there be a limit on time available for land to be claimed in the Northern Territory? This amendment removes the so-called sunset clause and thus allows claims over lands in the Northern Territory to continue beyond 1997. I request that the amendments be voted on separately.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to disappoint Senator Chamarette, but I am afraid that these amendments, which she describes as meaningful and significant, look pretty quixotic to us and we do not support any of them. As to the Greens amendment Q, which goes to the question of claims for compensation and argues in the proposed clause that nothing in this part is intended as compensation for dispossession, let me say just three things. Firstly, it is manifestly wrong to claim that nothing in this bill is intended as compensation for dispossession. The provision of $1.5 billion that is here provided for is certainly intended as one step in the process of recognition of indigenous dispossession and some compensation for that.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the government certainly does not want in any way to create the impression that this represents the totality of a final settlement. We have said over and over again that this is only part of the government's broad response to the Mabo decision. There is nothing in the bill which says that this is the government's final position and it certainly should not be understood as such.

Thirdly, the clause is quite unnecessary because, as a basic principle of statutory interpretation, we do not override common law rights unless by express statutory language, and there is certainly nothing in this legislation which could be so construed as an express overriding of any other claims that might be available as a matter of common law. So amendment Q hits the fence on at least three good grounds.

As to amendment R, prior extinguishment of native title being disregarded, I have to say that this is really a fairly extraordinary proposal. There is lots that I could say about it but in a nutshell it comes down to this: this proposal means that, if any land is acquired or set aside for the benefit of indigenous people for any purpose, any previous extinguishment of native title over that land will be disregarded, and presumably native title or the potential for a native title claim would be re-established.

The section will apply to any acquisition or dedication of land under any Commonwealth law whether related to this act or not, and arguably the provision will also apply to state laws as well. The section will provide for the non-extinguishment of native title, even over land which has been freehold for over 100 years. There is much more that I could say to further develop that argument and the consequences of it, but I think it will be appreciated that it is simply wholly unrealistic in terms of the basic principles of the native title legislation that we wrangled over for so long in this place.

There has to be some certainty in terms of what the effect of past extinguishments has been and the notion that native title claims could potentially re-arise, albeit with all the difficulties of establishing continuity of relationship and so on. Nonetheless, the element of uncertainty would be utterly at odds with the bargain that was struck, as it were, in the basic philosophy and approach of the native title legislation. While one understands the motivation, again I have to say that it is all a bit quixotic.

Similarly, with amendment P, the third one, repealing the sunset clause of the Northern Territory land rights act, would not benefit indigenous people, I do not think, but would certainly introduce an element of uncertainty in relation to land claims in the Northern Territory.

This again is an issue that has been hard fought over. There are elements of balance of judgment involved in the competing issues that are concerned. Indigenous people will have had over 20 years to claim land under the Northern Territory land rights act. We believe that is sufficient time to enable any claims with any character of credibility about them to emerge and to be made in that time frame. Again, it is important that we get the kind of certainty that governments have been arguing about and fighting about in the Northern Territory context for a long time. This sunset clause is an acceptable way through that, and we certainly would not accept its repeal in this particular exercise here. For all those reasons, we oppose all three of the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support almost all of the arguments used by Senator Evans. I may introduce one or two others. On compensation for dispossession, I think Senator Evans is quite right. I do not think anything we say in this legislation is going to make that debate go away, nor make any difference to the outcome of it.

PARA.TAB: I turn to amendment R, the matter about any purchase by the ILC making past extinguishments of no effect. The action of section 47 of the Native Title Act ensures that those whose ongoing link with the land is broken because there has been a past extinguishment would be able to reassert their native title rights. The effect of amendment R, as I understand it, is that past extinguishments would have been made void on any land purchased by the ILC. I think that amendment would work against the potential for the Native Title Act and the concept of native title getting broader understanding and acceptance in the Australian community, and certainly it would work against the potential for the land fund and its objects getting accepted in the broader community.
In relation to amendment P, our position on those matters has been clearly defined during this debate, and we will be opposing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Greens had included in amendment Q some indication that it was not seen as a totality of compensation, then I could have supported it. But I cannot agree that there is not some token gesture there. I think it is wrong to say that there is none.

PARA.TAB: On amendment R, revisiting the native title debate, we certainly supported certainty for past extinguishment, which is one of the reasons that we, instead of the opposition, moved the amendment for the farmers.

On the repeal of the sunset clause, I will need to go back and look at the record of what the Democrats in parliament said at that time. Senator Chamarette said that it went through the parliament without a murmur. I understand the argument here and I think that, of all the areas of Australia that need some time for Aboriginal people to work through their claims, the Northern Territory is certainly the primary case. So I am a bit attracted to that one. Senator Chamarette has asked my assistance to call a division on amendment P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to indicate that the arguments that have been advanced in opposition to Q1 and R1 are persuasive. I am supporting, however, amendment P1 of the Greens. We are talking about 1997. That is not very far away. There is a whole new ballgame now. It is all very well for the minister to say that the Aboriginal people have had 20 years to make claims. I think I heard Senator Chamarette say, `What with?' But that is slightly beside the point, I guess.

PARA.TAB: I do not normally like to interfere unduly with decisions and agreements that have been made between states or territories and the federal government. But this parliament has clearly been given the power on Aboriginal matters by the people. Under those circumstances, and having regard to my view that another 2 1/2 years is not long enough, I think it is desirable to repeal the sunset clause. What the government might like to do about that when the bill comes back to this chamber is another question.

As I said in the debate on a previous amendment, it may be coincidental that the amendment I was speaking upon had the same running time as the sunset clause. Then again, it may not be. Perhaps the government will wish to provide a little extra time. I can understand the argument that has been advanced about wanting certainty—but, in my view, this is too short a time. I believe the government ought to think about that and when this bill comes back perhaps it could provide an additional amount of time for the claims to be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a brief point. Amendment P1 raises some enormous issues. In the context of this debate on the land fund, which has been covered nationally for the best part of the last few months, the issue of repealing the sunset clause in the Northern Territory land rights legislation is not something that has been debated or given much consideration. It is a debate that should be had, but it is also a debate that should certainly involve the community in the Northern Territory and the Northern Territory government. It is a matter that should be closely considered by all involved. I think that to have that debate at this stage in proceedings is not an appropriate or sensible way for the committee to deal with it. I do not deny that the committee has the power, the right and the ability to do so, but I think it is not the appropriate time to have that debate.

PARA.TAB: Amendments Q1 and R1 negatived.
Question put:
That the amendment P1 (Senator Chamarette's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Clause 3, as amended, agreed to.
Progress reported.
