DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (51)Clause 6, page 45, lines 5 to 22, omit proposed subsections 4B(2) and (3).
(52)Schedule, page 50, proposed amendments of the Native Title Act 1993, after repeal of Part 10, insert the following amendments:

PARA.TAB: "Heading to Part 12:

TAB.TAB: Omit the heading, substitute the following heading:

SPEECH.PARA: `PART 12—PARLIAMENTARY JOINT COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE AND THE LAND FUND'
Subsection 204(1):

PARA.TAB: After `Native Title', insert `and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund'.

SPEECH.PARA: (53)Schedule, page 50, proposed amendments of subparagraph 206(d)(v) of the Native Title Act 1993, omit the amendment, substitute the following amendments:

PARA.TAB: After `Act', insert `and Part 4A of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989'.
After `NNTT', insert `or by any person under Part 4A of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989'.
After subparagraph 206(d)(vi), insert the following subparagraph:

SPEECH.PARA: `(vii)the operation of the Indigenous Land Corporation and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund established by Part 4A of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989; and'.".

I will as briefly as possible outline the effect of coalition amendments Nos 51, 52 and 53. Amendment No. 51, I presume, will not receive any support. I believe we had the substantive debate on this issue when we discussed Aboriginal trusts under a previous coalition amendment. The effect of the amendment is to remove the requirement—I will be interested to hear Senator Harradine's view on this—that organisations regarded as indigenous organisations require an interest of at least 50 per cent. I believe that debate has already been had. Senator Harradine has already indicated, when we debated a previous coalition amendment relating to trusts, that he would not support an organisation being deemed to be an indigenous organisation if it had less than 50 per cent. This would be the effect of clause 51.

PARA.TAB: In other words, it would be possible for an Aboriginal corporation to have a shareholding of indigenous people that was lower than 50 per cent. That is the effect of this amendment. We believe there are reasons why it could be an advantage in joint venture operations and so forth for Aboriginal organisations to have shareholdings of less than 50 per cent. But I indicate that I understand there will not be much support in the chamber for amendment 51.

I move to amendment 52. The effect of this amendment is to ensure that the Joint Committee on Native Title, which was formed under the Native Title Act, will maintain the role that it has been given under the Native Title Act to oversee in a parliamentary capacity as a parliamentary committee the operations of the land fund. As the land fund was initially created under section 201 and the intent was given to it by the preamble, the Native Title Act had the oversight of the implementation of the land fund as it stood. By removing the land fund from the Native Title Act and putting it into the ATSIC Act, we have effectively ensured that the Joint Committee on Native Title would not have the capacity to oversee the implementation and operations of the land fund.

The effect of this amendment would be to ensure that that does happen. We think it is a good idea that there be a parliamentary committee to oversee this, just as we have a committee overseeing the Native Title Act implementation. That committee, under the chairmanship of Senator Chris Evans, a Labor Senator from Western Australia, has already set off on a series of Australia-wide consultations with a range of interested parties concerned with the implementation of the Native Title Act. The committee has already taken evidence in relation to the land fund.

I think it would be in the very best interests of the parliament and the people of Australia that that committee maintains its role in overseeing the implementation and operation of the land fund. Amendment No 52 changes the name of that committee to the Joint Committee on Native Title and the Land Fund. The effect of amendment No. 53 is to ensure that the Native Title Act is amended so that that parliamentary committee would have the powers and the responsibilities that I have outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not support any of these amendments, although there are different degrees of passion involved in our position. We are certainly wholly opposed to coalition amendment No. 51, which I do not think has much support elsewhere in the chamber. That amendment would enable the land fund to be used, basically, to benefit interests with minimal indigenous membership and control. Whatever other flexibility one might want to invest in the corporation, I do not think anyone really wants to see that being the case.

PARA.TAB: There is also a constitutional problem with the way that this amendment would work; to provide the capacity for non-indigenous persons to benefit from the land fund to a greater extent than indigenous persons in particular cases. That is the logic of the amendment. It would not be supported by the races power in section 51 of the constitution. That would really place the whole bill in doubt. That is all that really needs to be said about that particular amendment.

The government has mixed feelings in relation to amendments No. 52 and No. 53. We rather take the view that further formal parliamentary scrutiny of the land fund is not necessary, given all the 1,001 other accountability mechanisms and reporting processes that are required. We think it de-emphasises the legitimate centrality placed upon the native title issue itself for the parliamentary committee, firstly, to have this additional function and, secondly, to be retitled accordingly. That is not an issue on which I want to waste any more time in this chamber, not least because I know that the numbers are against me.
Amendment No. 51 negatived.
Amendment Nos 52 and 53 agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to, subject to a request.
Bill reported with amendments and a request.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the report be adopted.

SPEECH.PARA: In moving that the report be adopted, let me briefly indicate the government's position on the future of this legislation. It is a very close run thing as to whether the government will support the bill even going back to the House of Representatives in its present form with so many amendments which we find unconscionable and of a character which will make the bill unworkable.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, we think the best course to follow is for the bill to be sent back to the House of Representatives, and for the House of Representatives to make a number of changes to the bill, including restoring original provisions, and for the Senate to have a further opportunity a little later down the track to reconsider its position in the hope that, with the benefit of further reflection and further consultation, some better piece of legislation will emerge.

There is much I could say on the subject of a really quite heartfelt character about our response to the swathes that have been cut through the original concept of the bill, but, given the constraints of time, I will not go into that. I want to outline the major amendments that the Senate has made to this legislation, which we think are absolutely unacceptable in the sense that they will make the bill unworkable for a whole variety of reasons. I will mention some other matters briefly, but the major amendments are seven in number.

First of all, the coalition's first amendment, amendment No. 1, requires that the ILC give priority to the most severely dispossessed in performing its functions. As we said, this opens up ILC decisions to legal challenge about who is the most severely dispossessed. It is an inherently unworkable criterion. We believe, moreover, that it is one which will cause conflict in the indigenous community and will be wholly unhelpful in advancing the basic philosophy and objectives of the legislation.

The second amendment that we have most concern about is coalition amendment No. 4 and various consequential amendments that flow from that. The amendment extends the right of the ILC to make grants to individuals and trustees. As we said in debating this amendment, this is contrary to the aim of the land fund which is to provide communal benefits. It is contrary to traditional indigenous land-holding practices. We believe it will reduce accountability.

The third problem area is that subsumed in coalition amendment No.7 which requires that grants of land have regard to health, housing and related matters. That is something that we debated exhaustively. We think the basic problem with it is that it de-emphasises the inherent philosophical force of the land fund legislation, which is to provide land as land—qua land—as a basis for the wellbeing of indigenous people. To tie the provision of land to a consideration of the extent to which a variety of other objectives will be met, which are not the responsibility of the ILC to advance, will not helpfully reflect that basic philosophy. We have the prospect of these things being justiciable and the potential for controversy as to the extent to which particular grants of land satisfy this particular criterion. A consideration of these issues again contributes to the unworkability of the legislation.

The fourth matter that we are concerned about is Greens amendment S1 which requires the ILC to consult traditional owners before acquiring land. On the face of it, it seems a perfectly innocuous amendment and one which is wholly consistent with the general consultative obligations of the ILC, and which are entirely appropriate. However, the way the amendment is cast we believe that it would make much of the ILC's activity in practice unworkable. As we see it, there will be extensive delays while traditional owners are identified. There is doubt over the meaning of `traditional owners'. We are familiar with this problem in a variety of other contexts, having debated this in the context of the native title bill. There is bound to be conflict as to who are the traditional owners.

All of these matters were exhaustively debated at the time. I am only giving a capsule summary of our concerns, but they are real, and they are not based in any sense on a lack of respect for the position of traditional owners, or a feeling that their interests should somehow be subordinated. It is just a concern that far too onerous an obligation is being cast by this amendment on the ILC.

The fifth area that causes us real problems is Greens' amendment L1 which relates to the removal of the ILC power to control the disposal of land. This opens up the possibility of sales of land granted by the ILC in order to make quick profits, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander persons being as capable as any other members of the community of not acting in accordance with the intended philosophy of this legislation. We believe it would lead, over time, to a possible diminution of the indigenous land base. It certainly would reduce accountability, as we see it, for the expenditure of public moneys, particularly when this provision is read in conjunction with that enabling the grant of land to individuals.

The sixth area of concern goes to the whole question of national and regional strategies and the relationship between them as covered by Greens amendments J2A, J6, J7 and J8. The requirement that a national strategy be based on and derive from regional strategies, and the further requirements that regional strategies be based on wide consultation—including state and territory governments—with ILC decisions being based on those strategies, and with no money being distributed in a region until regional strategies are prepared, all combine to create a whole series of real, practical problems. We are not against national and regional strategies being prepared after a proper consultative process in each case—that is what the bill already provides for—but there are still problems of working out the national and regional relationship.

The way in which the legislation is now couched, these issues—which previously were non-justiciable, in our judgement—will be justiciable, thus leading again to the possibility of further litigation, further delay and further controversy. Extensive delays in the preparation of the strategies will now be inherent, with this being a particular problem in the context of the limitation on money being distributed until regional strategies are prepared. The ILC will not have the opportunity to purchase land as new opportunities arise. There will be further avenues for legal challenges to ILC decisions in this respect. Again, I am summarising in a few sentences something which has been the subject of long debate; but I think everyone here knows what these concerns are about.

The seventh matter of concern to us is one that we addressed this afternoon. It relates to the cap of $3 million per year on ILC administrative expenditure and also to the budgetary problem of the request now being made to add a further $3 million to the pool. We see that cap as being an inhibition to the ILC's ability to operate flexibly and responsibly. While we all want to see administrative costs reduced to the maximum extent possible, the organisation has to run efficiently. There are a great many practical administrative obligations upon it—many more as a result of the amendments that have been passed in the legislation. The restriction is an artificial and unreasonable one.

In addition to those major issues—each one of those is a major issue in the judgment of the government—there are a number of other amendments that cause us concern. Coalition amendments 33 and 36 remove the requirement for the ATSIC chairperson to be on the ILC board and make provision for only one ATSIC commissioner to be on the board rather than two. Although, in practice, these are capable of being bypassed by the actual appointment strategy, nonetheless, they reflect an approach to this legislation which does not fully acknowledge the role that ATSIC has played and the real necessity of ATSIC and the ILC having a close and effective working relationship.

There are problems with coalition amendment 42, which we will need to further look at. That amendment was also debated today. It relates to additional requirements coming from the parliament for further information. There is a number of other matters of this kind which do not go to the heart of the legislation in the way that the major matters I have dealt with do; nonetheless, in combination, they add unconscionably to the practical problems that the ILC will face and, as such, need to be given further consideration by the government and by the House of Representatives.

We envisage at least those matters to which I have explicitly referred being addressed again in the House of Representatives, with the Senate having another opportunity to think about its position on this some time down the track. I genuinely and sincerely hope that those honourable senators around the chamber—such as Senator Harradine, in particular—who I know are absolutely dedicated to the cause, who want to make this work, who are not playing politics in any way with this and who have not really got caught up in Aboriginal politics will give this further, mature, considered consideration over the weeks and months ahead in order that, when this matter comes back to the Senate—as it is reasonable to anticipate it will—we might end up with a rather more workable piece of legislation than the one I am afraid we now have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond as briefly as I can to the summing-up of Senator Gareth Evans. The problem the government created for itself and for Australia was that, within a few minutes of our shadow minister, Chris Gallus, presenting the coalition's amendments to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, it said—with the advice of Prime Minister Keating, we believe—`No, we will not have a bar of any of the coalition's amendments. They are all bad. They are trying to wreck the bill.'

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened absolutely intently to Senator Evans and I will do Senator Kernot the courtesy of listening in absolute silence during her contribution. I will try to sum-up as quickly and succinctly as I can and put the position of the coalition. I ask Senator Kernot quite seriously to restrain herself from interjecting.

PARA.TAB: The problem was created because the government made a bad snap judgment and locked itself into a position. Thankfully for Australia, for the debate and for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, Senator Evans has been far more sensible in handling the amendments and, indeed, has supported many of the coalition amendments. The Democrats have also supported some of those amendments.

One of the problems the government created in that strategy was in choosing the health, housing and education so-called amendment as the big bogy. It said, `This is the thing that is trying to wreck the fund.' Anyone who looks at the amendment will see that the health, housing and education amendment was turned into the bogyman when it is not. It is like the ghost in the mind of a child: it may be scary if we dream about it for too long, but when we look it in the eye, it is not scary at all.

In Senator Evans's outline of the seven planks causing the government great distress, the point he made about Senator Harradine in this debate was a very good one. Senator Harradine is respected right around the chamber and around the nation as someone who has impeccable credentials when it comes to Aboriginal affairs issues. His support for the final Green amendment in relation to the sunset clause is testimony to those credentials.

The reality is that all the coalition amendments that were supported had the support of Senator Harradine and the support of the Greens—as they had to have in order to be passed. Anyone who reviews what Senator Evans said in relation to the coalition's position and to the bill as it now stands will know that for political reasons he has had to present a stack of reasons why the government cannot live with this bill. He enumerated seven reasons.

I urge all honourable senators to look at the nub of those seven issues. I am not going to go through them. If they look at the specifics of what he has mentioned, they will realise that, because of the position the government put itself in during the first few hours of this debate, he has had to create a monument to explain why the government says this bill has been destroyed. The reality is that the coalition has listened extremely carefully to hundreds if not thousands of people who are very concerned about this legislation.

We have seen in the past few weeks a most unique if not historic amount of cooperation, discussion and consultation between some extremely unusual partners in this debate. The discussions, cooperation and consultation we have had with people such as Senator Chamarette, with people from her office and with Aboriginal groups from around the country—if they achieve nothing else—have been very positive for Aboriginal affairs discussions and for the coalition as a whole.

We listened very carefully to all of their concerns. We made a genuine attempt to make this bill more reflective of not only the hopes and aspirations of Aboriginal people but also the hopes and aspirations of people across Australia. Frankly, if one wants to be honest about this, the way that this debate has been handled, particularly in the Senate, is probably a very genuine step in the process of reconciliation, even though I see that the chairperson of ATSIC has said that it is a step backwards in that respect. That is simply not true.

Looking at the paddle-pop sticks that Senator Evans has created in his monument as to why this bill, in his words, has been made unworkable, one just has to pick item four he raised, and that was in relation to consultation with traditional owners. It is absurd that the ILC would go to a place and seek to buy some land and not seek out the traditional owners and find their views. For the government to say, `This is one of the fundamental reasons why we cannot live with the bill as it is now amended', really shows what an absurd position that is.

The strategies issue, the $3 million extra funding that the Senate has requested from the government to fund the administration and to ensure that the moneys available for land acquisition and land management stay intact—if that is the paddle-pop stick that Senator Evans wants to build his monument out of, his monument as to why this bill is now unworkable from the government's perspective, then he really should find some more solid foundations to that monument because that really is just a paddle-pop stick.

All those involved in the coalition have, from the very outset, been genuine about this. Anyone who knows the coalition knows that it is very much a broad church when it comes to these issues. We came out from day one and said that we would seek to amend this legislation based on some principles. In one line, that principle is to ensure that the people at whom the legislation is directed are the people who are assisted. It is very much based on the principle that we should empower people back at the community level, at the individual level, to ensure that the ones who do have a big stake in this have control of it and that it is not yet another Commonwealth government organisation that has its control and its power structures here in Canberra so many thousands of miles away from those people who are so disadvantaged and indeed, in the terms of this bill, so dispossessed.

The first point that Senator Evans made was that the object of the initial land fund was made very clear in the Native Title Act. Frankly, one had to have some sort of object or principle when one dealt with this act. The words in the preamble to the Native Title Act said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is also important to recognise that many Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders, because they have been dispossessed of their traditional lands, will be unable to assert native title rights and interests and that a special fund needs to be established to assist them to acquire that land.
The first amendment on the severely dispossessed, simply in an honest way, and again supported by Senator Harradine, sought to insert that principle in the bill.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Evans is saying that that was an unworkable principle in the Native Title Act—and that is really what he is saying; that is the principle—he is saying that the Native Title Act, when we passed that preamble back in December last year, had enshrined in that legislation an unworkable principle that would have become just as debatable in courts of law if that had proceeded under the original program which was to be set up under section 2(1) of the bill.

That is the coalition's view. We welcome the fact that the government will not see through its threats just to withdraw the legislation or put all the money into ATSIC. We are glad that it will be going back to the House of Representatives. If, as a result of the sort of cooperation, discussion and consultation that has taken place in the Senate—it has been a constructive debate in many areas—we can move forward and find a bill that will resolve the differences that have been thrashed out over the last 20 or 25 hours of debate, we can achieve something historic for Australia.

But it will not be achieved if the coalition presents what are well-reasoned and well-argued amendments and the government slams the door. If there is going to be bipartisanship on these things, it needs to be a two-way operation. Clearly, in relation to the land fund bill, the government closed that door. Senator Evans has opened that door and we are saying that we will walk through it and we will be constructive about it—and I think we have been here.
I conclude on a personal note by simply recognising the contribution to this debate that Senator Ellison in particular has made. I very much appreciated working with him on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing Senator Campbell forgot to say was that the reason there was more constructive cooperation was that the coalition changed a lot of its amendments, listened to the debate and made constructive contributions as a result of that. That is a very different position from that which the government and the Australian Democrats found themselves in in the House of Representatives debate.

PARA.TAB: However, I just want to sum up briefly. There is a lot I could say but I will confine myself to this. Let us look at the checklist of what we have: we have an ILC with specified objects and principles. That is a good thing. But we have an ILC which will grant land or money for maintenance of land to Aboriginal people, including individuals, according to the criteria of most severely dispossessed, which is contestable in the courts. That is a very difficult thing. We have land which can then be sold, thereby depleting the land base, which is the very purpose of this bill. It is called a land fund bill. That is why I personally think that is very difficult as well.

We have land which has attached to it what ought to be, and what in fact are for any other Australian citizens, automatic citizenship rights. We have extensive layers of consultation in the preparation of nearly everything the Indigenous Land Corporation has to do. I can live with that. We have a diminution of the power of government and ATSIC. This lack of confidence in ATSIC is very sad. We have had extensive debate previously in this place on ATSIC.

We have a fund which is generally agreed probably does not have enough money but there is at least a top-up amendment which says that, on the government's model, the government will have to deliver on its promise of the model's being self-sustaining.

Apart from some of those details, we have had a competition of philosophies here. I cannot subscribe to the world view that governments and all government agencies are intrinsically evil or, at the very least, ill-intentioned. I do not subscribe to the view that we will never revisit the debate about land rights and dispossession.

But the most unedifying thing about this debate has been the selective championing of groups of Aboriginal people either monolithically on the one hand or very selectively without actually delineating for whom we are speaking, and then a pretence that some groups' views have some right to superiority over others. There has been an unwillingness in here, really, to accept the representative nature of ATSIC. The division that we now see in Aboriginal society is a poor reflection of the way we have conducted that part of the debate, and perhaps we can come back to that at another stage.

We have also seen a lot of romantic rubbish written about what has gone on in here. I cannot let this pass: this is Margo Kingston in the Sydney Morning Herald on 12 November, and I only point to two little sections. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Greens' insistence on real self-determination clicked with the Liberals' libertarianism. Both sides hate big, centralist bureaucracy. Both believe in devolution of power to communities. . . or individuals (the Liberals).

Sure! I can really believe that when I look at the Liberal policy processes, the Liberal formulation—very individual based! I am really convinced when I see the way the Liberals exercise individual conscience votes on matters such as the sexual conduct bill. So the Liberals have a long way to go till they convince me that there is any pretence of libertarianism in this debate at all. It is just very convenient. However, Margo Kingston goes on to say at the end:
The Opposition can now never return to its paternalistic roots on Aboriginal affairs.

That might be the price those opposite have paid for the sort of debate we have had here. If it is, then maybe it was worth having. But we might just keep our eyes on Senate estimates during the next few days to see the sort of scrutiny and principles that they apply to areas of Aboriginal spending—having regard to the way we have seen it before. The price we might be paying for their leaving behind their paternalistic roots might well be an unworkable bill which defeats the purpose of setting up a land fund. I just wonder whether Aboriginal people, monolithically or individually, think that that is a price worth paying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to make the equivalent of a third reading contribution, which seems to be what is happening here. But I thought, in light of what we have heard, that I might end the committee process by quoting from Kevin Gilbert in an interview in August 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: What are we to reconcile ourselves to? We have to look at the word `reconciliation'. What are we to reconcile ourselves to? To a holocaust, to massacre, to the removal of us from our land, from the taking of our land? The reconciliation process can achieve nothing because it does not, at the end of the day, promise justice. It does not promise a treaty and it does not promise reparation for the taking away of our lives, our lands and of our economic and political base. Unless it can return to us these very vital things, unless it can return to us an economic, a political and a viable land base, what have we? A handshake, a symbolic dance, an exchange of leaves or feathers or something like that?
And I add: or an indigenous land corporation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has given very mature consideration to the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill. In fact, the Senate has spent 27 hours and 30 minutes considering the bill in its second reading stage and in the committee stage. There have been, as has been indicated, 50 amendments and one request that have been adopted by the Committee of the Whole. This time is in addition to the time that was spent by the Senate committee when it gave consideration to the legislation. So no one can say that this matter has not been dealt with with the seriousness and the thoughtfulness that was required.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, the debate was extraordinary in this sense—that senators were actually giving their full reasons for the amendments and either voting for them or against them. Support was advanced for them by the proposers of the amendment and reasons for not supporting them were advanced by the opponents of the amendment. Persons could then take a considered view. Of course, I had a view before I came into the chamber. Some of the things I ticked I eventually did not support. I did not support all the opposition's or the Greens' amendments but I did support the bulk of them because they had that common thread.

I thank the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) for what he said about me. But I say this to the Senate: I think all of those persons are committed—indeed, the whole Senate is committed—to the rights and the wellbeing of Australia's indigenous people. I do not know of anybody here, particularly those who have been involved intimately in this debate—half a dozen senators have been here practically for all of those 27 hours and 30 minutes—who could be accused of not having a deep commitment to the rights and wellbeing of Australia's indigenous people.

The minister said that the Senate would be given an opportunity to consider the legislation again. I hope that the House of Representatives will give mature and favourable consideration to the basis of the amendments that have been adopted, the 50 amendments and one request that have been adopted by this chamber. Now is not the time—it is not the third reading stage; there is no third reading stage because there is a request—to rehash all the arguments. There will be another time for that. But I hope that goodwill shall prevail and that the House of Representatives will reconsider its view of the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe these amendments have now given this ship the rudder it so badly needed and that at least now there is some direction to this legislation. The scope of the benefit which it will cast upon the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community is now widened by the inclusion of individuals and groups. The coalition's amendments and, I also believe firmly, the amendments moved by the Greens and also by the Democrats, have been put forward in a genuine manner in an attempt to seek some profound sense of justice. I think the government should look very carefully at these amendments because I believe they go to affording a real benefit to the people for whom this legislation was intended.

PARA.TAB: The other aspects, particularly the seven mentioned by Senator Gareth Evans, need to be closely looked at because I believe they do advance the cause; they do advance that part of the preamble to the Native Title Act which we started out with back in December last year and which formed the basis of debate on this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say some words of thanks which I should have done in my earlier remarks. I refer to the officers who have been such a major source of support and input for a debate as complex, as lengthy and as gruelling as this. I would like to thank, from PM&C, Mike Dillon, Sandra Ellims, John van Beurden, Margaret Byrne, Michelle Cannane, Yvonne Fetherstone, plus quite a few others who gave them support. It is very difficult to handle an exercise like this. I know that other staffers and other officers probably deserve equal thanks.
—How about the chairs of the committees?

—The chairs of the committees deserve some thanks. I would also like to thank the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) for carrying the flag for as long as he did and as ably as he did through much of this debate.

PARA.TAB: If it is a rudder that has been put on the ship, it is one that will make sure that the ILC steams around in very unproductive circles, I am afraid, for a long time to come. One final word: the seven particular matters that trouble us more than anything else that I identified are not just cattle prod sticks designed to make some political point or maintain political face. They are really the seven deadly sins of this legislation that we have identified and that we believe have to be—

TALK.START.PARA: —Paddle pops.

—They are not paddle pops; they are seven deadly sins. There really need to be a few acts of contrition on the other side if we are to move this debate further forward in relation to those sins. But we will have another opportunity to reflect upon that. I thank the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Report adopted.

EMPHASIS.TAB: Reasons for the House of Representatives disagreeing to Senate amendments Nos. 31, 32 and 33—

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senate amendments Nos. 31, 32 and 33 are not acceptable because:

A credit ground for parts used in re-manufacturing goods sold to exempt users is unwarranted in terms of the basic structure of the sales tax law. The purpose of analogous credit grounds in the sales tax law for goods producers is to prevent the `cascading' of sales tax through different levels of the production chain. Exempt users are predominantly service providers and therefore not taxable on their outputs, so there is no question of needing to ensure their inputs are free of sales tax to avoid `cascading'.
The amendments would also introduce unwarranted complexity into the tax law and its administration.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has reached agreement with the opposition and the Australian Democrats on this matter. I wish to comment at this stage about the sales tax matter—credit for goods used and the repair of second-hand goods sold to always exempt persons. I understand that Senators Patterson and Lees are then going to move an amendment, and I will make some comments on their amendment to my motion later on.

PARA.TAB: Firstly in respect of the sales tax issue, the government, to facilitate the passage of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994, has decided to move the amendment. I understand it has been circulated to honourable senators. The amendment will allow repairers of goods to claim a sales tax credit on new parts used in the repair of second-hand goods, provided the repaired goods are then sold to always exempt persons.

The related credit ground will have only prospective effect, which is a very important aspect to the government. It will only apply to goods where the repair takes place on or after royal assent of the bill. The credit ground will also ensure that the repairer will only be entitled to the credit where the tax borne on the new parts has not been passed on to the always exempt person. This credit ground is similar to that contained in the bill for export authorisation goods.

The government considers that the amendment adequately addresses the concerns expressed in this chamber by opposition and Democrat senators, and also Senator Margetts. The amendment is explained in greater detail in the supplementary explanatory memorandum that I tabled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment just moved by the government is welcomed by the coalition. It is a significant concession by the government on the issue of sales tax liability of the parts used to remanufacture goods bought by always exempt users. While the amendment is a significant concession, it does not extend as far as the coalition's original amendment. It will only offer a sales tax credit from the date that the bill receives assent—this was always our intent—and where remanufactured goods are bought by exempt users.

PARA.TAB: Arising from this amendment, imported remanufactured goods will no longer be at a sales tax and, therefore, a price advantage compared with locally produced goods purchased for cash. I think it is unfortunate that the government was not willing to agree to extend the sales tax credit situation to exempt users in respect of lease remanufactured goods. But, on a positive note, at least some agreement and progress has been made. It has been made, I suppose, along lines similar to those arising from an amendment last year in relation to mining and agricultural goods.

The amendment will provide the burgeoning remanufacturing industry with a degree of encouragement. The amendments are also environmentally friendly by encouraging the purchase by exempt users of remanufactured goods. I think I have to perhaps acknowledge the interest of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) when he discovered the environmental aspects of this legislation. The amendment will assist with local employment, meet the increasingly responsible recycling agenda within Australia and correct an anomaly that was previously in favour of imported goods and worked very much against Australian goods.

However, I would like the Senate to note that the original coalition amendment would have also had the additional beneficial effect of rectifying another anomaly in sales tax legislation, which currently exists to deny farmers who lease remanufactured farm machinery a sales tax credit on the parts used in that remanufacture. I have drawn this anomaly to the Senate's attention before, and the fact that it is penalising farmers who opt to acquire equipment through leasing arrangements, I think, is somewhat unfortunate. Again, I ask that the tax office and Treasury reconsider this matter.
I remind honourable senators that, in times of coming out of the severe drought, the New South Wales Farmers Association in a recent press release said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is imperative the anomaly is addressed because of the expected high rate of leasing of reconditioned farm equipment once the drought breaks. Few farmers will be able to afford to buy secondhand equipment let alone new machinery. The most likely option for farmers will be to lease reconditioned equipment.
That would have been a secondary benefit that would have flowed from our amendment in relation to the remanufactured goods to always exempt users.

PARA.TAB: I would like to reiterate that it is simply unfair that farmers who purchase remanufactured farm machinery for cash get a sales tax credit on parts used in remanufacture but those who lease the goods do not. Discrimination on the basis of method of acquisition is not only a significant variation from the pre-streamlined sales tax position but also a major distortion to the financing decision by farmers.

On a very positive note, I believe there is some work being done by Treasury and tax in relation to this issue, and maybe something positive may come out of it in terms of the government's package. Again, I urge the government to give serious consideration to this anomaly. In relation to what has been achieved so far, I thank the government for picking up the thrust of our amendment and expressing as its own terms. I have no problem with that.

I thank the officers from the office of the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), Treasury, the Australian Taxation Office and also Mr Neil Olesen, who cooperated very closely but very firmly on this whole matter. I think it is an outcome where we are certainly making considerable progress, but in relation to the leasing aspect there is perhaps some way to go in the future, not only in the relation to the sales tax on the parts used to remanufacture goods for lease to exempt users, but also to the sales tax on the parts used to recycle farm machinery leased to farmers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment that I have circulated is being moved jointly by the coalition and the Democrats as a compromise to facilitate the passage of this bill so that the home child-care allowance can be properly implemented and some of the confusion surrounding the HCCA reduced. I will speak briefly on this because the coalition's concerns were covered exhaustively in the second reading of this bill and the subsequent debate in the committee of the whole.

PARA.TAB: I simply want to reiterate what the coalition has said from the outset: that thousands of families will be worse off when the government moves them from the dependent spouse rebate, under the taxation regime, to the home child-care allowance, under the Department of Social Security. I stress that the coalition supports the concept of the home child-care allowance. From the outset, we acknowledged the real benefits that derive from recognising the contribution of those parents caring for children at home by paying an allowance directly to them.

However, the coalition has had grave concerns from the beginning that families would be worse off as a result of the government's legislation. When this was first mooted, one of my staff, with help from the library, systematically searched for which families would be worse off. That search produced a quite exhaustive list of the differences made to various families, depending on whether they were on the dependent spouse rebate at the with or without child rate or on the home child-care allowance.

The changes that are being made jointly by the coalition and the Democrats will mean that families will be able to continue to claim the with child rate of the dependent spouse rebate at the end of the financial year and deduct any HCCA they have received. This will mean that they will receive a top up if they are worse off with the HCCA. Families will have access to the with child DSR even if they have qualified for HCCA but not claimed it.

The compromise is that the with child rate of the DSR will not be indexed, so that over time—approximately six years—the rate of the indexed without child DSR will surpass the frozen rate of the with child DSR, effectively ending the dual system. The residual system will still exist, whereby those who may be worse off under the HCCA rules compared with DSR could continue to get the DSR level of assistance. However, as the relative value of the with child DSR declines, there will be an increasing incentive to obtain the HCCA because the HCCA rate will be higher and will be available fortnightly. From the coalition's point of view this is not the ideal solution to the legislation's defects. However, as I said, it is a compromise which hopefully will reduce some of the confusion surrounding the home child-care allowance.

There is a great deal of confusion out there in the community amongst those eligible for HCCA. For example, many people believed that they would retain their with child spouse rebate while getting the home child-care allowance. As a result of that confusion, many employees have continued to take their DSR during the year while their spouses have been claiming the HCCA. These people will have to find the money to repay this double dipping at the end of the financial year.

The government has admitted that it has totally botched the implementation of this allowance. In a recent media release, the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Gear, admitted that many taxpayers may face an unexpected tax bill at the end of this financial year because of the confusion surrounding the HCCA. There are many families who are not in a position to afford that and who are in for a shock. I remind the chamber that when we first debated this matter Senator Harradine said over and over again that there would be a problem with this.

The widespread confusion which has beset the HCCA could have been avoided if the government had allocated resources to informing families of the abolition of the with child dependent spouse rebate equal to those used in promoting the introduction of the home child-care allowance. I suppose the government does not want to tell people the bad news—that it is taking one thing from them without giving them another—it only wants to tell them the good news, and that is where the confusion arises.
Of course, the government has attempted to blame the opposition for the bungling associated with the HCCA, claiming that:

SPEECH.PARA: The confusion is being unnecessarily fuelled and extended by the Opposition and the Democrats.

I refute that. I refuse to accept it. I think that is absolutely appalling. The government should have got the legislation right in the first place. For it to turn around and blame the coalition and the Democrats is totally unacceptable. This is the government's legislation. It was not workable from the beginning and it has left many families worse off. Now the government has the hide to turn around and blame the coalition and the Democrats. That is rich!

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—Who said that?

—That was Senator Abetz giving me a bit of support. The government is blaming the opposition for this because it wants to shift the blame somewhere else. Well, let me put this back fair and square in the government's court; this is the government's problem. I hope people realise that they were cheated at the election. We bear no responsibility for this situation, none at all. It is the role of government to ensure that its legislation is submitted to the parliament in a timely fashion for scrutiny and debate. It is the government which must accept the responsibility for and the consequences of not introducing this bill in the parliament earlier.

PARA.TAB: The home child-care allowance, as I have previously stated, was conceived not out of a genuine concern for families or for those who care for children at home, but out of the basest desire to win votes at an election. The HCCA was Mr Keating's key election policy commitment to women. His pledge during his campaign launch was `this allowance is more generous than the dependent spouse rebate it will replace.' That was nothing short of a cunning deception.

From the beginning the home child-care allowance was a policy conceived with deliberate deception, flawed in its original drafting and implemented with incompetence, trickery and bungling. The bottom line is that despite Mr Keating's promise that the HCCA would be `more generous' than the benefit it replaced, that will not be so for thousands of families. The changes that are being made jointly by the coalition and the Democrats will partly alleviate this situation because families will be able to continue to claim the with child rate of the dependent spouse rebate, although the with child rebate will not be indexed and will be claimable only at the end of the financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment arises as a result of negotiations between the Democrats, the government and the opposition and has, I am pleased to say, been endorsed and jointly sponsored by the opposition. I also need to add that I am speaking on behalf of Senator Lees who, on behalf of the Democrats, was involved in those negotiations. The amendment achieves our dual objectives of ensuring that no family is worse off this year because of the cashing out of the DSR and its replacement with the HCCA; and providing a substantial and increasing incentive from 1995-96 onwards to transfer from the rebate system to the allowance. Our key concern in this issue is that the number of people disadvantaged by the new system could be very substantial. Statistics on this are not yet available and will not be fully available until late 1995 at the earliest. If, after looking at the statistics at that time, it proves that our concern was unfounded, the Democrats will be willing to reconsider this safety net package.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to go over this debate again; we have had this debate already. But I do remind the government that the HCCA proposal, as has already been pointed out by me and others, contains serious anomalies whereby many families would suffer and not gain in shifting from the dependent spouse rebate to the HCCA.

PARA.TAB: By way of example, families moving overseas for a temporary period would still be subject to Australian tax but would lose the HCCA after 13 weeks. The DSS definition of income is broader than the taxation concept of income. In fact, tax agents gave evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public administration of the difficulties with the HCCA scheme. It was said, for example, that a woman might have to file 26 claim forms a year for the HCCA if her income fluctuates above the $10.88 per fortnight. Now that these anomalies have finally sunk in, the government has changed its mind and has decided to retain the spouse rebate but only at the without child rate.

There has been a compromise, and I suppose that is something, but the compromise involves the freezing of the spouse rebate at the current with child level with no indexation. As Senator Lees has indicated, in about six years time, those claiming the DSR instead of the HCCA will get the without child DSR. In other words, in six years time those caught by the HCCA changeover anomalies will get nothing from the tax system or HCCA for their children. They will be treated as though they have none. That is economic blackmail pure and simple. The proposal before us would also stop employees with children from claiming PAYE instalment variations to take account of the DSR. Employees with spouses and no children will continue to get tax instalment deductions varied to take account of the DSR.

The change to HCCA from DSR is an administrative bungle of the first order. Hundreds of thousands of one-income families are having their financial privacy invaded for a measly $2.60 a fortnight. As Senator Patterson indicated, they thought they were getting another $30 in addition to what they had already. It may be an unintended deception, but it was a deception on the part of the government.

DSS is not even administering the law correctly. I put it to the committee, and to the parliamentary secretary particularly, that thousands of self-employed spouses are being denied their entitlement. HCCA is legally based on fortnightly income of the spouse, yet the Department of Social Security told the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration at its meeting on 19 September that for the self-employed it is working on a previous year's taxable income. Mr Tune made that comment in answer to a question by Senator Watson. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The definition of income being used in the social security system for HCCA purposes for the self-employed is to basically use previous year's taxable income.

Where is the legal basis for this administration? There is none. That is a very important question that just has not been answered. I ask the parliamentary secretary to please tell us now where the legal basis for that statement of Mr Tune is. There is none.

PARA.TAB: There is another aspect, and I raised this previously. Gifts are included as income in the DSS definition, as distinct, of course, from what happened with DSR. I ask the minister how this is applied to an individual unit instead of a married couple income unit when we look at gifts from one spouse to another. The minister has not produced any legal advice on this obviously unintended consequence. But I have had the matter looked at, and a gift from a husband to wife, for example, technically means that her claim to HCCA should be reduced. Technically that is the situation. That is ludicrous, is it not?

Many workers just give their pay packets to their wives. Theoretically and technically that excludes her from receiving HCCA. There would be a riot if it actually happened, but that is the technical situation. The minister should look at those questions seriously and perhaps should, in the upcoming estimates, give us some responses. Ultimately, I believe the legislation will have to be duly amended.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 14th report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation entitled Superannuation Regs II—Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations, together with submissions and the Hansard transcript of the evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek to leave to have my tabling speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Background

PARA.TAB: The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations prescribe the standards that apply to the operation of superannuation entities, that is: regulated superannuation funds, approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts. Those standards currently relate to a variety of issues such as the provision of information to members and other persons, the management and trusteeship of superannuation entities, matters associated with public offer entities, the financial management of funds, eligible rollover benefits and many other matters.

SPEECH.PARA: This report, Super Regs II, is the second of two reports of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation on the regulations relating to superannuation. The first, Super Regs I, which examined the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Regulations, was tabled on 29 August 1994.

In the inquiry resulting in this report, Super Regs II, the committee sought to find remedies to some of the more technical policy problems which have arisen since the SIS framework was established. The recommendations aim to fine tune the operation of the regulations and in some important measures, to make it more consumer-friendly.

The issue of member investment choice, more accurately referred to in the report as beneficiary investment choice, was the subject of more evidence and submissions than any other feature of the SIS regulations. The committee makes three recommendations concerning member investment choice, the most important one recommending that, member investment choice become mandatory for all standard employer-sponsored funds with more than 50 members. This, however, must be phased in over a period of, say, five years.

The committee considered that the intervening period would allow the education campaign conducted by the Australian Tax Office with the assistance of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, various other agencies and the private sector interests to educate the community into the consumer elements of superannuation. The committee recommended that member investment choice be made a component of this education campaign.

The committee also considered that the intervening period until member investment choice is mandated could be usefully employed by superannuation funds to upgrade their administrative and technological capacities to cope with the additional demands that would be placed on their operational systems by the introduction of member investment choice.

In the absence of widespread community demand for member investment choice, the committee has been proactive in recommending the eventual introduction of mandatory member investment choice for a number of reasons. These are:
(i)to promote competition between funds;
(ii)to enhance consumer understanding of superannuation;

(iii)to empower individuals who are compulsory members of funds to influence their superannuation arrangements and provide them with an increased sense of ownership of their superannuation balances, thereby assisting them in achieving the objectives of self provision in the Government's retirement incomes policy.
The committee also believes that choice of fund would promote these objectives, but has refrained from making recommendations about mandating choice of fund membership.

The committee has recommended that the current standards under the SIS regulations governing member investment choice be relaxed to allow trustees to formulate individual investment strategies on the condition that they are consistent with the overall investment strategy of the fund affected.
Other recommendations made by the committee in this report include recommendations that the Government:
review, and if necessary, move to limit the extent of exposure of superannuation funds to derivatives transactions;
review and remedy any unnecessary constraints on the legitimate investment activities of superannuation entities
reconcile the conflict between the sole purpose test under SIS and the recovery of Commonwealth debts;
amend the definition of `member' to include pensioners and deferred beneficiaries;
amend the definition of `beneficiary' to allow full access to funds' internal complaints mechanisms and the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal;
fine tune some of the disclosure requirements;
review the rules concerning small funds with non-arms length members;
reduce the presumed age of retirement;
finalise the tax treatment of commutations of allocated income streams; and
refer a number of other technical problems to the ISC for resolution.

Super Regs II reports to the Senate the evidence presented in relation to an arrangement struck between the AWU/FIME and the administrators of the Nationwide Superannuation Fund, whereby the union received 20% of the administration fee levied by the fund in return for marketing the scheme.

The committee accepts the advice by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer that it was not uncommon for administrators to enter into agreements with third parties for promotion of a particular superannuation product. The only unusual feature of this arrangement was that it was a union that was the third party.
I commend this report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The main point I would like to make about the Joint Coal Board's 47th annual report 1993-94 is in relation to pages 24 and 25. Although there is not an actual page or section dealing with the environment in this report, this particular section is called `International training'. What narks me most of all is that we have Australian International Development Assistance Bureau aid going through as environmental aid.

PARA.TAB: Why that gets me is that we are talking about Australia using the latest coal technology in the developing world to enable them to lessen their dependence on imported oil and substitute this with lower-cost coal as a principal power generation and industrial energy input to their economies. At the same time, these countries are encouraged to `protect their environment' through the use of clean coal combustion technology developed in Australia.

When we consider the debate in the media and in this chamber in recent times in relation to Australia's inability to meet its greenhouse commitments, it is outrageous in the extreme that Australia is giving aid as environmental aid in order to have access to markets to sell more Australian coal. This is not just an interpretation. The last paragraph on page 25 says:

SPEECH.PARA: If Australia can continue to contribute to this economic development while at the same time ensuring that the vast quantities of coal which will be consumed are produced and utilised in an environmentally responsible manner, we will have made a contribution to the economic and social advancement of the developing world.

It is all about selling more Australian coal and replacing another fuel source, oil, with one that actually contributes in a greater amount to the world's greenhouse gas emissions. Some people said at various times during the debates on this particular issue, `Oh, it is about replacing dirty coal technology with cleaner coal.' It specifically says that it is about replacing oil with coal. The only thing that is perhaps cleaner about this is that it might be a lower sulphur coal. That is not to do with greenhouse gas emissions, and I am pleased to say that they have not attempted to pass this off.

PARA.TAB: I wonder about the actual commitment of the Australian government, through the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, to international environment when it tries to pass off this nonsense as environmental aid. Yes, it might have something to do with reducing sulphur emissions if it was a matter of choosing between Australian coal, with or without the sulphur scrubbers or without the particular process, but we are not even talking about the best available technology for CO2 reduction. We do not even use that in Australia. We are not using that for the proposed Collie power station. The reason we are not using it is that it adds something like 25 per cent onto the price.

If we were to produce coal in the manner that is being used in other places in the world as best available technology, it would be rejected in Australia. That is the real cost of producing coal technology. The real cost is producing it in a way that reduces the CO2 emissions to a considerable extent. If we are not doing that because it is too expensive and because it makes other methods of power financially more attractive, then what the heck are we doing? How can we hold our head up in the world and say we are doing the best for the environment when we are using precious aid resources and calling it environmental aid? I think it is a disgrace. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: The first point that I wish to make in the context of the ADI report is to express my concern about the very late tabling of this report. Given the new estimates process this year, these annual reports are really all that is left to enable a proper examination of the activities of government departments and associated organisations. Yesterday we had the ludicrous situation in which we were being asked to examine the activities of the Department of Defence in the Estimates Committee without having access to the ADI annual report.

PARA.TAB: This year among the highlights outlined in the report is the signing of a joint venture agreement with Lend Lease for the development of the property at St Marys in Sydney. This site is currently used to store miscellaneous nuclear waste which the government was suddenly so anxious to move, so much so that it drafted regulations allowing virtually open slather in relation to the removal and transport of nuclear waste under the ANSTO Act. It is interesting to note that ADI is already exempt from state and other regulations under section 122A of the Defence Act in a similar manner to the exemptions available to ANSTO under the ANSTO Amendment Act 1992.

My concerns about this issue have already been placed on the record. ADI is also selling off properties in Maribyrnong and Footscray in Melbourne, and in Canberra as part of its restructuring. It will build a new munitions factory at Benalla in Victoria. I note that there is a Victorian inquiry into these plants, and their failure to abide by Victorian environmental regulations, as a consequence of section 122A(2)(a)(ii) which exempts ADI from `the environmental consequences of the use of land or premises,' and under 122A(1)(c) extends that exemption to `any act or thing done by or on behalf of ADI' under state or territory laws. This means that this exemption applies to any company planning links to ADI in this proposal.

It is our understanding that ADI has actually decided to clear up the mess, at least to its own satisfaction, because it wants to sell off this property. It is well located, the economy has picked up, and it should make a good return. So it is with a sense of irony that I read on page 26 that ADI has now developed an environmental service component which it is actively marketing. I also wonder where the profits from these sales will go. How much will be returned to consolidated revenue and how much will go to defence or be rolled back into ADI to make its suggested sale more attractive?

I would also like to make a few comments about the new Minehunter MHC program. I note that the last Minehunter program, the MHI program, was a disaster. It was poorly thought out and poorly planned from beginning to end. After $150 million was spent to produce two boats that basically could not be used in more than a gentle breeze, the Joint House FADAT committee delivered a report damning the project and it was abandoned. This one seems a bit better, but there remain a number of serious problems.

The MHCs are relatively standard hulls and will probably handle a swell a little better than the MHI. I note that one of the major failings of the MHI, apart from the fact that the thing could not go out in waves, was that Defence demanded the latest high-tech sonars that did not work. They have repeated that mistake in the MHC. It has planned the use of very expensive Raytheon sonars that can be dropped to various levels below the ship. These are used in the Baltic where there is relatively little ocean temperature variation, unlike Australia. They have never been used in this sort of environment.

If they do not work, efforts to make them work will prove exceedingly expensive, and there is little justification in having them, given the location of our submarine bases, the existing intelligence networks on mines, and the lack of any threat of the kinds of mines this system is designed to detect.

It is also another example of setting up an industry from scratch under ADI. This practice has added $220 million to the cost of each Collins submarine and Anzac frigate we buy. Whilst I acknowledge that this has provided employment, it seems to be heavily subsidised employment. The MHC hull is simple. Certainly there are shipyards in existence that can build them. I believe this is just another example of wanting a guaranteed contract to make subsequent sale of an asset more attractive. It is a practice the taxpayer pays for and which does nothing for defence. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
