TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address this evening the presentation of annual reports. I would like to congratulate the departments which tabled their annual reports prior to the deadline of 31 October 1994. The setting of the deadline meant that information contained within the annual reports would enable parliamentarians, in particular those senators involved in the Senate estimates process, to make informed judgments about the effectiveness of any one department in meeting its program objectives.

PARA.TAB: Under the revisions introduced to facilitate scrutiny by the Senate of departments, the annual reports are now key accountability documents for reviewing departmental outcomes for the previous financial year. On 17 March 1994, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts agreed with the proposal put forward by the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet to significantly reduce the number of detailed requirements on which departments must report in their annual reports. However, this came with the proviso that there would be no diminution in the information available to members and senators.

Departments must continue to maintain information previously available in the annual reports and, furthermore, to provide this information on request. The Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of Finance were instrumental in implementing these revisions to the accountability process. Where such information is not included in the annual reports, it was agreed that it must be made available on request to members and senators and members of the public, once the report has been tabled. The Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet's own guidelines outline that the information should be provided to the person requesting the information within five working days of the day of the request. I quote from a letter to the secretaries to departments from Bill Blick, First Assistant Secretary, Government Division, Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, in which he states:

SPEECH.PARA: The time frame for the provision of this information has been set at five working days from the date of the request after annual reports have been tabled. This arrangement would be the subject to any negotiation between departments and the Member of Parliament or Senator making the request. If the requester wants the information no later than five days after the request, departments do not have the discretion to extend the deadline without agreement from the requester.
The letter also states:
Commonwealth authorities whose operations are similar to those of departments should consult these revised requirements and comply with them.

What I am most concerned about is the breach encountered by many senators' offices in obtaining information previously available in the annual reports. This concerns not only breaches of the guidelines but difficulties experienced by senators' offices in obtaining the relevant information previously available.

PARA.TAB: What is of greater concern is the breach of these rules by the very department instrumental in establishing these guidelines—none other than the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. The department has been generous in providing to my office a number of explanations, after the expiry of five working days, as to why certain information was yet to be provided to my office. The information requested finally emerged some seven working days after the initial request.

I suggest that this is a very embarrassing position for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to be in. And if the department is not embarrassed, then it ought to be embarrassed. The department instrumental in obtaining permission from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts to revise annual report requirements is now one of the first departments to breach its own guidelines.

I have also had problems obtaining information from the Department of Administrative Services. This department failed to respond to telephone calls when a initial request for information as made on Monday, 7 November 1994. When the request was finally recognised on Tuesday, 8 November, my office was informed that the person who was normally assigned to the task of distribution of the additional information was on sick leave for some three weeks. Naturally, I have not received the information requested from the Department of Administrative Services within the five working day deadline.

I do not begrudge anyone sick leave. However, the rules as agreed by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts are in place. There is something fundamentally wrong with the operations of a department of over 7,800 public servants if it is unable to provide me with the information requested within the required time frame just because one person is on sick leave.

My office and, I believe, a number of other senators' offices, in requesting this information from various departments, have been provided with a number of excuses by officers of those departments as to why information previously available in the annual reports is not available and may not be available on request. Excuses range from department staff on sick leave to no understanding of the new requirements, and from provision of inaccurate and incomplete information to information which should be provided under these new provisions not being listed in the annual report.

What guarantees will be provided to parliamentarians that they will receive requested information when the very department which established these guidelines cannot abide by the rules? That, I submit, is unacceptable.

The parliament, in particular the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts, has been generous to lessen the rigorous reporting requirements for annual reports. I have no doubt that the joint committee did this with reservations and concerns about the potential for departments to abuse the guidelines. The saying `Give a yardstick to the department and it will take a mile' seems to be ringing loud and clear as a result of these changes to reporting requirements.

I remind all departments that non-compliance with the provision of the information is a breach of the undertakings and guarantees provided by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of Finance to the clerks of the Senate, members of parliament and senators. It is regrettable that their word is not their bond, even when their word has been provided in writing.

I sincerely hope that the excuses provided by departments and the non-compliance of the guidelines are only as a result of teething problems faced by the changes to the reporting requirements. There are some very good reasons for the annual reports to be more user friendly and more cost effective. However, I am opposed to this if the result for parliamentarians is a reduced ability to scrutinise the effectiveness of departmental program objectives. The scrutiny and accountability of all government departments and their administration are matters of importance to all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about a matter which I think is of very serious concern and should be of serious concern to the Senate and indeed to the parliament. It relates to what seems to be blatant interference by a member of parliament in commercial arrangements between a government body—namely, the CSIRO—and a company known as Bridlewood Pty Ltd, which is owned by Mr David Battersby and his wife of Modbury Heights in South Australia. The member of parliament in question is Mrs Chris Gallus, who is the member for Hindmarsh in South Australia. Her actions, on the basis of the information provided to me and what I have been able to ascertain as a result of my own investigations, have placed Bridlewood and Mr Battersby and his family in a position where they are confronted with substantial financial losses for expenses incurred and may be sued for damages, all of which could force them into bankruptcy through no fault of their own.

PARA.TAB: Mr Battersby, who is a small business person, is only young—he is 31. He and his wife have three children aged two, five and seven. Mr Battersby and his wife run a small carpet laying business and endeavoured, through the course of a process, to enter into advertising. As part of that process, Mr Battersby contacted the CSIRO in relation to property that the CSIRO owns in South Australia with a view to putting up advertising billboards on that property. Mr Battersby sent a proposal to a Mr Kevin Howard, who is the business manager of the human nutrition business enterprise of the CSIRO at Glenthorne. That was on 21 May of this year.

About mid-June Mr Howard rang Mr Battersby and agreed that the CSIRO, or certainly the human nutrition operation, was interested in the proposal and sought to meet with Mr Battersby to look at the type of signs that he proposed to put up at the site and to look at signs that Mr Battersby already had up at Parafield airport. They travelled to the airport and inspected the signs. Mr Battersby gave Mr Howard a copy of the contract that was used between him and the FAC for the putting up of signs on the FAC property. Mr Howard indicated that any process of commercial arrangement would have to be approved by the corporate services division of the CSIRO in Canberra, and that process was ultimately entered into.

On 12 July Mr Battersby received a draft copy of an agreement proposed to be entered into between the CSIRO and David Battersby and Bridlewood. He requested on 13 July two minor changes, and both were agreed to. He received three copies on 29 July of a contract for signing by both him and his wife, and they did so. They then proceeded to go through the process of making this proposal become a reality.

Once having got the original contract signed by the manager of the corporate services division, Mr Battersby entered into an arrangement with a company to start making the billboards. He also employed the services of a company to conduct soil tests so that the foundations and so on could be put in for those billboards.

All of that went along very well until such time—it was around September of this year—as a Mr Mike Patchell of the corporate services division phoned Mr Battersby, saying that Chris Gallus was causing a lot of problems and that some other advertising companies had been ringing up. He indicated to Mr Battersby that if the development and everything else was done legally and properly he had no worry.

Mr Battersby rang Chris Gallus to ask her what the problem was. By all accounts, Chris Gallus said to Mr Battersby that the project was dead; that he should get a good lawyer; and that, whilst she did not like to see anyone go bankrupt, from where she sat, he was going to go under, and he was playing in the big league now. Mr Battersby had never been officially advised by the CSIRO that the contract was over. Indeed, he received other information from the manager of another advertising company that he had heard from a competitor that the project was dead.

This really brings into question why Chris Gallus got involved in this and what her interest was. It is not in Chris Gallus's electorate. Certainly, the Glenthorne property is in Kingston, and Chris Gallus is the member for Hindmarsh. If you look at what Chris Gallus did prior to entering parliament it might throw some light on the question of why she got involved.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—I do not like to interrupt, but I would ask you to refer to the member as Mrs Gallus.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry; I do apologise. If we were to look at her CV, we would see that she was an advertising executive—I do not know for which company. But one would have to assume, as I said, on the basis of the information I have from my own investigations, that Mrs Gallus rang up on behalf of another advertising company. It seems that the real reason behind Mrs Gallus's intervention was that another advertising company felt that the price that Mr Battersby had entered into to pay rent for putting the signs up was insufficient. Yet he had done everything in accordance with the law. He had entered into a commercial arrangement, but it just so happened that other people did not like it. Therefore, Mrs Gallus apparently chose to intervene.

PARA.TAB: What happened thereafter was that Mr Battersby did receive a call from a Mike Patchell of CSIRO, who said, `The contract is over.' Yet it was a signed contract, copies of which I have. Mr Battersby had not received any written confirmation of that and, to this day, has not received any written confirmation of that. Quite clearly, the only reason that I can ascertain for the contract being terminated—and I have spoken to CSIRO officers and other people—although it has never been put in writing to that effect, is because Mrs Gallus intervened.

As I said earlier, Mr Battersby is confronted with very severe financial losses. I do not think it is appropriate for a member of parliament to act in this way. It appears that there was no good reason—and certainly Mr Battersby has been given no valid reason—as to why this actually happened.

So I intend to continue to pursue this issue but. As well I have written to the minister responsible for CSIRO and asked him to investigate the actions of CSIRO in this matter. I do not think that CSIRO's action with regard to the termination of the contract can go unnoticed.

Quite frankly, this is a very sad and sorry event. This person has no capacity to meet the costs of some $70,000 that he has outlaid and has no capacity to meet the possibility of being sued for a substantial amount of money for contracts that he sought to let for the placing of advertising. For instance, Channel Seven had entered into a contract with an advertising firm for placing an advertisement on one of those billboards for the next 12 months to the tune of about $60,000. As I said earlier, under the circumstances, this is not the sort of behaviour we would expect of a member of parliament, certainly, I would think, not something we would expect from a conservative member of parliament who purports to stand up for small business in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order now, as I did not want to interrupt Senator Murphy's speech earlier. Can you rule on whether Senator Murphy was casting aspersions on a member of the other house? I listened carefully to his speech and I thought that towards the end he may have done so. Could you rule on whether he should withdraw any imputations of wrongdoing by Mrs Gallus?

—I am not sure that I need to make this point, Mr Acting Deputy President, because I think it is so clear to you. What Senator Murphy has done is something that happens consistently in this place as part of the political debate. If we were to give the interpretation to those words that Senator Panizza asked you to give, we would not have question time and we would not have half the debates that we have in this place. It is getting a bit late and I think we are all getting a bit sensitive. Perhaps Senator Panizza is getting a bit defensive. I would argue that what Senator Murphy has done has been very much within the standing orders and has been for a long time.

—I do not see that Senator Murphy has transgressed the standing orders. I would suggest that Mrs Gallus has the opportunity of using the House of Representatives in relation to the matters that have been raised if she so wishes.

—I accept that ruling, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you have given it. I take it I may now speak on the adjournment. Before I do, I would like to point out to Senator Murphy that there is a convention in the Senate where, if a senator gets up to bucket another senator or a member of the other place, he or she advises that other person of that intention. I presume that Senator Murphy has done so in this case. Perhaps he could give me some indication at some other time rather than now. I certainly hope that he did carry out that convention.
—Senator Bolkus put him up to it.
—Oh, did he?

—I ask that Senator Abetz withdraws that inference. I knew absolutely nothing about what Senator Murphy was going to raise. Senator Murphy is big enough to make his own statements in this place, and I am big enough to do my own work.
—It was an imputation, Senator Abetz.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, are we going to be in a situation where the words `Senator Bolkus put him up to it', referring to the making of the speech, is an imputation? Senator Bolkus was out of his place and was interjecting and making oral noises. He was assisting Senator Murphy in the speech. So it was quite obvious that Senator Bolkus was actively involved in it. To say that somebody was put up to giving a speech, which did not transgress the standing orders is, with respect, not an imputation on anybody.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the same point of order: I support what Senator Abetz has to say because even if he did accuse Senator Bolkus of putting Senator Murphy up to delivering this speech—and you ruled that Senator Murphy cast no aspersions on Mrs Gallus—I cannot see that that is an imputation against Senator Bolkus.
—Mr Acting Deputy President—

—Senator Murphy should wait for his turn. I could put someone up to ask Senator Bolkus a difficult question in question time. I do not think there is anything wrong with doing that. I invite you to rule that Senator Abetz does not have to withdraw.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the same point of order: the two matters are totally unrelated. Senator Abetz, in his normal grubby way, made an interjection that definitely was an imputation against Senator Bolkus. Senator Bolkus had no information with regard to what I was seeking to raise in speaking on the adjournment here tonight.
—I wish I did.

—What he says is probably right: he wishes he did. He probably would have wanted to do it himself. Quite frankly, I think Senator Abetz should be asked to withdraw that imputation because the two matters are totally unrelated. I can quite categorically say that Senator Bolkus had no idea—in fact, none of the members on this side of the chamber had any idea—of what I intended to speak on tonight.

—There was a clear imputation that Senator Bolkus was doing something untoward. Senator Bolkus has indicated to the Senate that he was not aware of the speech or its contents, and I would ask Senator Abetz to withdraw the imputation.

—I may be wrong on a matter and that is different from being in breach of standing orders. That is, with respect, the matter that ought to be exercising your mind as to whether or not a comment should be withdrawn.
—You have been asked to withdraw. Just withdraw it and stop the crap.

—I am getting hungry, so I am more than happy to withdraw. But in doing so, I have been referred to as being involved in `grubby' activities by Senator Murphy. I have been accused of `crap'. I would have thought, with the greatest of respect to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that those two words and inferences are a lot more offensive than the words I have just withdrawn. I would suggest that Senator Murphy be invited to withdraw.

—Sometimes while being in the chair it is best to have a deaf ear, otherwise things do get in the Hansard. I did not refer to that latter remark. I think the latter remark was unparliamentary. Now that it is in the Hansard, I will ask for its withdrawal. I do accept that you have withdrawn.
—Both comments—`grubby' and the other one.
—`Grubby' is not unparliamentary. I do take it you have withdrawn?
—Yes, absolutely.
—Senator Murphy, do you withdraw that latter remark?
—I withdraw.

—I do remind Senator Murphy that we have the convention, and I certainly hope he has extended that convention to Mrs Gallus, a member of the other House. She will no doubt defend herself in any way that she can on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 15 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware: (a) of recent changes to the conditions for the supply of advertising space in the Yellow Pages; and (b) that customers are required to open credit accounts and make payments 6 months in advance of distribution.
(2) Given these new conditions, has Yellow Pages made any new guarantees on the service it provides.

(3) When the existing Yellow Pages joint venture was set up, was any consideration given by Telecom to the implications for the level of competition in the directory services market, and is the Minister aware of any representations to the Trade Practices Commission on this subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on information provided by Telecom and the Trade Practices Commission:

PARA.TAB: (1) Telecom has advised that:

(a) There have been no recent changes made to the conditions for the supply of advertising space in the Yellow Pages directories. The existing conditions have basically remained unchanged for some 15 years.

(b) Customers are not required to open credit accounts. All customers (other than those whose advertising contract is typically less than $500 or those who have been repeated defaulters) are offered a choice of instalment payments and are not required to pay the full amount on the signing of the contract. Arrangements for such instalment payments are arrived at through negotiation between the customer and Yellow Pages Australia.

Generally, under the instalment arrangements, Yellow Pages Australia requires that the payments be made by a maximum of ten instalments paid over a maximum of ten months between the date of contract signature and no more than two months after publication.
(2) See response to (1) above.

(3) Telecom advises that before the joint venture which provides sales, marketing and compilation services in respect of Yellow Pages directories was established (as Pacific Access Pty Ltd), Telecom cleared the proposal with the Trade Practices Commission.

The Trade Practices Commission has advised that at the time the joint venture was formed there were no section 50 implications arising from the formation of the joint venture. Since then the Trade Practices Commission advises that a number of complaints have been made on a range of issues in regard to Parts IV and V of the Trade Practices Act. I am advised by the Trade Practices Commission that it is presently making inquiries and discussing the issues raised with Telecom and Pacific Access Pty Ltd, concerning directory entries, disclaimer clauses and the conduct of selling agents.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Veterans' Affairs: Grants to Trade Unions and Community Groups

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 24 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the department, or any of its agencies or statutory authorities, approved or made available any grants, or other forms of payments, to trade unions or community groups in the 1993-94 financial year, if so, in each case: (a) what is the name and adddress of the trade union or community group which received the funds; (b) what was the amount involved; (c) what was the purpose of the payment; and (d) under what program was the payment made; (e) who approved the payment, and (fl what acquittal requirements are there pertaining to the payment and are there any outstanding acquittals.

(2) Has the department, or any of its agencies of statutory authorities, approved, made available, or does it intend to make available, any grants, or other forms of payments, to trade unions or community groups in the 1994-95 financial year, if so, in each case, please provide details as per (1) (a) to (f).

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) There were no grants made to trade unions by the department. There were, however, a substantial number of grants made to a wide range of client organisations.
(a) The names and addresses of these organisations have been provided to Senator Short separately.

(b) The total amount of grants for the 1993-94 financial year is $4,352,974.47. The total amount of grants for the 1994-95 financial year is $1,120,928.00. Details have been provided to Senator Short separately.
(c) The purpose of these grants is to provide financial assistance to various client organisations of the Department. Details have been provided to Senator Short separately.
(d) These grants were made under the Hostel Development Scheme, Joint Ventures, Minister's Discretionary Fund and Grants in Aid Programs.

(e) Grants made under the Minister's Discretionary Fund, Hostel Development Scheme, Grants in Aid and Joint Ventures are approved by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Grants under $10,000.00 or less under the Joint Ventures Scheme are approved at Departmental level.
(f) The acquittal requirements vary but generally it is achieved by relying on audited statements from the recipient organisation, or production of documentation that verifies the use of the grant.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 30 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Which lighthouses in New South Wales are listed for sale by the Australian Government.
(2) What price was determined as being a realistic value for each of these lighthouses.
(3) Who determined these evaluations.
(4) With whom did the Federal Government consult to reach these evaluations.
(5) Have any of the lighthouses been sold; if so, for what price, and to whom.
(6) Has there been any price negotiations with the NSW Government.
(7) Does the Minister see State Government retention of the lighthouses as a priority; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA), which owns and operates Commonwealth lighthouses, currently has 15 properties in New South Wales listed for disposal. These are at Barranjoey, Burrewarra Point, Cape Byron, Green Cape, Evans Head, Fingal Head, Kiama, Nobbys Head, Norah Head, Point Perpendicular, Point Stephens, Richmond River, Smokey Cape, Sugarloaf Point and Warden Head. Of these properties, 14 are available for purchase by the NSW Government and the other, at Point Perpendicular, has been leased to the Department of Defence.

(2) AMSA has determined a book value of $3.536m for the land and improvements for the 14 properties. This valuation was prepared on the basis of the sites' existing use. The Commonwealth has offered the properties as a block to the NSW Government at this valuation.
The valuation of individual properties is considered by AMSA to be commercially sensitive information.

(3) During 1991/92 AMSA engaged independent valuers, Edward Rushton Pty Ltd, to determine values for AMSA's properties. The valuations were carried out in accordance with guidelines issued by the Department of Finance.

(4) During the course of the valuations, detailed discussions were held between Edward Rushton Pty Ltd, AMSA, the Australian National Audit Office and Coopers & Lybrand (AMSA's internal auditors). The valuers employed by AMSA also consulted with local planning authorities.
(5) No lighthouses in NSW have been sold.

(6) During April 1993 AMSA offered 12 of these properties for sale to agencies of the NSW Government at their book valuations. The Premier of NSW wrote to the Prime Minister on 11 June 1993 seeking transfer of the properties at no cost to the State. The Government has considered the request of the Premier, but has decided that it could not agree to transfer the properties at no charge. The Government is, however, prepared to offer some assistance to the NSW Government in the purchase of these properties. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport wrote to the Premier of NSW in early October 1994 offering the properties for sale for $3.536m and offering a grant of $0.275m to cover transaction costs and remedial repair work.

(7) The Commonwealth Government recognises the heritage and cultural values of many of these lighthouses and the environmental considerations involved in their disposal. With these considerations in mind, the Commonwealth does see ownership of the lighthouses by the NSW Government as a priority. The Commonwealth has, therefore, offered the sites for purchase by the NSW Government at their existing use valuations and has also offered a grant to cover the transaction costs and remedial repair work.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 13 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Industrial Relations laws in NSW which have left migrant women open to exploitation, low pay and dangerous sweatshop working conditions:
(1) Has the NSW Government changed the industrial relations laws to prevent unions exposing such inhumane practices.

(2) Do these laws force unions to give employers 7 days notice of a visit, gain a certificate of entry from the NSW Industrial Relations Commission, and only visit workplaces which already have union members.

(3) Have recent visits to workplaces in western Sydney revealed that migrant women are being exposed to dangers such as needles in hospital sheets, without being warned in their own language of the risks of HIV and hepatitis infection.
(4) Have cases been found in one clothing workshop of women being paid $3 an hour when the award rate was $13 an hour.
(5) Have the industrial relations laws of any other State been changed along similar lines.
(6) What action can the Federal Government take to protect workers, particularly women migrants, from these draconian laws.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

PARA.TAB: (1) The NSW Government has changed industrial relations laws to make it more difficult for unions to undertake workplace inspections. Under section 733 of the NSW Industrial Relations Act 1991 (the NSW Act), which was introduced by the Greiner Government and commenced operation in March 1992, union officials must adhere to a number of requirements before entering a workplace for the purpose of investigating suspected breaches of an award or agreement.
The Act repealed the Industrial Arbitration Act 1940 and the Trade Union Act 1881. A State-wide general strike, the first in NSW in 65 years, was held in protest at the introduction of the new Act.
(2) The NSW Act requires a union official to give an employer seven days notice of a proposed visit for the purpose of investigating suspected award breaches or non-compliance with the NSW Act.
In addition, for the purpose of investigating suspected award breaches or non-compliance with the NSW Act, a union official:
is only entitled to visit a workplace where members of that union are employed. If no union members are employed at a workplace, union officials have no right of access;
must be authorised to do so by the NSW Industrial Registrar; and
can visit only during working hours.

Where a union official wishes to visit a workplace for the purpose of talking with union members, there is no requirement to provide notice of the proposed visit. However, in such cases a union official is only entitled to talk with the employees during lunch time or other non-working time.

(3) I am aware of a visit to the Parramatta Linen Service by the Leader of the Opposition in NSW, Mr Carr, which reportedly revealed inadequate health and safety protection of workers including dangerous working practices and inadequate infection control.

Under the NSW Occupational Health and Safety Act 1983, the Parramatta Linen Service must ensure the health, safety and welfare at work of its employees to the extent reasonably practicable. Responsibility for ensuring compliance with the occupational health and safety regulations in NSW lies with the WorkCover Authority of NSW.

Worksafe Australia, the operational arm of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, which has responsibility for declaring national occupational health and safety standards, has developed a national code of practice for health care workers and other workers at risk of the transmission of HIV and hepatitis B in the workplace.

Worksafe Australia has approached State and Territory regulatory bodies seeking to incorporate the national code as an approved code of practice under the principal occupational, health and safety legislation in the State or Territory. To date, all State and Territory regulatory bodies, bar Victoria, have indicated a willingness to consider doing this. The WorkCover Authority of NSW has indicated that it will be taking this step in early 1995.

(4) Yes. In March 1994, the NSW Minister for Industrial Relations and Employment released the findings of a task force set up to investigate award and occupational health and safety compliance in the clothing industry.

Task Force inspectors from the NSW Department of Industrial Relations, Employment, Training and Further Education and the Workcover Authority of NSW visited over 300 workplaces and issued over 220 notices and fines for offences including under-award payments and breaches of safety regulations. Under-award payments included cases where workers were being paid as little as $3 an hour.

In response to the report, the NSW Minister established a strategy group comprising NSW Government agencies, the Labor Council of NSW, the Textiles Clothing and Footwear Union of Australia (TCFUA) and the NSW Retail Traders' Association to consider longer term strategies. The Leader of the Opposition, the Labor Council of NSW and the TCFUA are calling for the NSW Government to restore union right of entry.

The Federal Government has granted $260,000 from the Workplace Reform Program to the TCFUA for a national outworker campaign aimed at informing clothing industry workers and their employers of their rights and obligations. The campaign commenced in May 1994 and has included a telephone information service in ten community languages and interviews of workers and employers by project officers.
(5) The industrial relations laws of a number of States contain provisions similar to those in the NSW Act regulating the ability of union officials to enter a workplace.

The South Australian Industrial and Employee Relations Act 1994 was introduced by the Brown Government and commenced operation on 8 August 1994. The provisions in this Act regulating the ability of union officials to enter a workplace are substantially similar to those contained in the NSW Act. However, under the South Australian legislation:
a union official is not expressly restricted to visiting during working hours;
a union official need only give "reasonable" notice of any proposed visit; and
a union official needs to be authorised by a State award or enterprise agreement, rather than by the State Industrial Registrar.
The provisions of the Tasmanian Industrial Relations Act 1984 regulating the ability of union officials to enter workplaces are also similar to the NSW Act. However, under the Tasmanian legislation:
a union official need only give two working days notice of any proposed visit; and

a union official need not gain any form of authorisation to visit the workplace, although the official must make a declaration of secrecy before a Justice of the Peace prior to inspecting any employment records.

Under the Victorian Employee Relations Act 1992 introduced by the Kennett Government, union officials have no general statutory right to visit a workplace for any purpose. This is also the case under Western Australian legislation.

(6) Workers employed under State awards may gain greater protection by obtaining federal award coverage. Where workers are covered by a federal award, union officials have greater rights to visit that workplace for the purpose of ensuring award compliance.
Under section 286 of the federal Industrial Relations Act 1988 (the IR Act), a union official may enter a workplace for the purpose of ensuring the observance of a federal award, provided:
the union official is authorised to do so by the Secretary or Branch Secretary of the union; and
the union official enters the workplace during working hours (subject to any conditions laid down in the award).

The IR Act does not require union officials to give notice of any proposed visit. Union officials may also visit a workplace where no union members are employed, provided the employer is bound by the federal award or work to which the award applies is being carried on.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, upon notice, on 13 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why has the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) established a new research laboratory in France, while at the same time sacking five agricultural research scientists in Western Australia, one of whom is the world leader on medics and clovers that put nitrogen back into the soil in natural pastures between wheat crops.
(2) Did the Minister give his approval for the establishment of this laboratory, and how was it paid for.

(3) When CSIRO's chief executive, Dr Stocker, told the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on 2 September 1994 that CSIRO funds were actually being increased for rural research, was this French project included.

(4) Was Dr Stocker's statement to the committee misleading in that the `agricultural' research funds to which he referred include numerous off-farm manufacturing research projects involving farms products, which would not normally be classed as agricultural research but instead as `manufacturing' research, such as `food technology'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) has recently completed the construction of a new laboratory complex on the Agropolis International Campus at Montpellier. The laboratory was officially opened by the Hon Barry Jones, MP on 10 October 1994. The new laboratory provides better facilities to support the research of the Division of Entomology, which has been present at the site since 1966 but in rented accommodation.

Montpellier is an internationally recognised site for research into biological control of weeds and insect pests with climatic similarities to Australia which enables field testing prior to importation of control agents into Australia. One successful outcome from Montpellier was the introduction of a rust disease to control skeleton weed in wheat farming systems in the early 1970s which has saved the industry hundreds of millions of dollars. Current projects include collaborative projects with State Departments of Agriculture in Victoria and New South Wales. Following the establishment of the CSIRO new laboratory, the US Department of Agriculture has decided to move laboratories from Paris and Rome to Montpellier and the French National Institute for Agricultural Research (INRA) is also consolidating on the site, providing excellent opportunities for collaborative projects of benefit to Australia.

The establishment of the new laboratory commenced in 1988 and its strategic importance is a completely separate issue from those which led to the recent restructuring of the Division of Animal Production and the retrenchment of 5 staff in Western Australia.
(2) Ministerial approval for the acceptance of grants to establish the new facilities at Montpellier was obtained in May 1990; and for the entering into contracts for the construction in July 1992.

The total cost of the laboratory is approximately $2.3 million with CSIRO paying for the land and part of the cost of construction. Other major contributions have come from Australian rural research and development corporations and French local and regional government as follows:
Meat Research Corporation—$446,500
Grains R & D Corporation—$200,000
Aust Wool Research and Promotion—$446,500
Region of Languedoc Roussillon—$250,000
District of Montpellier—$175,000

(3) Dr Stocker, addressing the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on 2 September 1994, (now Senate Economics References Committee) presented a number of ways by which investment in rural research could be measured. One of these ways—expenditure directed towards those Socio-Economic Objectives (SEOs, one of three classifications developed by the ABS as part of the Australian Standard Research Classification) which would between them cover the area of rural research—showed an increase in CSIRO expenditure on rural research, in real terms, between 1990-91 and 1993-94. Expenditure on the research laboratory in France would have been included in these figures.

(4) Dr Stocker focused on the main issue being addressed by the Inquiry, the funding and resourcing of research related to rural industries. This research is broader than `agriculture' and, in addition to farm-based activities, includes manufactured inputs to on-farm production, environmental aspects and post-farm storage, transport and processing of rural production.
In his address, Dr Stocker showed a number of ways of quantifying CSIRO's commitment to the rural sector, including:

a table showing the actual and projected appropriation allocations for the Organisation's two rural-based Institutes, the Institutes of Plant Production and Processing and Animal Production and Processing, from 1989-90 to 1996-97;
a graph showing CSIRO's expenditure by socio-economic objectives (SEOs), for period 1990-91 to 1993-94; and

another table showing expenditure on research for 1990-91 and 1993-94 under the headings inputs to farm, on-farm production, post-farm processing and other rural-related. This table was compiled by CSIRO using SEO details and presented in response to a request by Senator Chapman at an earlier hearing.
It is clear from the proof Hansard for this hearing, that Dr Stocker went to great lengths to explain the basis for the figures to avoid any suggestion of being misleading.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 17 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why is it that the details of the 1993 scores for C-rated drama and hours of C-rated programs could not be made available to the Australian Children's Television Action Committee by 30 August 1994.
(2) Please provide a copy of the 1993 scores to Senator Alston as soon as they become available.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Committee did not request 1993 compliance information from the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA). The ABA provided the chairperson of the Committee, Mr Max Hall, with published compliance information for 1990 to 1992. The ABA also published preliminary figures for drama (including C drama) on 1993 compliance by broadcasters with its standards in July and Mr Hall received a copy of those figures at that stage. However, teething problems with a new computer program have meant that the scores for 1993 have not yet been finalised. In view of the exemplary record of all commercial broadcasters in compliance with the minimum requirements for C drama and hours of C and P programs since introduction of the standard in 1990, the ABA is satisfied that this temporary delay poses no threat to the objects of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992.

(2) The ABA will shortly be publishing information on compliance with the Australian Content and Children's Television Standards in its journal, `ABA Update'. When it is published, the honourable senator and the Australian Children's Television Action Committee will be provided with the information.
